Company Name: Bankers Reserve Life Insurance Company of Wisconsin
text: In addition, the company has engaged in other green initiatives with constituents  Examples include our LEED Gold corporate headquarters as mentioned in Question One, and working with our partners (various state Medicaid agencies) to replace certain required hard copy provider directories with online versions which will significantly reduce the usage of paper products across the organization

Frontlines management team together with the board of directors are prepared to issue a public statement in case of a disaster, and every aspect of the business continuity will be addressed with respect to our customers, vendors, employees, companys finances, controls, and short- and long-term expectations to all our stakeholders Aside from the Disaster Recovery Plan, the company also maintains contracts with reinsurance companies, which allows for more predictable results in case of such emergencies as the reinsurance companies are able to absorb larger losses and reduce the amount of capital needed to provide coverage
We are putting more fuel efficient vehicles in the fleet to reduce our fuel expense This will also reduce our emissions

Key examples include significant increases in electronic applications, capabilities for electronic payment of policyholder premiums, electronic payments of disability benefits and reductions in mailings Initiatives are currently underway related to eApplication and electronic policy issuance, electronic billing notifications and electronic claim benefit statements through web technologies We have reduced the paperwork required for certain types of claims 
With regard to employees, please reference our response to question 1 plus their key role in reducing paper and energy usage through technology innovation We are processing increasing amounts of work electronically, eliminating paper usage We utilize an electronic document storage system eliminating the need for physical storage of paper records We have installed keycard access printers to further monitor and reduce our employees paper usage Similarly, with business partners, we encourage electronic vs paper communication Regarding regulators, we maintain strong capital and financial resources to withstand all forms of adverse risk events, including climate change

Questions to consider include:
	For what perils does the company believe that future trends may deviate substantially from historical trends due to changes in the hazard? Similarly, for what perils, if any, does the company believe that a catastrophe model extrapolating observed trends would be insufficient to plan for maximum possible loss or yearly average loss? What steps has the company taken to model or analyze perils associated with non-stationary hazards?  We have not evaluated these future trends to date
	Has the company used catastrophe models to conduct hypothetical stress tests to determine the implications of a wide range of plausible climate change scenarios? We have not
	Has the company conducted, commissioned or participated in scenario modeling for climate trends beyond the 1-5 year timescale? We have not
Therefore, we do not have a formal climate change policy with respect to risk management and investment management

N American natural catastrophe exposures are monitored in house using the AIR model with regular comparison against the RMS models Modelled results are based on warm sea surface temperatures 
(WSST), which recognize the impact of climate change on sea temperatures In addition, in house models have been developed to monitor accumulations following recent increased incidents of hail

MFM utilizes a risk management platform provided by our reinsurance broker This allows us to assess specific hazard exposure by location such as wildfire, hail, wind, earthquake and flood This platform provides hazard rating and scoring based on historical data

Changes in the rate and severity of natural disasters and weather patterns present a significant risk to level of claims that Landcar receives These types of events could have a significant impact on the financial results of the company We continue to evaluate our business processes in order to identify means whereby we can improve our operations and decrease our impact on the environment Our consulting actuaries perform quarterly loss reserve calculations taking into consideration multiple risks including climate change that could affect severe weather conditions and higher loss ratio

Earthquake and hurricane deductibles as well as named storm deductibles are used, as allowed, and various options are available  Hurricane deductibles may be eliminated in some locations for policyholders if loss mitigation measures are undertaken as well  We also assist our customers after a loss to take certain measures to prevent further weather related losses

Arbella encourages our commercial property policyholders to manage their exposure to loss from weather related events through interaction with our loss control department Arbella has increased our staffing in loss control over the past two years to help our insureds manage risk and mitigate loss that can result from wind, precipitation, flood and other environmental factors Our loss control representatives consult on property recommendations such as roof maintenance, snow removal, drainage, and best practices to prevent wind damage In addition, we make recommendations related to emergency preparedness and contingency planning Arbella offers other products such as Flood Coverage and Earth Movement to protect our insureds from catastrophic perils while offering adequate and fair deductibles to make the coverage affordable

Our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) team accounts for climate change in our risk management as one of many risks that the team assesses  Nationwide Investment Risk Management gives consideration to geographic risk which includes, among other things, the potential long-term effects of climate change in a number of ways across asset classes  Nationwide Investments includes a view on climate change, alongside other factors, when evaluating potential investments
For more information on how Nationwide accounts for climate change in our risk and investment management, please see our responses to questions three, five, six and eight

Therefore, it is important that we also take a long-term view on the risk factors that may have an adverse impact on our portfolio, which includes climate change Hence, sustainability and climate change are essential topics for us Our asset management has a well-defined framework, which considers ESG criteria consistent with the Groups Code of Conduct, and has a commitment to sustainability The overall responsibility for sustainable investing lies with the Group Chief Investment Officer, supported by the Asset Management Investment Committee and the Asset Management Executive Team Furthermore, an ESG Advisory Group, formed by representatives of all investment units, legal, compliance and risk management, oversees and monitors the progress of our responsible investment activities and ensures that our commitment is reflected in our day-to-day activities

The Group Asset Management Responsible Investment Policy defines our commitment to sustainability The policy outlines in particular the principles for all responsible investing activities which include asset classes, investment manager selection, portfolio monitoring and reporting, voting (through the reference to the Swiss Re Voting Framework) and engagement

Swiss Re's strong commitment to sustainability is also defined in our Sustainability Risk Framework This framework enables us to identify and analyze potential ESG risks within an investment The framework consists of two umbrella policies on human rights and environmental protection, and seven policies on sensitive sectors or issues: the defense industry; oil and gas (including oil sands); mining; dams; animal testing; forestry and logging; pulp & paper and oil palm; and nuclear weapons proliferation Each policy contains a number of predefined criteria and qualitative standards that may lead to the exclusion of a company or a country from our investment scope Following a recent review, we extended our exclusion list to include companies potentially posing a significant reputational risk to investors due to controversial business activities from an ESG perspective Our Asset Management unit applies all mentioned criteria to our investment assets, and excludes companies and countries if they do not meet the pre-defined criteria and qualitative standards

Swiss Re is committed to investing its assets responsibly via a controlled and structured investment process, integrating environmental, social and governance (ESG) criteria As part of our continuous improvement, we switched to benchmarks composed of higher ESG rated companies for our listed equity and corporate bond portfolios Thus, we apply sustainability related risk factors consistently along our entire investment process Material outcomes are incorporated into our investment decision making

As a long-term investor, we consider ESG factors that may have an adverse impact on the sustainable value of our portfolio, such as climate risk and carbon footprints For the systematic and regular integration of such ESG factors, we apply sustainability ratings to our investment portfolio As a result, we measure our exposure to carbon emissions in listed equities and corporate bonds in a systematic manner

For our rates product portfolio that mainly includes government bonds (incl agency), we have implemented a concept of minimum ESG rating standards at country level considering political risk, human rights, and environmental factors that affect the resilience of countries as part of our ESG practice Assessment results guide our responsible investment decisions to ensure the targeted ESG quality of our government bond portfolio The sustainability rating is of particular relevance from the perspective of climate change as it measures not only the overall social and governance situation in a country but also its environmental aspects This allows us to consider environmental management in any country in our investment strategy 

In 2017, Swiss Re's Asset Management receives the highest rating for its responsible investment approach ("Strategy & Governance") the second year in a row Swiss Re scores among the top 15% of all signatories of the United Nations' Principles for Responsible Investments 

In Swiss Re's real estate investments, sustainability criteria play an essential role We apply ambitious sustainability standards For projects in Switzerland, the applicable criteria are defined in the Energy Mission Statement of Swiss Re This stipulates that all new buildings need to conform to the MINERGIE standard (wwwminergiech), a Swiss quality label specifying high levels of energy efficiency and superior user comfort When an existing building is due for renovation, this standard applies whenever it is feasible from an architectural, technical and financial point of view By the end of 2016, the combined value of our MINERGIE®-certified buildings reached USD 04 billion, or 22% of our Swiss portfolio of direct real estate investments The total energy consumption surface in accordance with the MINERGIE® standard was 82'497 m2 at the end of 2016 In addition, more than 59'000 m2 had been sold on to third parties

Since 2015, Swiss Re has also invested in the US real estate market The investment managers approach to sustainability includes GreenGuide: Sustainable Property Operations, a best practice guideline for sustainable and efficient real estate operations; ULI GreenPrint Foundation, a global environmental management platform; and LEED Certification from the US Green Building Council

At the end of 2016, approximately 44% of our investment portfolio was managed externally For more systematic and regular monitoring of the actual integration of ESG factors into this portfolio, we have engaged the services of a leading ESG research company This expert provides in-depth research, ratings and analysis of the environmental, social and governance-related business practices They assess our portfolios relative to traditional as well as tailored ESG benchmarks built up on the following criteria: 

	Environmental: Climate Change, Natural Resources Use, Waste Management and Environmental Opportunities;
	Social: Human Capital, Product Safety, Social Opportunities;
	Governance: Corporate Governance, Business Ethics, Government & Public Policy

Results are used to better understand the implications of incorporating ESG considerations into our investment decision-making process and to further improve the quality of our investment portfolio For that, we work closely with the external managers to ensure they consider these ESG aspects in their investment processes The managers individual performances are monitored in line with our Responsible Investment Policy, and they are required to report regularly on their responsible investment activities  The next step is to provide a deep-dive analysis on the portfolio's inherent carbon emissions to get detailed transparency and to better manage the risks and opportunities associated with climate change 

Furthermore, we actively contribute to a low carbon economy by investing in the growing SSA (sovereigns, supranationals and agencies) green bond market, primarily relying on the Green Bond Principles Moreover, as part of our commitment to sustainability, we invest in green bonds in our credit mandates, as well as renewables and social infrastructure in our infrastructure private debt mandates Debt raised through green bonds is used to finance environmental responsible projects that provide clear benefits from that perspective We are well advanced in meeting our investment target for green bonds of at least USD 15bn

In order to mitigate the risk of stranded assets, we have also adopted a policy to avoid investments in companies that generate 30% or more of their revenues from thermal coal mining or that use at least 30% thermal coal for power generation We divested from all related equity positions and the vast majority of our fixed income holdings

We have also made funds available to remove snow and ice from the insureds roofs in the northern territories to reduce the possibilities of roof collapse due to the weight of ice and snow which could result from climate change

PCS has, however, established a Sustainability Committee, which helps the PacificSource family of companies strive for ways to reduce its carbon footprint Through a focus on the environmental impact of our operations, we have successfully implemented a number of green initiatives We have a goal of developing sustainable facilities Our Springfield, Oregon office was constructed for workflow efficiency, to maximize energy efficiency through thoughtful lighting, window covers and IT infrastructure, and to maintain green space by keeping our property adjacent to the river in its natural state to help sustain the local eco-system A portion of PacificSources undeveloped land has been used to establish a community garden project Additionally, our office building in Bend, Oregon was awarded LEED gold certification for its energy efficiency The Green Initiatives Committee has also focused on the reduction of paper use through a number of Information Technology (IT) and education projects It has greatly reduced the use of bottled water in our facilities, developed a composting and recycling plan, and curtailed the use of disposable dishes and cutlery

Company Name: Kaiser Foundation Health Plan of Washington
text:
KP partners with nongovernmental organizations, community groups, industry stakeholders and others to increase knowledge about climate change, encourage reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, and increase resilience to climate change-influenced events such as droughts In 2018, KP was the leading health care sponsor of the Global Climate Action Summit in San Francisco, and CEO Bernard J Tyson addressed the conference Mr Tyson shared this video to illustrate the health risks attributed to climate change, and how organizations are coming together to address this as a matter of population health: https://youtube/yeih2v4P25A 
Furthermore, KP has: 1 joined RE100, a collaborative, global initiative uniting more than 100 influential businesses committed to 100 percent renewable electricity; 2 helped found the California Healthcare Climate Alliance, a collaborative of health care organizations, facilitated by the NGO Health Care Without Harm, to urge policymakers and climate action advocates to integrate health and healthcare considerations into the development and implementation of climate change policy; 3 joined the Ceres Business for Innovative Climate and Energy Policy coalition to promote responsible bi-partisan public policy; 4 signed onto the Ceres Connect the Drops campaign on water stewardship, a campaign that showcases the strong leadership of California companies and policymakers to advance water solutions that ensure sustainable management of the states stressed, and often unpredictable, water supplies
KPs web site details our efforts to be a leader in advocating health in all policies and all sectors, and in working to end health disparities We have been active in developing and promoting policies and projects that afford greater access to more active modes of transportation and that support local food production and sustainable sources of healthy food In 2010, KP helped to successfully defeat a proposed rollback of Californias strong climate change laws
KP has worked with Eli Lilly and Company (Lilly) and the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB) to develop a water risk analysis framework for the supply chain of commodities (specialty chemicals, packaging, etc) that Lilly purchases for two of its major diabetes products for the US market UCSB used the World Resources Institute Aqueduct tool to identify first-tier suppliers located in water-stressed areas and developed a system to evaluate commodities produced in areas of relatively high water risk The insight gained into water-related risk associated with suppliers can better inform future sourcing decisions by Lilly Lilly has used the information to assess if current supplier risk-management practices are adequate and to determine if additional data are needed to support sound risk-management decisions Lilly has also evaluated how they might apply a similar framework to other products
As described in our response to Question 3, KP has supported improved research and risk analysis on the impact of climate change
Our companies do business globally and could be affected anywhere in the world where we do business

The Company's operations are not impacted by climate change and as such there is no associated risk  Without more specific information it is impossible to predict any financial effects on the business

NORCAL reviews its long-term strategic asset allocation annually Based on the latest strategic asset allocation study, NORCAL has determined that climate risk in the portfolio must be monitored, but no immediate actions are necessary to proactively modify the portfolio

Company Name: American Standard Insurance Company of Wisconsin
text:
Also in 2008, the company completed a third party-reviewed greenhouse gas emissions inventory The sustainability plan includes a mission statement and a triple bottom line structure that details American Familys commitment to environmental stewardship, social responsibility and economic efficiency 
The environmental, social and economic activities of this plan align directly with our strategic plan serving to drive company-wide initiatives, such as emissions reductions in our operations The number one objective is reducing greenhouse gas emissions A primary strategy for greenhouse gas reduction is the creation of a corporate Energy Management Strategy Team with the goal of continuously improving the efficiency of owned facilities This cross disciplinary team has representation from Information Services and Data Center Management In 2012 variable frequency drives were installed in data centers and non-data air conditioning centers to reduce energy use Other actions include the reductions of waste, water use and operational impact on land In addition we practice social responsibility programs by advocating supplier and employee diversity, delivering a robust employee wellness program, and ensuring that employee training, community relations and marketing activities are carefully aligned with our sustainability objectives
American Family also supports reducing the impact of business travel and employee commuting through increased use of webcasts and videoconferencing Since 2006, video conferencing systems and other telepresence technology has provided virtual communications alternatives in order to reduce travel In April 2012, The League of American Bicyclists designated American Family Insurances Madison, Wis, headquarters as a Bronze Bicycle Friendly Business (BFB), based on best practices for staff and the greater community 
In 2008, the company established an energy management baseline and goals Owned real estate is actively maintained with the Energy Star portfolio and includes multiple certifications To date, a 20% overall energy reduction has been achieved resulting in 22,000 metric tons of CO2 emissions reductions Solar panels have been installed in four locations for a total of 40 KW of renewably sourced power Complementary programs include building envelope upgrades, HVAC fixtures and controls, retro-commissioning projects, electrical fixture and controls updates, and behavioral modifications such as employee programs to power down equipment when it is not in use Water reduction of 25% was achieved at the conclusion of 2011 Initiatives have been put into place towards achieving a Zero Waste goal including the recycling of organics, office paper and pre-consumer organic waste Reductions in the consumption of paper and office supplies have also been achieved Beginning in 2013, 40% of our customer-facing correspondence is sourced from 30% and 10% post-consumer content, saving an estimated 440 metric tons of CO2 at current volumes A variety of recycling programs has been implemented which include office supply streams, cell phones, chargers and obsolete electronic equipment In some of our larger facilities ice/water machines are provided which has reduced plastic bottled water consumption Weve also provided staff with reusable metal water bottles to use at the ice/water machines, eliminating the use of disposable cups
Due to the limited Estate assets, liquidator is not in the position to use those assets on compliant surveys

Accordingly, for each response in this survey, a reference to Cambia is also a reference to each of those carriers collectively (ie, Asuris Northwest Health, Regence BlueShield, Regence BlueShield of Idaho, and Regence BlueCross BlueShield of Oregon)
Cambia does not have a formal plan to assess, reduce, or mitigate its emissions in its operations or organizations However, Cambia does have a formal sustainability program that seeks to incorporate the triple bottom line framework (economic growth, environmental stewardship, and social equity) into its planning, decision-making, and operations The sustainability program includes efforts to incorporate greater environmental stewardship into company operations Working with Cambias Real Estate and Facilities department, Information Technology (IT), and Human Resources, Cambia has undertaken the following efforts that will result in reduced greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions:
	Information Technology (IT): There are several efforts within Cambias IT infrastructure where technology and date center infrastructure changes have resulted in efficiencies directed at power, cooling, and space:
o	Major cooling upgrade to Salt Lake City data center
o	Switch to more efficient servers
o	Server virtualization
o	Mainframe consolidation
o	Increased data storage efficiencies
o	Replace firewall infrastructure with a more energy-efficient system
o	Replaced load balancer infrastructure with a more energy-efficient system
o	Upgraded our call center telephone system
o	Recycle eWaste though a BAN-certified eCycler
o	Shift to print on demand and double-sided paper
	Real Estate and Facilities:
o	Replaced aging HVAC system (boilers and chillers) with more energy efficient system
o	Established standardized HVAC temperature set points, to maximize unit efficiencies, which reduced energy consumption
o	Implemented daylight harvesting in Burlington, and implementing in locations when remodels occur
o	Changed lighting in Salem garage from sodium vapor to fluorescent
o	Received Energy Star certification in 2 locations (Burlington and Tacoma), tracking energy use in all locations through Energy Star
o	Contracting with a janitorial vendor that uses proprietary green cleaners and microfiber towels to reduce waste
o	Renovating and maintaining our office space through use of low VOC paints and carpets, purchasing products with recycled content, reusing materials and furniture where possible, recycling materials such as carpet
o	Conducting waste audits to assess the waste stream and identify opportunities to reduce waste and increase recycling
	Human Resources
o	Reducing our actual footprint through telework and mobile work arrangements An estimated 20% of Cambia employees now work remotely This initiative has reduced/eliminated commutes for these employees with a commensurate reduction in emissions (We have not measured the reduced emissions or other environmental benefits of this shift to remote and mobile work) While we expect this effort to have decreased emissions, we recognized that there is some displacement of emissions to employees who are now lighting, heating, and cooling their homes during the day when they are working from home
o	Cambia has a strong commute reimbursement program that subsidizes public transit passes and carpooling
o	Cambia also has a strong bike commuter program that encourages employees to bike to work The bike commuter program provides support to all levels of riders such as beginning bike commuters through a bike buddy program, various bike-commuting workshops and a resource-rich Bike Commuters site on Spark, the company intranet Cambia participates in May Bike to Work Month and the Bike Commute Challenge in September

Company Name: Athene Life Insurance Company of New York
text: The companys 2020 Corporate Social Responsibility Report is available on the Athene website and, among other things, highlights the companys efforts to make positive changes for the environment

The purpose of the companys investment portfolio is to maintain adequate resources to satisfy policyholders claims while earning an appropriate return on its investment  The company invests primarily in a very diversified portfolio of fixed income assets, covering a wide array of industries, sectors, and technologies  The company does not feel that the impact of climate change is a relevant consideration when making investment decisions  That being said, the company will evaluate and make investments in companies that promote green technologies, but on an equal basis with any other investment, based on the overriding considerations such as credit quality, yield, duration and concentration risks

The company has not altered its investment strategy in response to these considerations  As mentioned above, the companys investment strategy is to maintain a well-diversified portfolio, primarily of fixed income securities, and to make investments based on factors such as credit quality, yield, duration, and concentration to any particular issuer or sector  Through this diversification, the company feels it has mitigated many risks, including the risk of climate change, for its stakeholders  As such, no alteration to investment strategy for climate change risk considerations is expected to be made

S) and is well-diversified geographically A direct linkage between climate change and excess health costs is difficult to establish  However, climate change could conceivably disrupt the Companys local operations due to climate related events (eg more frequent office closings)  However, this operational risk is mitigated by the Companys Business Continuity Plan and Emergency Management Plan

Guidance includes regulatory and market intelligence, operations planning such as building efficiency analysis, and communications with a continual focus on sustainability As action is needed following the review and assessment process, the CSR Council, which has cross representation from multiple functional areas (ie, Communications, Workplace Solutions, Real Estate, etc) devises strategies and implements initiatives to optimize Humanas position with respect to climate change issues from a regulatory, customer, shareholder and other stakeholder perspectives The level and depth of action depends on the materiality of the risk or opportunity
At an asset level, Humana's Workplace Solutions team has responsibility for assessing risks and opportunities In combination with Humana's sustainability leaders, a focused team of Humana individuals plus consultancy partners collectively identifies and implements strategies to reduce energy and water consumption The team meets on a bi-weekly basis to review activities such as facility energy and water efficiency project efforts, "green" building or sustainable site solution design and selection, and associate workplace habits such as PC power management or building energy management endeavors The team also reviews overarching progress against various key performance indicators (KPIs) set to measure activities and performance against specific goals such as energy and GHG emission reductions  The team is also responsible for educating, engaging, and empowering all Humana associates on energy management and climate change opportunities
The CSR Stewards utilize a GRI oriented materiality matrix to review impacts that includes financial, stakeholder, regulatory, reputational and citizenship concerns where issues are rated based on relative importance in these areas and associated actions are taken to manage risks / opportunities appropriately Risks and opportunities ranked with high relative priority are then assessed and managed by the appropriate functional team (ie, facilities and operations, corporate communications, etc) with responsibility for associated initiatives  Humana has historically reviewed activities based on financial value (ie, return on investment, net present value) and contribution towards specific reduction goals and targets for energy and GHG emissions reduction  In 2013, we will be evaluating the use of a Sustainability Return on Investment (SROI) methodology for determining focus and resource investment in pursuit of sustainable initiatives including energy efficiency and emissions reductions

Sentry has programs in place that assess, reduce, and mitigate its emissions in its operations Our plans include monitoring natural gas and electrical usage, reducing dependence on diesel fuel oil, and selecting fleet vehicles that have low emissions For the past 15 years, Sentry has monitored its use of natural gas at the facilities that it owns, and for the past 30 years it has monitored usage of electricity at those facilities For the past 8 years, Sentry has monitored usage of utilities at facilities that it leases Sentry has implemented changes that have resulted in a reduction of the amount of energy used at its facilities Sentry is a low quantity user of diesel fuel oil It is used at the headquarters in Wisconsin as a back-up for utilities when blackouts occur, which is typically once or twice per year Sentry does not use diesel fuel oil at its other facilities 

Sentry replaces its fleet vehicles on average every three years Prior to purchasing new vehicles Sentry reviews and compares fuel efficiency and carbon emissions as part of the vehicle selection process Eighty-three percent of Sentrys fleet is comprised of 4-cylinder vehicles and the fleet averages 27 mpg Sentry currently has four plug-in electric vehicles in service that qualify for Californias Clean Air Vehicle Decal program Sentry tracks fleet carbon emissions on a monthly basis

Under the Green Building Loss Settlement provision, NYSIR will pay up to an additional ten percent (10%) of the direct physical damage loss payment amount up to a maximum of $75,000 per loss to replace or restore damaged covered property with equipment and/or materials compliant with the most current LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design), Energy Star or Green Seal standard in effect on the date of the loss This additional limit of insurance can also be applied towards the cost of services from accredited green building professionals The Company also includes these pre-loss loss avoidance measures under its Excess Flood Endorsement:  Sandbags, Supplies, and Labor $1,000 per policy year for the costs incurred to protect insured buildings from a flood or imminent danger of flood, $1,000 per policy year for the reasonable expenses you incur to move covered property to a place other than the described location in order to protect it from flood or the imminent danger of flood

Company Name: Talcott Resolution Life and Annuity Insurance Company
text:
Talcott Resolutions life and annuity  business is primarily deferred and payout annuities, so the impact on our company of climate change is minimal   Therefore, while Talcott Resolution does not have a specific standalone policy that addresses climate risks, Talcott Resolution addresses climate risks as part of a comprehensive approach to its risk management and investment management processes 
As part of Talcott Resolutions Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) framework, emerging risks like climate change are tracked to understand how these risks can impact Talcott Resolutions capital and surplus  Annually, ERM compiles emerging risk data obtained through management discussion groups and industry survey reviews and leads risk committee discussions to prioritize the emerging risks that should be focused on over the coming year Talcott Resolution addresses climate risk to its investment portfolio as set forth in its response to question five below

Our usage-based product, Snapshot®, gives drivers a financial incentive to drive less and safer, as drivers can earn discounts based on their driving habits  
	Discounts are given to policyholders who have homes that meet high building code enforcement construction  Discounts can be given even for older homes that have met the Institute for Business and Home Safety guidelines for the fortified hurricane designation
	Progressive offers customers a Paperless Policy option in order to reduce the amount of policy-related paper documents they receive Having policy documents delivered electronically saves trees, expedites document delivery and reduces the chances of misplacing documents  As of December 31, 2017, there were over 9 million paperless policies

	Produce Public Service Announcements about how to file claims for local radio stations 
	Send e-mails to customers and agents with claims reporting information and safety tips  
	Use social media tools (ie, Facebook, Twitter, etc) to reach broader audiences with claims reporting information and safety tips  
	Provide payment leniency in some severe situations to customers who need it  
	Deploy catastrophe response teams to affected areas to assist with claims  
	Inform employees about how they can assist with relief efforts

The Groups main exposure is to wind and hail, both of which seem to be deviating from historical trends The Group does manage catastrophe risk with a strong reinsurance program, risk tolerance statements surrounding net impact due to catastrophe, and annual stress testing for catastrophe scenarios of multiple wind/hail events up to a 1000-year return period

Government agencies and legislative bodies:
Chubb maintains relationships with federal and state government agencies and legislative bodies through our federal External Affairs and our State Government Affairs operations, whose mission is to advance our legislative and regulatory voice in concert with the company's business priorities As a priority, we support legislative and regulatory measures that will foster a healthy, open and fair insurance marketplace, both pre- and post-natural disasters and other weather-related events We strive to accomplish this mission by working with members of Congress and state legislatures, by partnering with industry and trade associations on legislative strategies, and by interacting with our regulators 

We have participated in constructive dialogue with US House and Senate leaders and their staffs regarding public policy initiatives and legislative proposals relating to natural disaster insurance and the impact of these initiatives on Chubb, the insurance industry and the customers we serve

Industry Associations:
Through the American Insurance Association (AIA) and other insurance organizations, we take part in the industrys dialogue on climate exposures, natural catastrophes and the necessity of increased mitigation For example, through our participation in insurance trade associations, we support the strengthening of building codes to enhance construction survivability

Non Insurance Organizations:
Chubb participates in ongoing efforts to mitigate risks posed by climate change through memberships and engagement with national organizations and industry councils Our participation is one means to share and increase the intellectual capital we have developed For example:
	Chubb sponsored the fire tests for the storage of Lithium Ion batteries managed by National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) These batteries are the primary source of power for hybrid vehicles NFPA is working to address risks associated with new technologies like the battery
	Our Loss Control Services staff made a presentation on wildfires at the 2013 Extreme Weather Insurance Business Management Congress 
	We support Greentown Labs in Massachusetts, which provides the prototyping space and resources needed by entrepreneurs as they work to solve the world's biggest energy and environmental challenges
	We sponsor the Global CleanTech 100 recognition and fund risk identification research in that sector
	We participate in industry groups and panels that address challenges relating to climate change, including:
¿	The Advanced Research Projects Agency-Energy (ARPA-E) of the US Department of Energy, which advances high-potential, high-impact energy technologies
¿	The American Society of Safety Engineers
¿	US Green Building Council  A Chubb manager currently serves on the board of the New Jersey Green Building Council
¿	SmarterSaferorg, a coalition that includes environmental advocacy groups such as Ceres, Environmental Defense Fund, National Wildlife Federation and the Sierra Club, founded to promote and support disaster safety and preparedness measures that are consistent with sound environmental stewardship of our fragile coastal ecosystems

Agents and Brokers:
For our agents and brokers, we offer extensive training and education on issues concerning climate-related perils through a variety of engagements, including:
	Chubbs Loss Control University which includes training and educational resources on business continuity, disaster planning as well as fire prevention, detection and protection
	Lunch and Learn events
	Professional and Other Continuing Education
	CEO Roundtables

In 2013, our Clean Tech group presented 13 Continuing Education Classes and other non-credit events, as well as making presentations at the World Broker Network meeting in San Francisco and the Wells Fargo Global Broker Network Meeting in New York

Employees:
We recognize that being an environmentally responsible company is also a point of interest and pride for our employees We communicate our efforts to our employees through an internal social site The site launch included a video featuring our President of Personal Lines and Claims discussing the importance Corporate Responsibility at Chubb 

We encourage employee telecommuting and compressed work weeks, thus enabling employees to lower their carbon footprint Approximately 15% of our US based workforce currently teleworks more than 1 day per week In addition, approximately 3% of the US workforce is on a compressed workweek

In addition, some of our locations have cross-functional teams focused on reducing the offices energy usage, paper usage and/or other impacts

Shareholders and Other Stakeholders:
We communicate these efforts and the potential impact of climate change to many constituencies through our annual submission to CDP, on wwwchubbcom and in SEC filings such as our Annual Report on Form 10-K

Our focus is on analyzing weather data and models in detail to manage the risks posed by extreme weather events  We use hurricane and severe storm models to quantify weather risk and address it through underwriting, pricing and reinsurance decisions  

With respect to underwriting decisions, we have taken aggressive steps to limit our property exposure, including: expanding to other states and other product lines to improve diversification; reducing property exposure in coastal areas; shifting to percentage-based deductibles; and renewing coastal property without wind

To better prepare for inevitable natural catastrophes, Allstate recommends an improved system of catastrophe preparedness and protection that is financially sound and organized to efficiently utilize the resources and expertise of private and public entities, including those of local, state, and federal governments Currently, a significant gap exists between the available coverage and necessary protection for major natural catastrophes because of the limited capacity of the private insurance and reinsurance sectors and the financial burden caused by these catastrophes

A national backstop for state catastrophe funds that is fully funded by a portion of private insurance premiums would increase the private insurance market's ability to respond to large-scale natural catastrophes The plan we support would not eliminate private reinsurance, which allows insurance companies to spread the risk of catastrophic losses and which is essential to the private insurance market Private reinsurers will continue to play an integral role in the insurance market, and private reinsurers will be encouraged to participate in providing capacity to the national backstop This plan would spread risk even more and provide a guaranteed source of reinsurance protection after major events or a series of events that could destabilize the market or even threaten a private market collapse
 
The plan we support will provide additional, needed capacity to the market, above and beyond what the private reinsurance market provides It will not eliminate private reinsurance; it will supplement it

Allstate specifically supports the Homeowners and Taxpayers Protection Act of 2013 (HR noi) because it includes the features of the plan we have discussed in these comments This legislation was drafted with input from experts in catastrophe management and actuarial science and improves upon similar legislation introduced in the past The sooner this legislation becomes law, the sooner and the better we can prepare and protect America from future natural catastrophes

Allstate also engages consumers and customers on the topic of disaster preparedness through vehicles like the Allstate Slog (http://blogallstatecom/), allstatecom (http://wwwallstatecom/tools-and-resources/be-aware-and-prepareaspx), and the distribution of disaster preparation and awareness brochures to customers by agency owners

Allstate is a member of and actively supports ProtectingAmericaorg ProtectingAmericaorg is a national coalition of more than 300 organizations representing emergency management experts, first responders, disaster relief agencies, non-profits, businesses, and insurers that believes that a comprehensive solution is needed to better prepare and protect America from future catastrophes

Allstate publicly discloses all identified climate related risks through the CDP annually

Company Name: Palisades Property and Casualty Insurance Company
text: The Company has named storm and hurricane deductibles in place in coastal areas to encourage customers to take measures to protect their properties  The Company sends information to customers about the risks posed by weather events, and the property mitigation measures that they could take to reduce these risks We send similar information in advance of threatening storms such as hurricanes, and use social media (website, blogs, etc) to publicize these messages to our customers and the public at large

Company Name: Clear Spring Property and Casualty Company
text: The Company analyzes risks associated with climate change and how that could impact underlying asset performance  The company does not have dedicated personnel to monitor as all investment team personnel consider correlated risks impacting asset management performance and underwriting process prior to investment approval

Please note that the Companies have approximately 20% of their total writings in Property and the remaining 80% of their total writings are for lines other than property; thus the business focus is on liability lines of insurance Additionally the Companies write almost entirely commercial lines risks rather than personal lines risks 

Perils considered when assessing the potential risks posed by climate change include:
	Hurricane and tropical storm
	Tornado
	Flood
	Drought
	Wildfire

Hurricane
North Atlantic hurricanes and tropical storms typically impact states between Texas and Maine  The Group identifies and models its hurricane risks in 23 states that could be affected by these perils, and on an annual basis has its exposures modeled in an alternative vendor model with a broader set of states

As noted in section 3, over the period from 1880 onwards there is a slight downward trend in the number of landfalling hurricanes  Some of the weather and climate conditions that make it easier for hurricanes to form in the Atlantic Basin also appear to impair the likelihood of landfall  For example, hurricanes that form further from land are less likely to maintain their structure long enough to make landfall as damaging events  In the long term the current consensus view is that there will be fewer hurricanes, but that these will be of greater intensity However the same science that provides this long term view also indicates it will be many decades before we see these changes

In a recent paper that discusses the short term (three to five years) impact of climate change on insured losses observes that climate change has had no measurable effect on the North Atlantic hurricanes that drive Cat Market losses Loss levels have gone up over time primarily due to increases in the value of building stock standing in the way of hurricanes These are the conclusions of the most recent report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change  [Climate Change and Hurricane Loss: Perspectives for Investors by Karen Clark and John Lummis June 2015]
The IPCC note in their  CLIMATE CHANGE 2013 : The Physical Science Basis: Frequently Asked Questions that Over periods of a century or more, evidence suggests slight decreases in the frequency of tropical cyclones making landfall in the North Atlantic and the South Pacific, once uncertainties in observing methods have been considered 

The Group closely monitors the forecast numbers of tropical storms and hurricanes for each season, investigates all available vendor models, and tests alternative assumptions on the potential frequency and severity of such events

Each individual property location is assessed for catastrophe risk, with particular focus on those nearest the coast and / or near river estuaries

Tornado
As noted in section 3, over the period from 1950 onwards the number of tornadoes is not increasing  In older calendar years there was significant under-reporting of the weakest category of tornado (EF-0); if one considers all other tornado strengths there is no trend in the frequency of these events or in the number falling into each strength category EF-1 to EF-5

When tornado insured losses are normalized for changes in exposures (for example, the number and values of the buildings and contents, often in areas that were previously agricultural land), these too show no increasing trend

The Group models tornado losses in every state within the USA, and has also revalued the tornadoes reported by the ISO Property Claims Service (PCS) from 1950 onwards to allow for changes in exposure as an additional data source  

Flood
As noted in section 3, flood losses arising from river and surface water are decreasing as a percentage of GDP  
The majority of the property policies issued by the Group exclude losses covered by flood  In those policies that do cover flood, many have flood sublimits

Drought & Wildfire
Drought and wildfire are strongly connected  One study looking at data through to 2002 indicated that fully half the variability in wildfire (measured by acres burned) arises as a result of drought conditions
(Fire and Drought, The Thoreau Institute, December 31, 2006) 

As noted in section 3, the current period of drought is not as severe as periods seen in the past  Furthermore, there was a drought in the latter part of the 16th century that was far more severe than any subsequent drought in North America

The Group does not write the two business lines that would be most significantly impacted by drought (crop multi-peril) or by wildfire (homeowners)  Consequently our losses arising from such events are minimal
No computer modeling is done

Each decision with respect to underwriting or investments is made considering revenue relevant risk factors However, Old Republics enterprise risk management process is designed to identify, assess and manage any risks, including environmental concerns, if they potentially exceed Old Republics defined risk tolerance In light of materiality considerations, we do not believe that such a process is currently relevant to an assessment of Old Republics financial soundness

The Companys investment managers have not led the Companys investment committee or Senior Management team to believe that there are significant concentrations of climate change risk on securities in our current portfolio The Company does not heavily invest in heavy carbon emitting industries The Company does not believe there is a significant component of fixed income, equity or real estate securities which will be adversely impacted by climate change related catastrophes

AIR has examined the relationship between the annual landfall frequency and different climate signals, such as sea surface temperatures (SST) in the North Atlantic Many scientists believe that an increase in SST will lead to an increase in the frequency as well as intensity of landfalling hurricanes Estimates of the effect of SST on hurricane frequency can be obtained by comparing the number of landfalling hurricanes during years when SST has been warmer than average to the landfall frequency during the entire historical period since 1900 Considering the nature of Frontlines business and the location of the insured risk, the company finds this modeling useful in predicting the anticipated losses as well as estimating the amount of reinsurance it may need to acquire for an upcoming year These predictions are calculated on an annual basis
The broader company fiming, related to locations where are operations are critical, deals with climate change risks and assessments and that has been filed

The Company has a Corporate Enterprise Risk and Capital Committee made up of members of senior management that provides oversight of our enterprise-wide risk structure and the processes established to identify, measure, monitor, and manage significant risks, including credit, market, and operating risks  The Corporate Enterprise Risk and Capital Committee periodically reviews the Companys strategies and policies for managing these risks and reports to the Board The Boards role is regular oversight of the enterprise risk management process, including reviews of operational, financial, legal and regulatory, and strategic and competitive risks 

In consideration of climate change and other environmental and social risks and opportunities, in January 2011 the Company established an Office of Corporate Responsibility, led by a Senior Vice President who reports regularly to Executive Management Through the Office of Corporate Responsibility education, policy development, and enterprise-wide integration of sustainability practices and climate change risk/opportunity awareness have been deployed and are being further refined and expanded  Programming for sustainability education, including education related to climate change and its impacts, was provided during 2012 and the first half 2013 to members of the Facilities, Audit, Finance, Risk Management, Investments, Continuous Improvement, and Legal, Compliance, Product Development, Human Resources and Public Policy groups, as well as heads of all major Operations groups The efforts of the Office of Corporate Responsibility include coordination of information relating to the management of environmental risks to physical assets described below, and the integration at an enterprise level of processes for further evaluation of climate change risks and impacts on the business in general

Additionally, increases in energy and fuel costs may result in broader inflationary pressures from our suppliers 

We manage risks associated with energy and fuel costs through
(1) our emissions reduction projects and 
(2) our tracking and monitoring on progress toward energy reduction targets    Our Global Real Estate (GRE) team considers this potential risk to inform decision on making on investments in emissions reduction projects In 2014, we completed 13 emissions reduction projects, which include lighting retrofits and replacements of aging infrastructure   We also manage this risk towards our emphasis on fleet efficiency - Cigna's vehicle fleet exceeds the national average fuel efficiencythe majority of our vehicles are 4-cylinder with alternative fuel (E85) capabilities and hybrid engines, and are classified as partial zero emissions vehicles  To manage progress against our 2017 emissions reduction targets, we utilize a proprietary technology data management portal and Utility Insight; a tool to aggregate data for all the sustainability program efforts The Utility tool provides a detailed dashboard of energy cost, consumption and variance across our real estate portfolio  in addition to Energy Star ratings  These management methods, most notably our investments in emissions reduction projects, have not reduced the likelihood of this risk, but they have reduced this risks potential magnitude over the next five years

Risk: Tropical cyclones (hurricanes and typhoons)-- Increases in the frequency and severity of extreme weather events, such as hurricanes and typhoons, could impact our business services distribution capacities, and may cause damage to physical assets  Cigna is committed to excellence in helping our customers enhance and extend their lives and protect their financial security Such a commitment requires that we be prepared to provide our services and offer our products virtually without fail    Cigna's Customer Disaster Response also may need to make temporary policy changes, such as waiving various medical requirements, refilling prescriptions and expanding its help line, to proactively address customer service issues and provide personal assistance and support for all affected by a disaster     Additionally, Cignas Employee Assistance Program (EAP) may open its telephone lines to offer members of the impacted communities access to trained clinicians via the telephonic EAP services, regardless if callers have Cigna EAP or not The EAP may also offer immediate access to on-site Critical Incident Services (CISD) support for Cigna clients

Management methods for the risk of tropical cyclones (hurricanes and typhoons) include the following:  
(1) Cignas Business Continuity Planning and Data Center Recovery plans sets forth procedures for data recovery, continuation of business functions and the use of supporting technology to recover critical business operations in the event of hurricanes and other unexpected disruptions The plans are updated and documented annually Cignas data center recovery plans are tested routinely with end-user evaluations of the restored systems as part of the testing protocol 

(2) Cignas critical applications run in hardened sites protected by an emergency generator Weve also repatriated core elements of our recovery capability including infrastructure to recover the top prioritized business functions and related computer applications through data and server replication

(3) To support clients, we have an online Disaster Resource Center, which is updated to offer resources specific to an area and incident Paired with an intimate knowledge of the provider network, Our Employee Assistance Consultant team area trained to respond quickly in the event of hurricanes

(4) We also obtain insurance and make investments to protect our facilities from hurricane risk   These management methods have not reduced the likelihood of this risk, however; we believe that these methods have reduced this risks potential magnitude over the next 1-3 years

Risk: Reputation--Corporate reputation on performance related to environmental responsibility, particularly on issues related to climate change, is increasingly important to our corporate clients as evidenced by the frequent occurrence of sustainability questions on RFPs for potential corporate clients and RFIs from existing ones   Also, our reputation on performance related to climate change issues is becoming increasingly important to our employees, investors and other stakeholders We will continue to monitor their key concerns and areas of greatest interest through stakeholder materiality assessments 

Management Method: Management methods include the following:  
(1) Within our Strategic Sustainability Performance Plan, we make continued emission reductions investments to support this energy strategy and 2017 emissions reduction targets

(2) The advancement of our Cigna Connects corporate responsibility framework across our organization supports our Strategic Sustainability Performance Plan by aligning and communicating our Corporate Responsibility initiatives 

(3) We closely monitor and respond to corporate client (including RFPs and RFIs) and investor requests related to climate change and corporate responsibility 

(4) We also engage stakeholders and employees to enhance continuous improvement in the implementation of sustainability This includes gathering data and operational experience from programs and sites, disseminating internal scorecards that provide feedback on progress towards goals and completing mandatory and voluntary external reports In 2014, Cignas published its first Corporate Responsibility Report using the GRIs G4 guidelines  We believe that  if Cigna did not engage in these current management methods - both the likelihood and magnitude of this risk over the next 1-3 years would be higher However, we acknowledge the importance of continuously improving and responding to evolving stakeholder concerns and expectations to reduce the likelihood and potential magnitude of this risk over the next 4-10 years

Company Name: The Providence Mutual Fire Insurance Company
text: We monitor industry written publications regarding the impact of climate change  Additionally, our risk matrix includes a comprehensive Business Continuity Plan and Disaster Recovery Plan  Both plans ensure a thorough claims settlement service program  PMFIC also utilizes the AIR and RMS modeling tools to estimate the impact of potential large storms (including hurricane and severe convective storms) on our capital

Personal Lines

Communication and Education: 
We provide our Personal Lines customers with several informational tools to help them manage, prevent, and mitigate effects of weather-related events on their property On our website, for example, we have created a section Catastrophe Assistance with tips for before, during and after a flood, hurricane or windstorm, tornado, dust storm or wildfire We also have participated in public education programs to help homeowners mitigate their wildfire risk, including providing recommendations to use fire-resistive construction materials in wildfire-prone areas  

Products and Services:
	Wildfire Defense Services Chubb Wildfire Defense Services is available to customers in 14 Western states The program provides education and property risk assessments to customers and helps protect their homes both before and during a wildfire By saving structures exposed to wildfire, we not only eliminate the production of air and water pollutants, but also reduce the need to reproduce the building materials and the associated carbon emissions that would result 
	Green betterment coverage With this coverage, a client can choose the option to rebuild their home after a covered loss with environmentally friendly materials and energy efficient systems, in compliance with environmental rating programs like LEED for Homes, up to an additional 100% of the insured value of the home
	Chubb offers premium credits in many states to homeowners who install mitigation devices or utilize storm resistant construction techniques These systems can mitigate losses from both the event itself and the aftermath A few examples include premium credits for the installation of:
¿	Explosive gas leak detectors
¿	Lightning protection systems
¿	Water leak detection systems
¿	Permanently installed generators
¿	Automatic seismic shut-off valves
¿	Masonry construction
¿	Hurricane durable roofs and 
¿	Impact resistant glass
	Chubb performs Infrared camera scans of clients homes and frequently identifies areas for improved energy efficiency, such as missing insulation or leaky window units These scans also prevent potential pipe freezes and other losses arising from severe weather events

Commercial Lines:

Products and Services:
	We have assembled a Clean Tech team to bring together expertise, products and services that support businesses innovating in such areas as smart grid technologies and resource optimization Chubb offers a full array of insurance products and services for these companies, including:
¿	General liability insurance
¿	Multinational solutions
¿	Workers compensation
¿	Builders risk, inland marine
¿	Ocean cargo
¿	Cybercrime and liability
¿	Property insurance
¿	Automobile liability insurance
¿	Excess umbrella
	Chubb Loss Control Services provides specialized assistance in business continuity and disaster planning as well as fire prevention, detection and protection
	At our Loss Control University fire lab in Warren, NJ, which is one of only eight certified Fire Protection Training Centers in the US, we provide property conservation training to our clients, brokers, building managers, schools and fire departments
	Chubbs Customarq Classic policy helps restore a green building to its original condition after a covered loss and insures covered property on a replacement cost basis, including green features such as vegetative roofs, ENERGY STAR® equipment, solar panels, translucent shades, geothermal system or any other item certified as green
unitedhealthgroupcom/who-we-are/sustainabilityhtml for perspective on our strategic areas of focus around Environment, Social and Governance topics, and our work with key stakeholders

Company Name: Standard Life And Accident Insurance Company
text: We consider several risks which relate to sectors and specific investments to estimate their impact on our expected returns on a risk-adjusted basis  For investment risk management, risks such as credit risk, market risk, liquidity risk, interest rate risk, sector risk, etc would include any impact of climate change to the extent it impacts these risks for any one investment or the economy as a whole  For example, an investment in a solar energy provider would have a greater element of imputed climate change consideration than an investment in a financial services company

Any attempt to measure the influence of climate change on mortality would be highly speculative and unlikely to be credible at this point  In light of this dynamic, the Company has not taken steps to "encourage policyholders to reduce the losses caused by climate change-influenced events"

Climate change risk currently ranks lower on the risk spectrum when compared to liquidity, durations, interest rate, and asset class

Furthermore from an investment portfolio standpoint we believe any risks or opportunities associated with climate change, such as carbon and water restrictions, are generally priced into the cost of the investment through the market; any potential arbitrage opportunities would have imbedded investment risk which we believe to be inappropriate for us to take given our overall risk tolerance profile

Given the nature of our underwritten liability we do not currently assess the correlation between climate risks our underwriting and investments Due to the relative short-tailed liability associated with the health underwriting risk profile we believe it is not as critical as it would be for a life company, or P&C company, to structure our portfolio with a similar duration
The company does not currently use computer modeling to manage climate change risk

Company Name: National Farmers Union Property and Casualty Company
text:
The Companys commitment includes public disclosure of direct emissions of greenhouse gases in accordance with a globally recognized standard 

In addition, the Company participates in the insurance sector's "ClimateWise" initiative within our European Operations and is involved in Australian industry initiatives regarding climate resilience with the Insurance Council of Australia

References to climate risk and risk mediation can be found in our ERM schedules, Investment Policy Statement and CAT modeling reports  We recognize that changes to climate are affecting much of our business including; the risks we insure, reinsurance costs, investment portfolio performance and business continuity planning
Our ERM strategy involves a broad assessment by four sub-committees focused on; underwriting, credit and investment market, operations, and strategic and marketing risks  These multi-disciplinary groups evaluate all potential exposures and assess probability and impact for each risk identified  When a risk is assessed to be a level 1, or highest risk, a risk tolerance statement and measurement is recommended to the Risk Management Committee  The Risk Management Committee, made up of senior leadership, finalizes any changes to the assessment and the Chief Risk Officer presents the full report to the board annually  Each quarter the board reviews a Risk Tolerance report monitoring the highest risks

While Homesite actively writes policies in all of the United States (with the vast majority of Homesites business in residential products) much of the Homesite book is concentrated in wildfire prone states and along the Atlantic coast  The perils of hail and tornado are an ever present concern especially as Homesites growth and as new home construction increases in highly exposed areas of the Midwest  

Homesite has business continuity plans in place to deal with weather-related catastrophes that may impact the various office locations  These plans are reviewed by Homesites Business Continuity Specialist on a regular basis  In addition, American Family considers the possibility of climate change risk to the organization in regard to the broader risk categories described in the response to Question 3 above

Company Name: Kaiser Foundation Health Plan Mid Atlantic
text:
KPs current and planned efforts to reduce its overall greenhouse gas emissions include energy conservation initiatives as well as large-scale investments in renewable energy sources and the purchase of carbon offsets For example, in the State of Washington, KP has a Power Purchase Agreement with Puget Sound Energy that, starting in 2021, supplies 100% of its yearly electricity needs from wind energy KP continuously conducts baseline and performance measurements for energy consumption and other sources of greenhouse gas emissions across its facilities and activities under its operational control These include clinical buildings where health care is delivered as well as non-clinical buildings (for activities such as administration and data storage) and fleet vehicle operations KP annually measures and reports its greenhouse gas emissions based on the General Reporting Protocol of The Climate Registry, a nonprofit collaboration among North American states, provinces, territories and Native Sovereign Nations that sets standards to calculate, verify and publicly report greenhouse gas emissions
KP publishes detailed summaries of its programs on its web site: wwwkporg/green

Although we do not have a formal risk management policy related to climate change, we have identified inherent risks associated with changes in laws and regulations that could result in increased energy costs; inherent risks associated with physical climate parameters, such as natural disasters, that may have a potential impact on our facilities and business operations; and inherent risks associated with other climate-related developments, such as increased health care costs, which may have a potential impact on our business operations
That said, it is not our business to tell policyholders what to insure, what risk to take/retain, or generally what to do
As stated in #2 above the impacts of severe weather losses are continuously evaluated through the ERM process, where catastrophe risk and investment risk are jointly modeled

Company Name: Unum life Insurance Company of America
text:
To summarize, they are:  
	Risks driven by changes in regulation
	Risks driven by changes in physical climate parameters
	Risks driven by changes in other climate-related developments

In our US operations, we have identified the following risks driven by changes in regulation:

Lack of regulation resulting in potential increased operational costs:  Future governmental emission programs either at the Federal, State or local level could impact our business Through trade organizations and other information sources, Unum keeps abreast of pending regulations that could impact our operations If a new regulation is implemented that impacts Unum, measures will be put into place to minimize the impact

1	Uncertainty surrounding new regulation resulting in potential increased capital costs:  As global transition to a low-carbon economy escalates, Unum will be required to comply with CC regulations as they are presented Compliance with regulations requires man-power and capital expenditure that would not have been required in absence of the regulation Unum Group owns four physical sites in four states, SC, ME, TN, and MA We operate these facilities utilizing green building best practices We are positioned to adopt new regulations when and if enacted Unum has a government relations department that stays abreast of federal and state issues relating to all topics, including climate change, and has positioned Unum to respond as regulations are being formulated and adopted

In our US operations, we have identified the following risks driven by physical climate parameters:
1	Change in mean (average) temperature resulting in potential increased operational costs:  This risk could cause an increased expense for utility consumption required for employee comfort in any of Unum's office buildings For example, in the Southeast, increases in temperatures caused by emissions will require additional cooling resulting in higher energy consumption to provide employee comfort while working Actions taken to address this potential risk include upgrade to our building systems to improve operational efficiency and lessen expenses

2	Other physical climate risk drivers which could potentially increase both capital and operational costs:  the CHA campus is subject to tornado and severe storm damage; and Portland and Worcester are subjected to winter weather Shifts in weather patterns has resulted in major weather events such as tornados and flooding that can result in major physical damage to infrastructure in any of our buildings For example, in 2011, our Chattanooga, TN campus narrowly escaped damage caused by one of the 27 tornadoes that touched down in the area The campus suffered minor damage from the storms but was not directly impacted

3	Uncertainty of physical risks which could potentially increase both capital and operational costs:  CC presents a plethora of weather-related risks as weather patterns become increasingly more severe and unpredictable These weather patterns present challenges as abnormal occurrences continue to materialize These uncertainties, including extremes in precipitation, droughts, increased snowfall and ice, rises in sea level, cyclones, etc are becoming more prevalent and require strategic planning, funding, and mitigation efforts

In our US operations, we have identified the following risks driven by other climate-related developments:
1	Reputation- which could potentially result in a reduced demand for our services:  Unum provides services to a large number of fortune 500 companies and receives inquiries from customers about our environmental programs and performance and also from State Commissioners Negative publicity may result in current and potential customers from conducting business with Unum
However, we do encourage our insurance producers and business partners to rely less on paper transactions

As part of this program, the property and casualty insurance companies use commercially available catastrophe models to model hurricanes, severe storms and earthquakes in order to estimate the possible impact of catastrophic events on their business The companies continue to work with their reinsurers and organizations such as IBHS in understanding climate change, its potential impact, and potential mitigation actions

Company Name: National union Fire Insurance company of Pittsburgh. Pa
text:
A potential result of this may be an increase of claims and/or probabilistic risk exposure 

Operational Risks
AIG currently operates within the US and in over 80 countries in the Americas, Europe, Asia Pacific, Middle East, and Africa The company has facilities and physical assets that could be vulnerable to the impacts of climate change The areas with the greatest potential for catastrophe losses likely are the major metropolitan centers along the eastern and Gulf coasts of the US, as well as the urbanized areas and coastlines of other countries in which AIG has property insurance exposures Within the US, hurricanes pose the greatest catastrophic weather-related risk for AIG  

Other Risks 
Risks driven by changes in other climate-related developments may include: reputational risk associated with the publics perception of AIGs carbon performance; and changes to consumer behavior based on changed preferences for products and services At this time, AIG believes that these risks will not have a substantive impact on revenues, expenditures or business operations, but the company recognizes that they may shape future considerations and strategies

As a global financial services provider with a relatively small environmental footprint, AIG is not an energy intensive business, nor does AIG consume large amounts of natural resources for the operation of business AIG does not consider climate change related regulatory risks to be material at this time Nevertheless, current cap and trade schemes and carbon taxes do affect AIG operating expenses in some geographies For example, in the UK AIG complies with the Carbon Reduction Commitment

AIG will continue to monitor regulatory developments, such as fuel/energy limits, carbon taxes, cap and trade schemes, emission reporting obligations, and heightened energy efficiency standards, and will assess the potential impacts of these developments on AIGs business
