During this process, the ERM team works with senior leaders across the organization to identify, assess, mitigate and monitor key risks As such, the potential impact of climate change is assessed by the defined business owner and includes an assessment of potential financial implications and an assessment of potential impact on MVPs ability to operate and/or meet its strategic objectives

USAA uses an extensive suite of catastrophe models purchased from well-known and well-respected vendors The Catastrophe Risk Management unit has dedicated computing resources and trained personnel to run these models internally Catastrophe model results are refreshed and evaluated monthly to track the impact of exposure changes on projected losses (Average Annual Loss, Tail Value-At-Risk, and Probable Maximum Loss) An extensive refresh of model parameters, assumptions and input data is performed annually to shape underwriting and pricing guidelines in catastrophe-prone areas In addition to internally-run vendor models, external  research is  also utilized to validate and inform underwriting, pricing and business decisions related to these risks

¿	Internal Models

USAA uses state-of-the-art modeling software to measure hurricane, wildfire, winterstorm and severe thunderstorm (including tornado) risk The selection of model parameters can produce a wide range of possible exceedance probability curves, so parameter estimation is calibrated with the purpose of any given model run For example,  USAA uses a subset of historical years with higher than average sea surface temperatures that can be used to parameterize the computer model as a proxy for estimating hurricanes under global warming conditions 

¿	External Models, Research and Validation
In addition to the models maintained internally, USAA works closely with its reinsurance brokers to validate model parameters and results  This allows us to improve quantification of the range of risks posed by natural catastrophes, including estimating future impact
USAA monitors scientific research on climate issues, including findings of the IPCC, the US Department of Defense, the National Climate Assessment of the US Global Research Program, the Actuaries Climate Index Research Project, and various actuarial and scientific journals This research shapes assessment of weather-related, regulatory and business operation risks, and informs model validation and parameterization
This assessment and research leads to more uncertainty in model results As a result of model uncertainty, USAA has set conservative capital requirements These conservative capital requirements drive our underwriting, pricing, and reinsurance-purchase decisions Growth in catastrophe-prone areas is managed in light of these risks, and USAA purchases enough reinsurance and holds enough capital to cover potential impacts of changing weather patterns USAA also realizes that it is insufficient to be prepared for only the types of catastrophes experienced in the past 100 years  Consequently, USAA performs annual stress tests to simulate the impact of extremely rare catastrophe losses on business operations, claims settlements, and overall financial strength USAA uses these stress tests to understand its strengths and weaknesses, so that we can adapt to new conditions and continue to provide excellent service and remain financially sound even if an unprecedented event happens
In light of the nature of our business, we have not taken such measures

The companys Enterprise Risk Management process is overseen by our Chief Risk Officer and includes participation by the senior leadership team and board reporting The management of the financial and legal risks related to climate change is very much a consideration in the companys underwriting practices, particularly in our property and casualty lines  The company considers the factors of climate risk to mitigate concentration exposures; supports our policyholders with education, safety, training and sustainability assistance; and provides immediate coverage and environmental cleanup for those impacted by adverse events

This question is not relevant to our business practice, operations or investment  The Company currently writes professional liability and incidental general liability insurance for health care providers and other professionals in the United States and some US territories  As stated in Question 2 , the risk of climate change-related impact on the lines of business we write is minimal at best  A potential impact would most likely occur in our investment portfolio  

However, given the long tail nature of our business, our investments tend to be less risky and more conservative  In the event climate change-related risks begin to impact any of our investment holdings, we are able to restructure our portfolio in order to minimize any financial impact those risks may have on our investment portfolio

We will monitor the effects of climate change as it pertains to the professional liability and incidental general liability market and evaluate any credible data that becomes available  Currently, we are not aware of any risks in any area where we provide coverage, both geographical and coverage wise

Climate change-influenced events and the losses caused by them are difficult to quantify in respect to this primary focus  Therefore MHP has not provided a focus on reducing the losses caused by climate change-influenced events

However, our  Enterprise-wide Risk Management framework takes into account various types of risks, including those that are weather-related, to evaluate their impact on our ability to conduct business, to serve our members, and to meet regulatory requirements 

HealthNow, as a health insurer, has determined the effect of climate changes to be immaterial for our current portfolio of investments

Company Name: National Union Fire Insurance Company of Pittsburgh, Pa.
text:
For example, a green property endorsement in the US and the UK provides an environmentally friendly property reinstatement in the event of a covered loss, in a manner required to minimize the potential harm to the environment

AIG provides a range of products and services across all lines of insurance, helping clients respond to the greening of the economy, expanding natural disaster resilience, reducing greenhouse gas emissions and being proactive against the threat of climate change AIG has taken steps to provide insurance products and solutions that help reduce potential losses that may be caused by climate-change influenced events, including the following initiatives

There may be an opportunity for AIG to build its reputation for its sustainability efforts among consumers, employees, shareholders and other key stakeholders who are increasingly interested in the environment and the impacts of climate change This enhanced reputational regard may lead to an increased demand for AIG products and services

In 2012, AIG PC saw continued interest in existing green products in residential and commercial property insurance that enable customers to rebuild to a higher standard of sustainability in the event of a covered loss, specifically:

1)	Ecosurance® is the portfolio of green products provided by Lexington Insurance Company, AIGs Boston-based surplus lines insurance unit:
	Upgrade to Green® Residential, first launched in 2007, provides coverage for certain products and materials identified as having ENERGY STAR® or equivalent levels of energy efficiency Repairs and replacements include, but are not limited to, lighting systems, heating/cooling equipment, windows, insulation, appliances, home electronics, indoor plumbing, and flooring materials
	Upgrade to Green Commercial responds to covered partial and total losses for both Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED®) certified and non LEED certified buildings In the event of a total loss, LEED certified insureds are provided coverage to upgrade their building to the next level of LEED certification upon reconstruction Non-LEED certified insureds can use the coverage to rebuild to a LEED silver standard
	LexElite Eco-Homeowner® responds to the unique risks faced by homeowners who generate their own power and feed surplus energy back into the local power grid If a homeowners alternative-energy system has a covered outage, LexElite Eco-Homeowner will protect the homeowner against lost income generated from selling surplus energy back to the grid and will cover the extra expenses incurred to purchase replacement electricity
	In August 2009, Lexington launched Upgrade to Green Builders Risk, which provides coverage that supports green building construction and renovation projects registered with the US-based LEED or the GREEN GLOBES® rating systems Available as an endorsement to Lexingtons Completed Value Builders Risk Policy, it extends coverage to address the risks green buildings face during three key areas of construction: project management and administration, site ecological impacts, and consumption of resources

2)	The Private Client Group (PCG) division of AIG PC provides insurance products and loss prevention expertise to high net worth individuals and families Since 2008, this division has introduced several products to encourage property development of high environmental efficiency, including: 
	For US based clients, PCG offers Green Rebuilding Cost, which allows policyholders to rebuild with materials that are more energy efficient, conserve water and other natural resources, and provide a healthier environment inside the home 
	For UK-based clients, PCG offers a Green Rebuilding Cost Coverage as part of its standard Home & Contents policy for high-net worth individuals This covers the installation of green building products that will use less energy, water and/or natural resources, create less waste and provide a healthier environment for residents

3)	Lexington also offers a suite of three insurance solutions for businesses in the developing climate change and greenhouse gas emissions sector:
	Newest to the suite, as of September 2012, is CarbonCover ODS, designed for project developers who are collecting tangible physical assets for the purpose of creating emission reductions and carbon offset credits CarbonCover ODS responds to direct physical loss or damage of a physical asset that is being collected to create carbon offset credits These assets can include ozone depleting substances (ODS) that are removed from refrigeration systems or methane gas that is extracted from landfills or underground mines Direct physical loss or damage to the asset is measured as the value of the carbon offset credits that would have been issued for the destroyed asset absent the loss, in accordance with a carbon registrys project protocol
	CarbonCoverSM Registry, launched in January 2010, which provides professional liability insurance for registries that track, confirm, and verify carbon offset credits; and
	CarbonCover Design & Confirm, extends Lexingtons architects and engineers professional liability coverage to expressly cover claims arising from greenhouse gas consulting services or emission reduction verification services

4)	In an effort to encourage customers to reduce carbon emissions from vehicle travel and support their efforts toward environmental responsibility, AIG PC introduced the Auto Physical Damage Alternative Fuel Incentive Endorsement in 2010 Available with commercial automobile liability policies, this enhanced coverage allows customers to waive or be reimbursed for their auto physical damage deductible, up to a maximum of $1,000, if a covered gasoline powered vehicle is deemed a total loss and is replaced with a green automobile This endorsement builds on two products launched by The Private Client Group division of AIG PC in 2008: New Vehicle Replacement Coverage and the 5% Hybrid Vehicle Discount Under the former, if a new vehicle is totaled within three years of its purchase, the client can opt to receive the agreed value, replace it with a vehicle of the same year, make and model, or receive a new vehicle of the same make and like model, including hybrids or alternate fuel editions The latter applies a discount to bodily injury liability, property damage liability, medical payments, uninsured motorist, collision and comprehensive coverages for owners of hybrid and alternative fuel vehicles
The company does not consider there to be any current risks driven by changes in climate-related developments which would present a significant impact to the company

The company continues to increase awareness of environmental issues among its employees as it seeks to recycle, conserve energy and be good stewards of resources  Please see the response to Survey Question 1 for related information

To expand its reach and methods of communication State Auto utilizes social media as an educational and awareness tool to inform and engage agents, policyholders and others on topics related to climate change The company delivers content related to disaster preparedness and how to make contact with agents or the company during times of disaster through our social networks, including Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn and YouTube  We make the content available to agents to enable them to use such information on their social networks, further expanding this educational and awareness reach beyond State Autos own immediate policyholder base  Such topics appear on the companys electronic agency network and include such subjects as wildfires, national preparedness, hurricane, hail damage, and winter weather

In the public filings for its majority owned public downstream subsidiary, State Auto Financial Corporation, it includes for the benefit of the shareholders various risk factors the company faces, including those related to climate change, catastrophe losses and geographic concentrations, among other factors

The Companys emissions mitigation and reduction plans are focused primarily on the operation of the physical building  For example: 

	A comprehensive recycling program is in place 
	Through the replacement of lighting fixtures and bulbs, electrical consumption and the number of bulbs have been reduced significantly
	Changes have been made to the building HVAC system to improve operating efficiency  
	Replaced existing carpet and all old carpet was recycled and not placed into any landfill
	Water restrictors exist on all water tabs as a water conservation endeavor 
	Existing traditional electric based hot water heaters tanks are being replaced with on-demand hot water heaters as the existing units fail 
	The company maintains a cross-functional team consisting of members of the Information Technology and Administrative Services/Facilities divisions This team, in addition to other goals, focuses on the reduction/appropriate use of electricity within our Data Center 
	The Company replaced the roof on its home office facility in 2015 utilizing cool roof technology

Furthermore, when considering purchases or supplies or utilization of vendors, the Company considers mitigation/reduction of emissions as an important component in the decision-making process
To the extent that the Company invests in Real estate securities, care is taken to avoid any concentrations in high risk geographical areas

We do not manufacture any tangible products The company operations are limited to one home office in Maryland and small agency office locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio, South Carolina, and West Virginia

Company Name: American Health and Life Insurance Company
text: Since the company provides primarily credit insurance products in a widely dispersed geographical area, the risks are not significant

is headquartered in downtown Buffalo, New York The site is the largest LEED® certified building in Western New York and the $110 million project incorporated one of the most extensive brownfield remediations in New York State LEED (Leadership  in Energy and Environmental Design) has certified the HealthNow building as a green building with silver status, meeting criteria related to conservation of natural resources, green power, non-smoking habitat, and landscape design LEED® uses green to refer to the planning, design, construction, and operations of buildings with several central, foremost considerations: energy use, water use, indoor environmental quality, material section and the building's effects on its site
HealthNow encourages and incents employees to be environmentally conscious through document recycling, portable laptops to decrease printing necessity, and preferred parking for Hybrid vehicles

The company utilizes catastrophe models to determine the extent of, plan for and measure weather related events  Consideration is gen to climate change to the extent that it is considered by the third party models that Bankers uses to review warm sea-surface temperature or near-term views in these models to provide correlation to historical trends

Bankers considers modeled and historic loss trends to determine reinsurance structure and attachment/limit, and incorporates these factors into our risk management strategies  They are also used to determine levels of reinsurance and capital requirements to mete claims needs, pricing adequacy for catastrophic costs and to set guidelines to mitigate catastrophe exposures

Most catastrophe models today are approved by regulators and are generally developed using the latest weather and climate data and science, tested by metrological, engineering, computer science and actuarial experts  The models often create alterations that account for perils where they believe future losses may deviate substantially from historical trends, specifically for Hurricanes  In these cases, Bankers considers the potential impact on the catastrophe loss distributions shown by these models

Furthermore, Bankers also takes into consideration different assumptions of Hurricane frequency and severity to match both the historic and the potential future hazard trends to test the impact of climate change on loss distribution  In addition to assumption sets created by model vendors, Bankers models scenarios of past severe events to determine the impact of prior storms on the current portfolio  Finally, Bankers considers deterministic scenarios to identify the potential impact of a worst-case scenario across its portfolio  The results of these stress tests are evaluated when deciding the best risk management strategy for the company, reinsurance purchases and growth plans and projections

Property insurance is an annual product, therefore, pricing underwriting and reinsurance and risk management strategies must evolve over the course of the year to match the changing market and climate environment As such, Bankers considers our view of risk as informed by the catastrophe models, to represent the most up-to-date view of the current environment for catastrophe events that may impact the portfolio  Consequently, the effects of climate change are accounted for on an ongoing basis, as the potential effect become known
Information on the effect of climate change on population health is currently limited
At this time, the Company does not see this risk as material  RLI will continue to assess as new information becomes available

Bankers offers rate discounts based on wind mitigation in many of its products, including homeowners and commercial residential lines  These discounts are based on the presence of wind mitigation features and construction features that reduce the severity of loss and include, but are not limited to, age of roof, roof shape, roof covering, shutters and others  Adherence to the building bode by sate is also reflected in the wind mitigation credits or in the rating algorithm for states that do not have wind mitigation discounts

We provide any discount or underwriting initiatives that educate insureds through communications either directly to the policyholders or through our agents

The Company relies on the investment managers to comply with an investment policy that maintains the appropriate returns and stability to meet the expectation of regulators, policyholders and governing boards The Company does not currently approach climate change as an Enterprise Risk Management issue

The organization has a well-developed Enterprise Risk Management program {ERM) that identifies the "risk level" and "possible monetary loss level assuming occurrence" for the group's Insolvency Risk, Market Risk, Underwriting Risk, Operational Risk, and Internal Control/Financial Reporting Risk Specific parameters and guidelines have been established to mitigate these risks and other associated risks within each of these areas Management is also responsible for addressing the correlation of risk in totality associated with these different risk areas The company does not consider there to be any current risks driven by changes in climate-related developments which would present a significant impact to the company

Forward-looking statements include statements regarding our understanding of general economic, financial and insurance market conditions and expected developments Undue reliance should not be placed on such statements because, by their nature, they are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties and can be affected by other factors that could cause actual results and plans and objectives of Zurich American Insurance Company, a New York domestic insurance company, and its pooled companies (collectively, the Company) to differ materially from those expressed or implied in the forward looking statements (or from past results) Factors such as (i) general economic conditions and competitive factors, particularly in our key markets; (ii) the risk of the global economic downturn and a downturn in the financial services industries in particular; (iii) performance of financial markets; (iv) levels of interest rates and currency exchange rates; (v) frequency, severity and development of insured claims events; (vi) mortality and morbidity experience; (vii) policy renewal and lapse rates; and (viii) changes in laws and regulations and in the policies of regulators may have a direct bearing on the results of operations of the Company  The Company undertakes no obligation to update or revise any of these forward-looking statements, whether to reflect new information, future events or circumstances or otherwise

In January 2013, Zurich Insurance Group Ltd (Zurich) formed the  Group Environmental Performance team This team is dedicated to support the business in reducing the negative impact its operations have on the environment They are responsible for managing a comprehensive set of activities to accurately measure, track, and improve Zurichs environmental footprint, helping internal stakeholders understand where and how they can operate in a more sustainable and efficient manner The four focus areas of the Group Environmental Performance Framework are: 

	Standards and Governance: continuous improvement of the Group-wide environmental management system (based on ISO 14001) 
	Environmental Reporting (measuring impact): achieving further improvements in the quality of data reported, and ensuring alignment to evolving external reporting standards and best practice
	Strategy and Projects (mitigating impact): develop new opportunities to achieve efficiency gains across operational and business processes
	Communications, Change and Relationship Management: continue to expand environmental networks across the business and broaden the use of business social tools for more effective information sharing and awareness building to achieve impact


In 2008, Zurich set its first global environmental target to reduce carbon emissions per employee by 10 percent by 2013 as compared to a 2007 baseline Zurich exceeded the original carbon reduction target in 2012 Following, Zurich set new environmental targets including a 50 percent reduction in carbon per employee and 40 percent reduction in energy per employee, by 2020 compared to a 2007 baseline In 2016, Zurich exceeded these targets achieving a 53 percent reduction in carbon per employee and 43 percent reduction in energy per employee In 2017 Zurich committed to further long-term environmental targets to be achieved by 2025 against a 2015 baseline  Those targets include Zurich achieving and maintaining a 20% reduction in total carbon emissions per employee, broken down by facilities and business travel emissions, as well as a 20% reduction in energy per employee 

See June 29, 2017 news release: https://wwwzurichcom/en/media/news-releases/2017/2017-0629-01

Additionally, Zurich has been carbon neutral since 2014, investing in the Rimba Raya Biodiversity Reserve, a REDD+ verified project

Zurich has achieved these substantial improvements in environmental performance through the following key programs:
	Purchasing renewable electricity wherever economically and operationally feasible
	Sustainable buildings  Addressing the full building life-cycle, Zurich considers sustainability starting at the selection of our buildings, through construction and office fit-out projects, and during day-to-day operations
	Efficient travel practices  only traveling when necessary and using video and teleconference wherever possible instead Zurich encourages the transition to a more sustainable car fleet

In 2014, Zurich started sourcing 100 percent renewable electricity at its North America headquarters in Schaumburg, IL They continued with this commitment at the newly constructed LEED Platinum headquarters which opened in the fall of 2016 As of 2016, Zurich North America sourced 63 percent renewable electricity out of its total electricity demand  Globally, 45 percent of Zurichs electricity comes from renewable sources

In addition to purchasing renewable electricity, the new LEED Platinum headquarters boasts a number of best practice examples in sustainable building including: a curtain wall system designed to maximize natural light; a system to provide high-quality indoor air; access to public transportation and accommodations for electric and low-emitting vehicles; incorporation of multiple green roofs, totaling more than one acre; landscape including 637 trees and more than 13 acres of native savannah plantings; walking paths and water features; rainwater harvest and re-use; recycling and reduction of waste during construction process and efforts to utilize locally-sourced building materials

In addition, Zurich has also implemented programs to remind employees to power down equipment when it is not in use  Many computer monitors and desktop computers are automatically set to go into a sleep or hibernation mode after a short period of inactivity

Zurich continues to work on reducing its impact from paper and printing Copier/printer machines in many of our locations are set for duplex (two-sided) printing and the print/copy default has been set to black and white vs color  Zurich has implemented a Managed Document Service (MDS) optimization program, reducing the total number of multi-functional devices (MFDs) ), and replacing the remaining fleet with more energy efficient equipment This program was put into place not only to reduce energy consumption and the impact on the environment, but to also deliver significant operational cost savings We have completed the third and final year of this program, reducing the number of MDFs within our North America office buildings from 438 to 348 machines (20% reduction) Find more information about Zurichs Environmental Performance:

https://wwwzurichcom/en/corporate-responsibility/climate-change/minimizing-our-environmental-footprint

	Aviva USA Community Shred Day (annual):
o	Aviva USA, the US division of the first global insurance company to become carbon neutral, is deeply committed to doing our part to protect our environment  To demonstrate this commitment to a targeted central-Iowa audience, we recognized 2011- 2013 Earth Days with a Community Shred Day During these events, Aviva invited residents to join in earth-friendly activities by dropping off their personal and confidential documents at the companys new West Des Moines headquarters building, where the documents were secured and destroyed by a third-party vendor This
event not only show cased Aviva as an environmentally conscious company, but it also created a market-exclusive opportunity to position the company as a local financial services leader
o	Primary target audiences for this event Aviva sought to gain awareness of its dual commitment to the environment and information security by providing a public service to consumers; share the message through central Iowa news media; and generate goodwill and awareness among our vendors, and business, regulatory and elected leaders  Our secondary target audience was Aviva employees and the agents which market our life insurance and annuity products 
o	Goals for our Community Shred Day(s) included:
¿	Partner with credible third parties who would effectively reinforce, support and extend Avivas commitment to environmental and corporate responsibility 
¿	Generate community, employee and customer goodwill by offering this complimentary community service, to be measured by the number of individuals bringing documents to the event
¿	Showcase Avivas commitment to earth-friendly practices at our LEED gold-certified campus by attracting media attention and getting consumers to visit the new headquarters building
¿	Help residents protect their identities by destroying unneeded documents containing personal information
¿	Provide some landfill relief through the recycling of an exceptionally large quantity of paper 
¿	Encourage all Aviva USA employees to participate in Earth Day activities in their local communities

As a long-term investor focused on managing assets to liabilities, we believe that investors taking both financial and non-financial considerations into account when making investment decisions will be the most successful in the long term  Issues such as corporate governance, climate change, use of natural resources, health and safety, labor relations, and human rights can be important drivers of investment risk and reward

We believe that a pro-active integration of relevant Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) factors into the investment process alongside traditional financial metrics and state-of-the-art risk management practices could support our investment result  However, integration of such factors requires diligence, expertise and focus  We do not believe that simply dedicating specific investment portfolios to the latest climate branded product of the asset management industry creates sustainable value for our stakeholders and the environment

Our investments are primarily managed by third-party asset managers, and it is at this level that individual security selection decisions are made  These asset managers operate within agreed portfolio guidelines set by Farmers and take all aspects into account, both financial and non-financial, when managing Farmers individual portfolios to ensure maximum value creation

As our core competency is selecting the right asset managers and evaluating them based on their superior investment processes, we have taken the following actions:

1)  For the procurement of new asset managers, we include questions related to the inclusion of ESG factors in the investment process into our request for proposal (RFP)
2)  We have implemented the capability to monitor ESG ratings provided by MSCI in our risk systems  This allows us to enter into a proactive dialogue with our asset managers about risk exposures to environmental factors
We do not use computer modeling to measure the climate change risk

	Weather alerts to insureds cell phones and email addresses relating to their respective geographic region and geographic regions of interest

	Loss control consultation with commercial accounts may address hurricane preparedness and contingency planning
	One of the Companys key business partners is Hartford Steam Boiler (HSB)  Specifically, with respect to this partnership, the following is offered to the Companys policyholders: 

o	HSB provides the Company with specialized coverages and services as part of its package policies that incentivize policyholders to purchase energy efficient technology and conserve energy which can help reduce carbon emissions, one of the factors which experts say is contributing to climate change 
o	The equipment breakdown insurance program that HSB designed for the company includes coverages designed to encourage commercial properties to replace damaged equipment and systems with energy efficient equipment 
o	Environmental, Safety and Efficiency coverage pays commercial policyholders up to 125 percent of the loss payable for upgrades to more energy efficient, safer or environmentally friendly equipment     
o	In addition, as part of HSBs optimize energy efficiency program, the Companys policyholders have access to services that can help them understand how they currently use energy and what steps they can take to improve energy efficiency and reduce their energy use 
o	HSBs energy optimization program also includes providing the Companys commercial policyholders with on-site energy efficiency observations that our inspectors make when conducting a boiler or pressure vessel inspection 
o	The Companys commercial policyholders also have access to a range of equipment efficiency calculators created by HSB and available on its website for the Companys small to mid-sized commercial clients that cover a wide range of equipment types and sizes including: lighting systems, HVAC, electrical and mechanical equipment, motors, vampire electrical loads as well as boilers 
o	HSB's equipment efficiency calculators can help the Companys customers objectively analyze important economic and environmental options, make informed recommendations and decisions, and create concrete plans to improve energy efficiency

Anticipated underwriting risks include potential D&O and general liability exposure for which we monitor litigation and litigation trends

Variance in rainfall can produce two scenarios: While extreme rainfall events have the potential to produce flooding in areas where the infrastructure cannot handle inundation, persistent drought in areas such as the Western United States has increased the risk of wildfires, as well as the potential of reducing the availability of water needed to fight fires

Regarding flooding, Chubb considers flood zones, building codes and numerous other environmental factors when evaluating whether to insure a risk  

Rising sea levels could increase losses by magnifying the impact of storm surges in coastal regions, especially heavily populated regions such as the East Coast of the United States  

We are at risk from hurricanes and cyclones along the coastlines of North America, wildfires in the Western US, and rising sea levels along the East Coast 

We utilize a number of strategies to mitigate our risk exposure, such as: carefully evaluating terms and conditions of our policies; incorporating updated information on loss trends in our pricing; managing our underwriting appetite; aggregating risk; and purchasing reinsurance  

We use a risk concentration management tool to monitor/control accumulations of potential losses in geographic areas exposed to weather-related risks and changing weather patterns 

There are other potential impacts beyond underwriting risk:
	Operations  Severe storms can cause flooding and/or building damage which may necessitate office closures We anticipate and mitigate the risk through updated business continuity plans and appropriate technology to enable remote working
	Investments - Water shortages and areas prone to catastrophe related weather events may impact the investment attractiveness of certain geographies or sectors
	Regulatory  Regulatory changes in response to climate change could impact customer demand for our products and/or their ability to implement our loss mitigation recommendations

Humana is committed to integrating green building principles into our existing and new portfolio of facilities with a focus on energy and water efficiency Humana advanced this objective through the integration of climate and sustainability factors such as energy efficiency projects at our facilities, access to transportation, Energy Star or LEED guidelines, employee engagement (ie, behavioral change) and other parameters, into the decision criteria used to improve our facility portfolio and select future Humana locations Opportunities for improving the portfolio and achieving energy and GHG reduction goals are identified by the Enterprise Associate and Business Solutions team in collaboration with our external consulting partners  Initiatives may be evaluated and presented to the senior management for support and funding including capital investment, employee involvement (ie, resource support) or other requirements  

Our short-term strategy is informed by our environmental goals, influencing our team to focus on energy efficient operations within our owned and leased facilities, spurring direct investment in both financial and personnel resources These investments have enabled Humana to implement initiatives to achieve our targets such as an ongoing portfolio-wide LED lighting retrofit, which will result in over $1,162,295 in annual energy savings, as well as continued alignment with our previously developed comprehensive set of design standards for office and clinical operations to ensure consistency, energy efficiency, and sustainable practices across new builds and renovations In 2020, we invested more than $300 thousand in building efficiency improvements, optimized our building occupancy rate, and implemented new energy-efficient processes and recycling standards Additional focus on infrastructure projects such as consistent BMS systems in our owned sites will create energy efficiencies We are also exploring renewable energy options to determine opportunity and feasibility toward setting a science-based target Finally, ongoing workspace optimization efforts increase workspace density while also decreasing building vacancies, thereby reducing our physical footprint and alleviating commute burden to reduce energy usage and emissions

On the whole, energy use reduction and greenhouse gas emissions reduction efforts not only drive progress toward our sustainability goals, but also illustrate to our employees and customers our commitment to reduce GHG emissions and operate as efficiently as possible Employee engagement efforts include a continuing focus on increasing work from home with the understanding that this strategy will have a significant impact on Scope 3 emissions, while providing our workforce greater flexibility and reducing operational demands of our facilities

Our long-term strategy is impacted by potential consequences of climate change such as regulation, natural resource scarcity, facility operational costs and human health impacts Our Enterprise Associate and Business Solutions leaders review short- and long-term trends and impacts associated with sustainability and refine our business strategy accordingly For example, Humana's portfolio includes both owned and leased assets where many facility investments are on a long-term basis (up to 10 years) Our sustainable real estate approach ensures these investments take into consideration the long-term impacts of building characteristics on climate change and overall environmental impact, employee wellness, and operational costs

YES The company has considered the impact of climate change on its investment portfolio  For example, new climate change regulations have the potential for a materially negative impact on an issuing corporations operations, financial performance and risk characteristics  Certain industries are more prone to risk regarding climate change including utilities, chemicals and other processing industries that could impact air and other resource quality  Agricultural production and related sectors such and fertilizer companies are susceptible to climate change and water availability  We have considered climate change risks for all asset classes  A large majority of the companys investments are in fixed income while other classes such as real estate and equities are not material  The company does not use a formal shadow carbon price when considering investments, however, industry trends and regulations are closely monitored  
b	YES In response to the potential for major catastrophe losses, the company has not purchased investments such as Florida Windstorm bonds, Oil Casualty bonds, etc  The company continuously monitors conditions in all sectors that are, or could be, impacted by future climate developments  Underwriting for industries such as coal generation electric utilities has materially changed in the recent past  A significant amount of extra time is now required for these types of underwritings in order to fully analyze the impact on an investment resulting from compliance with existing and potential new climate rules, regulations and laws

However, our insurance carrier does provide quantification of risks related to weather perils such as flood, power disruption, utilities, and fire protection

Geisingers property carrier utilizes software based natural catastrophe modeling run annually and provides a portfolio wide, regional, or peril specific overview of Geisingers exposure to natural catastrophe risks Once natural catastrophe risks are identified as potentially impacting Geisinger, engineering resources and loss control improvement efforts can be focused to manage and address specific locations or exposures

Therefore, any regulations addressing climate change are not likely to directly impact the Companys products or services  Rather, the Company may be indirectly exposed to regulatory risk as it relates to climate change if regulations impact certain sectors in which the Company holds investments  (See response to question 2)  Although the Company does not believe that climate change currently poses, or is anticipated to pose in the foreseeable future, any material risks to the Company, a significant increase in average mortality and morbidity rates in any geographical area could potentially result in an increase in loss ratios for the Company  These risks would be identified and monitored as part of the Companys existing enterprise risk management process

RGA expects that climate change risks could potentially touch upon all aspects of its risk taxonomy  As a life and health reinsurer, any climate-related impacts on mortality and morbidity would affect RGAs business  This would include both direct impacts such as additional deaths from natural disasters or wider disease prevalence but also indirect impacts from items such as reduced food production, macroeconomic environments, and migration  As noted in question #5, we expect that there will be both direct and indirect impacts on our investments as well  The macroeconomic environment will affect the environment in which RGA generates capital  Operational risk could be impacted both in terms of offices in high risk areas (for example, RGA has an office in Dubai, an area which could be severely impacted by rising temperatures) as well as via transition (for example, does a move to renewable energy sources result in at least a short-term timeframe in which electricity is both more expensive and less reliable)  Strategic risk will be impacted by RGA needing to adjust along with its clients as markets and products change, but also potentially in terms of how it does business (such as reduced travel leading to fewer in person client interactions)  As a global reinsurer, we are considering these issues globally, understanding that issues and risks may vary by location
