Company Name: TransGuard Insurance Company of America, Inc.
text:
Management has identified the most significant risk to the company as a result of climate change as being the increased frequency and/or severity of severe convective storms and hurricanes

the company uses externally developed models to assist in quantifying these risks and uses a ceded reinsurance program to mitigate the potential impact posed by these risks

Wildfires may increase in number and duration, in part because of climate change-related droughts, changes in wind and vegetation patterns, increased numbers of lightning strikes, and reduced moisture content in vegetation This could adversely impact the frequency and severity of property losses, especially in the Southwest and Rocky Mountain states Rising sea levels from Arctic warming and higher storm surges from hurricanes could impact buildings, equipment/property stored in the open and vehicles insured near the coast, bays, inlets and/or rivers While flood is not a covered peril for building and contents coverage, it is for inland marine and comprehensive coverage for vehicles In addition to increased property claims to insured property as a direct result of weather, claims for business interruption and other consequences of weather-related events become more numerous and severe
More severe convective storms and hurricanes will result in more deaths and business income
and additional living expense claims Increased exposure to claims based on liability insurance, where the insurer pays for legal claims brought by third party against the policyholder This increases defense costs even if no direct claim payments are ever made Increased regulation adopted in response to climate change may impact our organization and policyholders State insurance regulation could impact our ability to manage property exposures in areas vulnerable to significant climate-driven losses If we are unable to implement risk-based pricing, modify policy terms, reduce exposures and/or withdraw in catastrophe-prone areas as needed, our business/profits may be adversely affected Participation in residual market mechanisms can result in significant losses or assessments to insurers, especially if losses or assessments are not commensurate with our direct catastrophe exposure in those states If our competitors leave those states having residual market mechanisms, remaining insurers, including us, may be subject to significant increases in losses or assessments following a catastrophe

NWIs primary responsibility is to adhere to the investment and compliance policies established by its clients In accordance with the investment policies of the clients, NWI has a duty to assess the risks and opportunities of potential and current investments, which include those arising from climate change Therefore, NWIs credit research team considers both climate change and environmental regulations and disclosures along with many other factors in its assessment of the business risks and opportunities of all current and potential investments NWI also considers the effects of legislative action at the portfolio level when allocating funds across asset classes
The potential long-term effects of climate change are considered in a number of ways across the asset classes where NWI actively invests on behalf of its clients Some examples:
	For real estate/commercial mortgage loan investments, the potential impact of climate change factors into the evaluation/underwriting process by considering, among other things, proximity to coastal areas and increased risk of tropical storm damage, and the current water shortages that exist in the Western states
	For municipal bond investments, the ability of the bond issuer (ie municipality) to repay debt is largely influenced by the health of its local economy and stability of its population (tax) base Climate change issues ranging from water scarcity in the Southwest to coastal migration in Florida are considered when evaluating potential investments
	For corporate bond and equity investments, we review a companys policy and practice to manage climate change and environmental risks in order to assess their potential impact on overall credit worthiness We also actively monitor industry sectors that are more sensitive to climate change and environmental risks

When assessing and managing all of these risks, we consider overall company financial exposure, including insured coverage, not just investment risk

Part B:  The more specific answer is "No, not specifically in connection with climate change"  See response to first part of Question 5  As previously stated, NWI employs a comprehensive underwriting philosophy and approach that, among other things, includes assessing risks and opportunities that arise from climate change  This is a constant process that is enhanced and refined over time based upon the investment and economic environment

Company Name: Standard Security Life Insurance Company of New York
text: The company does not market P&C products/coverages Accordingly, the company has not addressed climate change with its policyholders

As a result, insured losses for our property casualty insurance business would adversely affect our financial performance and condition if the level of losses we experience over a period of time were to exceed our actuarially determined expectations 

Our property lines of business are the most exposed and we are actively expanding our geographic footprint to areas of the US that have a different or reduced catastrophe loss potential Extreme weather could also prevent our associates ability to perform necessary operational functions, such as processing new and renewal policies and claims Our ability to access our headquarters facilities or a failure of technology, communications or other systems could significantly impair our ability to perform such functions on a timely basis or affect the accuracy of transactions If sustained or repeated, such business interruption or system failure could result in a deterioration of our ability to write and process new and renewal business, serve our agents and policyholders, pay claims in a timely manner, collect receivables or perform other necessary business functions An unusually severe event could also trigger reinsurer insolvencies and/or could have more wide-spread economic and market impacts 

We have considered liquidity needs and the impacts of catastrophes coupled with market events triggered by the catastrophe that could cause investment losses and reduced liquidity  We consider risks both over short time horizons and their impact to surplus and over a thirty year time horizon, evaluating impacts on distributable cash flows 

Changes in regulation on climate change issues affecting the insurance industry could increase our cost of doing business or could restrict our ability to conduct business Regulatory changes could cause unexpected and unintended issues related to insurance pricing, claims and coverage These issues may adversely affect our business by impeding our ability to obtain adequate rates for covered risks, extending coverage beyond underwriting intent or by increasing the number or size of claims

Regional Sales Managers work closely with independent agents to ensure they understand products, pricing and practices  In addition, Company management assesses and balances market demand for new products with its intention to manage overall risk tolerance  Prudent re-insurance strategies are employed to offer products for which there is demand in the marketplace, but which exceed managements risk tolerance level  Finally, the Company maintains a strong balance of policyholder surplus reserves in the event of excessive losses

Company Name: First Allmerica Financial Life Insurance Company
text: For example, as disclosed as part of the California Departments Community Development Investments Report, the Global Atlantic insurance companies may invest in various green financing or clean energy projects  For example, the Accordia Life and Annuity Company owns a portion of two solar power plants located in Fresno, California

The majority of policies exposed to catastrophic events are one-year contracts allowing us to quickly adjust our exposure to catastrophic events if climate changes or other events increase the frequency or severity of catastrophes

AIG PC uses industry recognized models and other tools to evaluate catastrophic events and assess the probability and magnitude of such events AIG PC periodically monitors the exposure risks of our worldwide operations and adjusts the models accordingly

Climate change may increase both the frequency and severity of claims or the cost of defending such claims AIG PC policies are primarily written for periods of 12 months, providing AIG PC with the ability to modify underwriting practices and pricing procedures; limiting the financial impact of such increase in claims Each line of business and many individual policyholders may have different exposures to the effects of climate change

The strength of AIGs diverse and global franchise helps manage risks efficiently by limiting the economic impact of any single event and by contributing to a relatively stable risk profile overall However, AIG monitors natural catastrophe exposures on an ongoing basis and, through the AIG PC Environmental Working Group, is examining the latest climate science to better understand how climate change may potentially impact the frequency and severity of future extreme weather events

Gerber Life believes that climate change risk is significantly more relevant for property/casualty insurers than life insurers Gerber Life will continue to monitor current events related to climate change and consider re-assessing these risks as conditions warrant

The company utilizes industry-standard actuarial calculations in determining morbidity and mortality risk  Products are priced relative to risk trends and expense levels  The company's primary products include low-face-amount life insurance, pre-need policies, Medicare supplement policies and annuities  Products are distributed nationally with no specific geographic concentration  As such, the company does not believe there is significant climate change risk that could negatively affect business

Part of Aetnas response to CDP 2013 Question 21a is somewhat responsive to this question:
Aetna's Senior Vice President and Head of Marketing, Product and Communications, oversees Aetnas environmental sustainability practices, public policy positions, and Company responses and heads Aetnas Sustainability Council Various organizational personnel, eg, legal, insurance, real estate, and business functions, sit on the Sustainability Council and consider potential financial implications, regulatory factors, and reputational risk, using a risk management process An advisory group reports to the Council to assist in prioritizing new risks, investigate issues, and discuss new ideas

In addition Aetna also publishes an annual Corporate Responsibility booklet that is available at http://wwwaetnacom/about-aetna-insurance/document-library/cr/CorpResp2012pdf Aetna addresses  nvironmental sustainability on page 12-13 Aetna also publishes annually a more comprehensive Aetna Environmental Report detailing its progress on sustainability initiatives, which is available at http://wwwaetnacom/about-aetna-insurance/assets/documents/2013-Sustainability-Reportpdf  Aetna is a participant in the Business Roundtables Climate RESOLVE initiative and is one of the companies featured in the Business Roundtables 2012 sustainability report: Create, Grow, Sustain
Aetna has also adopted a Sustainability Policy Statement
As a health care company, we believe nothing is more important than helping people stay healthy Aetnas business strategy includes promoting sustainable practices nationally and internationally in furtherance of the health of our members, employees and communities in which we operate
We are committed to limiting our own environmental impact by reducing our energy consumption, conserving environmental resources, and adopting a sustainable approach to the management and maintenance of all real estate and business processes wherever possible We also are committed to addressing the waste that accounts for one-third of all health care costs and threatens the long-term sustainability of our health care system To that end, we will continue to work with health care professionals to further the development and availability of quality-focused, accountable care
Using a collaborative, multi-faceted approach, we are helping to develop a healthier population with a broader sense of responsibility toward the use of health care resources and with a shared sense of commitment to nurturing a healthy environment"
We maintain a webpage featuring our sustainability accomplishments, located at wwwaetnagogreencom

Company Name: Kaiser Foundation Health Plan of Washington Options
text:
KP communicates in a variety of ways with health plan members (policyholders) regarding environmental contributors to disease, and to share its efforts to promote healthy environments KPs web site features its environmental initiatives
Millions of people in KPs communities and beyond are being impacted by climate change-influenced wildfires and hurricanes KP worked to help reduce the effects of these disasters, because clean food and water, housing and power  as well as access to health care  are required to support good health and are essential to relief and recovery
KP continues to invest in state-of-the art technology to allow convenient access to high-quality care via secure messaging, telehealth, retail and employer-based clinics and mobile health vehicles These technologies and innovations help KP policyholders to potentially reduce their overall amounts of travel and travel-associated air pollution Kaiser Permanentes website, kporg, and its mobile apps, which allow access to personal medical information and communication with caregivers, were accessed over 850,000 times per day during 2018 Over 30 million prescriptions were requested via digital channels and more than 50 million lab results were viewed online in 2018 KP also uses teleconferencing, videoconferencing, and telepresence to reduce employee travel

Company Name: Horace Mann Property and Casualty Insurance Company
text:
Key risks would include risks that could conceivably be linked to climate change A comprehensive update to the Board on the status of the ERM programs and key developments is provided annually 

Additionally, our annual report contains a discussion of the potential risk factors posed by changing climate conditions, which may adversely affect the Companys financial condition, results of operation, or cash flows

The company relies on the results of commercial modeling software packages to analyze exposures to natural catastrophes The results of this modeling are used in all significant decision making, including evaluation of concentration of risks as well as the development of the companys reinsurance program

The companys underwriting risks are subject to repricing on a regular (annual) basis To the extent climate change may impact the frequency or severity of losses experienced by the companys policyholders, this impact would likely be over a prolonged period of time Any impact of climate change on the companys loss experience would be implicitly considered as part of the ongoing pricing analysis that is performed

The company also considers the impact of climate change on our business strategies We intentionally have chosen not to do business in hurricane-prone states and have also diversified our risks by expanding in recent years into states with differing weather exposures

We do, however, engage in and encourage informal measures, and our office is located in a designated "Green Spot" building that is committed to green environmental initiatives such as reduce, reuse, and recycle programs, and water and energy conservation

This strategy utilizes our expertise in identifying and managing risk and providing solutions The strategic plan focuses on the management of our operations and it is multifaceted, with elements concentrating on emissions from our facilities, fleet and travel management, paper reduction and related communication activities to key constituencies These are discussed in more detail below 

Many areas across Chubb are involved in the plan and its execution The areas include the Corporate Responsibility Office, the Chief Risk Officer, Administrative Services, the Strategic Business Units, Claims and other functional departments Recognizing the importance of environmental stewardship to our employees and other stakeholders, in 2013 we created the Corporate Responsibility Office to better coordinate and communicate our corporate citizenship activities, including our emissions reduction efforts In addition to working closely with the areas listed above, the office encourages and supports the formation of local cross-functional teams focused on reducing energy usage, paper usage and/or other initiatives to reduce our environmental impact

Annual emissions reduction and mitigation actions:
As part of our business operations, we have an annual planning process that includes emissions reduction and mitigation activities
As a result, since 2008 in the facilities we manage in the United States, we have:
	Reduced our Scope 1 and 2 emissions by almost 18% 
	Reduced electric consumption in corporate facilities by over 19% 
	Reduced natural gas consumption in corporate facilities by over 30% 

In 2013, our corporate global headquarters and two other buildings we own received Energy Star Certification

On a monthly basis, we recycle desk-side paper, secured shredded paper, glass, plastic, corrugated (cardboard), batteries, lamps, lamp housing or fixtures, ballasts, thermostats, aluminum, tin, copper, other metals, fryer grease, carpet, refrigerant, oil, diesel, paint, asphalt, chemicals, used equipment and motors On a seasonal basis, we recycle grass clippings, leaves, tree branches and stumps

In our offices we deploy:
	A Green Cleaning Program using cleaning materials which are certified green by Green Seal, Inc
	Paper towels with recycled or post-consumer waste content
	Coreless toilet paper to reduce cardboard roll waste (all New Jersey sites)
	Air fresheners that contain low or no Volatile Organic Compounds (VOC) (all New Jersey locations)
	No or low VOC paint
	No or low VOC chemicals when applicable
	New office furniture (desks, chairs, tables, filing cabinets etc) with recycled content, post-consumer or post-industrial waste (when needed)
	New carpet with recycled content (when needed)
	No or low VOC carpet adhesive
	New ceiling tiles (USG 450 White Frost) with over 50% recycled content and that have zero emissions (when needed, global headquarters location)
	Environmentally friendly roadway de-icing pellets (Whitehouse Station, NJ, location)

Energy savings for those buildings we lease and/or manage are achieved by:
	Conducting energy audits
	Having the HVAC (heating, ventilation and air conditioning) equipment and systems retro-commissioned
	Replacing failed appliances with Energy Star certified appliances (hot water heaters, refrigerators, dish washing machines)
	Replacing all failed motors with more energy efficient models (when applicable), and controlling motors by Variable Frequency Drives (VFDs) to modulate the motor speed based on need 
	Replacing heating and cooling units with more energy efficient units 
	Using building automation systems to efficiently operate lighting and HVAC systems based on need

As we renovate or relocate our non-owned/managed offices around the globe, we seek ways to reduce our environmental footprint For example, when we relocated our Atlanta branch in 2013, the corporate real estate team selected space in a LEED Silver certified building The building's certification was based on its proximity and shuttle service to MARTA, the local public transportation system; an on-site bank and restaurant; shuttle service to nearby shopping; a 3,500-square-foot training facility, which enables tenants to reduce their space requirements; and a building energy management system We designed the space with several environmental-friendly elements in mind By leaving part of the ceiling exposed, polishing concrete floors and leaving columns unfinished, we were able to reduce our consumption of carpeting, drywall and other materials Locating offices on the interior of the floor also reduced material usage and enabled us to take advantage of natural light and airflow, and the installation of efficient workstations helped minimize our square footage requirements 

Telecommuting:
	Chubb offers employee telecommuting and compressed work weeks Approximately 15% of our US based workforce teleworks 1 or more days per week In addition, approximately 3% of the US workforce is on a compressed work schedule

Fleet and Travel Management:
	We transitioned to a four-cylinder fleet in 2011 Each vehicle is replaced at 45,000 miles The overall fleet benefits from continuous improvements in fuel economy and carbon reduction technology, which has further improved GHG benefits by reducing the total carbon in 2013 another 25%, the equivalent of removing eighteen vehicles from the fleet
	In 2010, we introduced a policy encouraging employees to rent a car for all daily business trips in excess of 150 miles  The rental vehicles offered are 4-cylinder, thus limiting usage of personal cars, which may be SUVs, trucks or 6- or 8-cylinder sedans  In 2013, 75% of rentals were for four-cylinder vehicles 
	As of year-end 2013, nearly 1,300 Chubb travelers opted in to receive electronic copies, instead of paper copies, of hotel folios  
	As part of our annual hotel RFP process, Chubb Travel Services has made a concerted effort to partner with suppliers who have strong corporate responsibility and sustainability programs and projects  One major hotel chain partner has experienced a 9% reduction in energy consumption, and has lowered GHG emissions by 10% and water consumption by 7% 

Paper reduction:
	Paperless initiatives in all three Strategic Business Units, Claims, Billing and HR, combined saved over 15 million sheets of paper of paper in 2013 Examples include:
¿	100% of Chubb agents who write commercial direct bill business (where customers are billed and remit premiums directly to Chubb) review monthly commission statements on line 
¿	Chubb's Agency Bill agents are divided between those that submit a report of premiums due to us versus those that receive from us a statement of premiums due  90% of agents submitting a report of premiums due to us do so electronically while 100% of those receiving a statement of premiums due receive that statement electronically 
¿	Premium Accounting's Legal Collections unit serves as the liaison between Chubb and a number of outside collection agencies who are assigned premiums to collect on our behalf when internal collection efforts have been exhausted  100% of the communications between Chubb and those outside firms takes place electronically and all internal records are maintained in a paperless environment
¿	Premium Accounting has seen a 85% reduction in the receipt of paper checks in its bank lock box utilized for national brokers  Paper check receipts in 2013 totaled 5,000 while we project 800 paper checks received for 2014  Payments are instead being electronically wire transferred directly into Chubb's account
¿	988% of our payroll advices are online
¿	Personal Lines customers have the option to receive their policy electronically 
¿	Commercial Lines customers can remit payments over the phone or online
¿	98% of the documentation Personal Lines sends to agents and brokers in the US is done so electronically
¿	62% of our Commercial Lines agents are enrolled in our paper-free program 
¿	100% of all new claims are now digitized and stored/archived electronically 
¿	In 2013, the Claim Department completed full deployment of a document management system that digitizes all physical incoming claim mail  During 2013, more than one million electronic documents were digitized, rather than printed, by the Claim Department 

We recognize that our customers, employees and other key stakeholders are increasingly interested in our sustainability efforts, including with respect to emissions reduction, and an area of focus for the Corporate Responsibility Office is communicating our efforts  One of the Corporate Responsibility Offices first actions was to launch an internal social media site to communicate our actions, to engage employees and to share recommendations on managing and reducing environmental impact at the office and at home  The site launch included a video featuring the President of Personal Lines and Claims discussing the importance corporate responsibility at Chubb

We provide updates on our plans and progress toward meeting goals in our response to the CDP, as well as periodically on wwwchubbcom and through customer communications For example, we send communications to our personal lines policyholders to encourage them to make the world a greener place by enrolling in our paperless option - ePolicy

N American natural catastrophe exposures are monitored in house using  the AIR model with regular comparison against the RMS models  Modelled results are based on warm sea surface temperatures (WSST), which recognise the impact of climate change on sea temperatures  In addition in-house models have been developed  to monitor accumulations following recent increased incidents of hail

RMS and AIR catastrophe models are used to calculate probable maximum losses  These models consider earthquake, fire following earthquake, and wildfire but we are not aware of them including climate change risk  The Company does not have the expertise to distinguish risk caused by natural variability in weather patterns to the risk caused by climate change

NORCAL strives to make it easy for its employees to reduce its collective environmental footprint To promote that goal, NORCAL has instituted the following standards and/or processes at all office locations where possible:  Recycle waste toners: return to vendor or a remanufacturer  All disposable utensils, plates, and cups are compostable  Paper towels are produced from 100% recycled material  In-line filtered water: reduces delivery emissions associated with large bottle dispensers and reduces usage of individual bottled water  All locations offer recycle bins for cans and paper, and SF office also supplies compostable bins  All lighting in SF is LED and tied into sensors that automatically dim during brighter days to reduce electricity consumption  Motion sensors automatically turn off lights in rooms that are not in use  Redistribution of office products, internally  Environmentally friendly disposal of obsolete electronic materials  Recycling of old office furniture after replacement  All the new office furniture was made from reclaimed wood  

NORCAL further reduced its carbon footprint in 2020 due to the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic  Almost all of NORCALs employees currently work from home and we plan to make either full-time or hybrid work-from-home options available to the majority of our employees after stay-at-home orders are lifted

Therefore, any regulations addressing climate change are not likely to directly impact the companys products or services  Rather, the Company may be indirectly exposed to regulatory risk as it relates to climate change if regulations impact certain sectors in which the Company holds investments  (See response to question 2)  Although the Company does not believe that climate change currently poses, or is anticipated to pose in the foreseeable future, any material risks to the Company, a significant increase in average mortality and morbidity rates in any geographical area could potentially result in an increase in loss ratios for the Company  These risks would be identified and monitored as part of the Companys existing enterprise risk management process

Although the credit quality of investments plays a large role in our risk assessment of our portfolio, we consider the impact of climate change in our overall investment strategy We include the related effects of climate change in our evaluation of investment opportunities We may include in our investment evaluation process any prospective changes and/or opportunities in the renewable energy sector, economic or regulatory restrictions affecting a particular sector and/or effects of severe weather in a particular industry 
As of March 31st, 2017, we held 44% of our corporate bond portfolio in the Utilities sector, which includes investments in energy A portion of our energy portfolio is with companies dedicated to renewable energy and/or sustainable ways of harvesting and delivering energy to communities around the world

The Companies consider the impact of weather related events in their business continuity and disaster recovery plans The organizations Enterprise Risk Management program identifies and analyzes risks and mitigation strategies  As part of this program, the property and casualty insurance companies use commercially available catastrophe models to model hurricanes, severe storms and earthquakes in order to estimate the possible impact of catastrophic events on their business This analysis considers weather related climate change  

Climate change risk has not been identified as a discrete risk among the significant investment market risk factors for the Companies The potential for climate change risk impacting the portfolio is addressed holistically and not isolated to a particular investment type  Accordingly, all of the Companies risk monitoring beginning with asset allocation through individual asset purchase limits assists with monitoring each individual risk

The above processes feed into the organizations enterprise risk management program

We do not create products and we have a minimal impact on the environment  We offer LTD, STD and Life policies The extreme weather and climate change could pose a threat to our policyholder's An individual could get injured or killed by extreme weather changes - blizzards, torrential rain storms, flooding The probability of these weather related events materially affecting our financial statement bottom line is minimal

We use underwriting guidelines to mitigate weather-related losses in areas that are more prone to such activity  We evaluate trends in historical catastrophe loss, and continue to watch for new developing trends as climactic change continues to effect weather patterns  We also work closely with our reinsurance partners who use sophisticated catastrophe models to help us better understand our exposures to loss and develop loss estimates for natural disasters  The external models help us determine how much reinsurance to purchase and how it should be structured to satisfy our risk tolerance levels  

As referenced in response to Question 2, we also have developed business continuity plans that address our ongoing business operations should one or more of our locations become damaged by a severe weather-related event
Medicas focus includes energy conservation, waste minimization, recycling, community outreach, & wellness initiatives

Included within these risk mitigation efforts is the application of fortified standards developed by the Insurance Institute for Business and Home Safety (IBHS) As part of this program, mitigation credits can be earned by our customers thus reducing the premium we charge along with reducing the potential future losses due to weather-type events Nationwide also offers a home inventory process that allows consumers the ability to track their personal belongings for when an unfortunate event occurs Nationwide mailed information to 55,000 of our members in high wildfire hazard areas in Western states in the Spring of 2015 The mailing provided them with a website and information from IBHS on how to make their homes and businesses safer from wildfire  Nationwide believes that proper hazard mitigation is an effective way to address the increasing threat from wildfire  We are in the process of re-inspecting our portfolio and making risk reduction recommendations to our members on how to mitigate their wildfire hazard

In addition, to continue driving more awareness around the benefits from risk mitigation, Nationwide is implementing a new endorsement focused on replacing roofs according to the different IBHS standards at the time of an eligible loss which will result in a more weather-proofed roof IBHS guidance for mitigating property losses is available directly to the public at wwwdisastersafetyorg Increased risk sharing through the utilization of wind/hail deductibles is also being implemented to help encourage consumers to proactively mitigate weather claims In addition, Nationwide is active at the local and national level to help drive the necessary building code changes to make homes safer Nationwide is an active member of the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) Wildland and Rural Fire Protection committee This is a committee that develops codes, standards, and recommended practices for fire protection infrastructure used in land development in wildland, rural, and suburban areas

As catastrophe risk increases in certain markets, Nationwide continues to invest in the necessary tools to better understand the risk, whether it be hurricanes, severe thunderstorms or wildfires Financially, the importance of geographic diversification within Nationwides portfolio is one of the key levers to being a successful property insurer Included within this work is the integration of risk management findings into pricing, product development and distribution planning along with consumer education

Along similar lines, Nationwide constructed one of the first ever commercial buildings in San Antonio that is certified as fortified according to IBHS standards and we have also built a second office building to those standards in downtown Columbus The company continues to not only help drive these types of changes within the community but across the different businesses In partnership with home builders, banks, consumers, IBHS and legislatures, the necessary changes will need to occur leading to improvements in building codes and risk management in general

From a commercial standpoint, Nationwide provides education and loss control services to assist customers in identifying risks, ways to mitigate risks along with including exclusionary language for certain risk types within its contracts Through individual risk pricing modifications, those consumers who respond to these services in a positive manner could be eligible for improved pricing considerations

The Company also offers technical loss control support to 
policyholders on weather related exposures, including through the use of resources 
from the Institute for Business and Home Safety

Our investment advisory firm periodically reviews the ESG ratings for all the companies in our portfolio, which includes Environmental, Social, and Governance risks Our portfolio is assigned a letter grade rating from CCC (lowest) to AAA (highest) This gives our company a great indicator of how we are performing regarding climate risk No, we have not altered our investment strategy in response to these considerations
The primary risks considered in our investment strategy are:  Interest Rate Risk, Reinvestment Risk, Liquidity Risk, Credit Risk, Concentration Risk, and Tax Risk

Humana is committed to integrating green building principles into our existing and new portfolio of facilities with a focus on energy and water efficiency Humana advanced this objective through the integration of climate and sustainability factors such as energy efficiency projects at our facilities, access to transportation, Energy Star or LEED ranking, employee engagement (ie, behavioral change) and other parameters, into the decision criteria used to improve our facility portfolio and select future Humana locations  Opportunities for improving the portfolio and achieving energy and GHG reduction goals are identified by the Workplace Solutions team in collaboration with our external consulting partners  Initiatives may be evaluated and presented to the senior management for support and funding including capital investment, associate involvement (ie, resource support) or other requirements  

Humanas short-term strategy (<3 years) is influenced by climate change most notably with regard to our environmental goals, set to expire at the end of 2017 These goals influence our team to focus on energy efficient operations, spurring direct investment in resources, both financial and personnel, to focus on climate change mitigation within our owned and leased facilities These investments have enabled Humana to implement a portfolio-wide LED lighting retrofit program and other projects to increase the efficient use of energy at our facilities In addition, our design standards team, architect and engineering consultants, and facilities team collaborated in 2016 to develop a comprehensive set of design standards for office and clinical operations to ensure consistency, energy efficiency, and sustainable practices across new builds and renovations Overall, our facility portfolio efforts have resulted in over $18MM in cost savings, 65,000 MMBtu in energy reduction, and nearly 11,000 mt CO2e GHG reduction  Finally, ongoing workspace optimization efforts increase workspace density while also decreasing building vacancies, thereby reducing our physical footprint and alleviating commute burden to reduce energy usage and emissions

On the whole, energy use reduction and greenhouse gas emissions reduction efforts not only drive progress toward our sustainability goals, but also illustrate to our employees and customers our commitment to reduce GHG emissions and operate as efficiently as possible Employee engagement efforts include a continuing focus on increasing work from home with the understanding that this strategy will have a significant impact on Scope 3 emissions, while providing our workforce greater flexibility and reducing operational demands of our facilities By the end of 2015, nearly 50,000 sq ft of traditional space was converted to agile work space at eight locations, while 34% of Humanas employees worked from home by the end of 2016

Our long-term strategy (generally considered to be 5-10 years) is impacted by potential consequences of climate change such as regulation, natural resource scarcity, facility operational costs and human health impacts Our Workplace Solutions leaders review short- and long-term trends and impacts associated with sustainability and refine our business strategy accordingly For example, Humana's portfolio includes both owned and leased assets where many facility investments are on a long-term basis (up to 10 years) Our sustainable real estate approach ensures these investments take into consideration the long-term impacts of building characteristics on climate change and overall environmental impact, employee wellness, and operational costs

Liberty Mutual selects and monitors investments to balance the goals of safety, stability, liquidity, growth, and after-tax total return with the objective to protect and grow its assets so that it may meet its policyholder commitments Focusing on just one factor and applying it broadly limits our ability to maintain a safe, diversified, and profitable portfolio Liberty Mutual maintains a dedicated Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) program that evaluates the potential financial impact for risks on all material aspects of its business We believe this enterprise wide approach to be the most prudent way to address risks and their impact on Liberty Mutuals investments and its insurance business

Company Name: Foremost Property and Casualty Insurance Company
text:
Regulatory risks as diverse as insurance regulatory obligations, emissions caps, base load management requirements, and building code requirements could impact the insurance business  Regulation, as well, can have the unintended consequence of masking risk based price signals and could cause stakeholders to increase climate related risk  rather than manage and reduce such risks  For example, subsidizing property insurance premiums, or flood insurance premiums or providing insurance or agreements to re-build in regularly eroded coastal locations or high risk fire areas could cause increase of building in such locations in a manner economically inconsistent with the physical risks presented by climate change

Regulatory uncertainty and regulation that is not economically well-grounded can create additional risk for both insurers and society  Even where public policies are well grounded in sound economic policy, multi-state and nationally active insurers will likely be required to address potentially disparate and conflicting climate policies and rules and bear the associated costs 

These generally complex issues involving the interplay of new requirements within existing legal structures create unique risks; results of the same public policy will likely be different when applied in different jurisdictions - unless the results of interplay are completely and accurately analyzed in the development of such policy

Potential unintended negative consequences of regulatory action could pose a challenge for the industry, such as where the true economic cost of new legislation has not been well thought through or where the new legislation results in a disproportionate allocation of costs of climate related risk  In addition, competing requirements could mean that compliance in one jurisdiction may not satisfy other jurisdictions, thus creating duplicative or additive expenditures in the development of adaptive risk management solutions without demonstrable economic or social benefit  Additionally, regulatory actions may restrict a company from making needed changes to its pricing or prompt litigation which could put a financial strain on the organization

As the insurance industry faces regulatory risk, they face legal risk as well  Climate-related legislation that is not well-crafted may create incentives for law suits in some jurisdictions  Even in the absence of new laws, there have already been and may continue to be attempts to use existing laws to bring more climate change-related litigation against sovereign entities and companies in particular sectors 

With respect to an insurers own operations and physical facilities, regulatory initiatives relating to emissions limits, transportation, water and energy use could impact office planning, employee commuting patterns and general resource usage  Within Farmers, activities to help respond to these trends have begun, including telecommuting, meetings held via phone, video and webinar, recycling and other environmentally-friendly practices

Farmers also has exposure to physical risks of climate change with respect to its own operations and as a result of exposures of its insureds assumed by Farmers though insurance policies  As outlined in the previous section, the physical risks impacting Farmers customers, as a result of climate change, may generate higher volatility in claims

A growing consensus among climate change experts suggests that changing weather patterns present risks of concern related to climate change  Direct impacts such as increased frequency and severity of precipitation events, droughts, wildfire are among the multiplicity of potential conditions that could impact ultimate loss events for insureds  The risk of these events could also pose a financial strain on the organization  Improved resilience and customers risk management actions continue to be significant foci of Farmers  The potential indirect physical and public health impact, such as increased frequency of widespread disease events and localized food and water shortages, may also affect many areas of property and casualty and life insurance  Such physical risks have both obvious and subtle consequences for insurers  These vulnerabilities, risks, and consequences are considered as an integrated part of the underwriting process in a manner appropriate given the tenor of the insurance instrument and the manifestation of variability, risk management vulnerability reductions and impacts

With regard to the insurers' own operations or investments, insurers, like their customers, have facilities and operations that are exposed to physical risks of climate change described above  Climate change (severe drought) may drive people/employees away from California, which could be damaging to a Southern California based company

See also the responses to Questions 3 and 5

In addition, to continue driving more awareness around the benefits from risk mitigation, Nationwide is implementing a new endorsement focused on replacing roofs according to the different IBHS standards at the time of an eligible loss which will result in a more weather-proofed roof  IBHS guidance for mitigating property losses is available directly to the public at wwwdisastersafetyorg 
Increased risk sharing through the utilization of wind/hail deductibles is also being implemented to help encourage consumers to proactively mitigate weather claims  In addition, Nationwide is active at the local and national level to help drive the necessary building code changes to make homes safer    Nationwide is an active member of the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) Wildland and Rural Fire Protection committee  This is a committee that develops codes, standards, and recommended practices for fire protection infrastructure used in land development in wildland, rural, and suburban areas

We have also made funds available to remove snow an dice from the insured's roofs in the northern territories to reduce the possibilities of roof collapses due to the weight of ice and snow which could increase due to climate change

We monitor our exposure to potential catastrophe losses by using catastrophe models These models help us quantify the financial impact from potential hurricane, earthquake, earthquake fire-following, severe convective storm and winter weather events on a probabilistic basis We utilize these results to manage and purchase our catastrophe reinsurance program 
Additionally, we include the results of the catastrophe model in our internal economic capital model (ECM) Our ECM is a stochastic model used to quantify and analyze the financial impact and probability of occurrence of key risks faced by our company: underwriting risk, credit risk, interest rate risk and operational risk Weather-related events and losses from catastrophes are included within underwriting risk Through our ECM we have determined that weather-related events account for a significant portion of our potential capital requirements 
Furthermore, we include the effect of weather-related losses in our underwriting practices by attributing a percentage of losses due to weather-related events into our business planning We utilize model results and prior experience to estimate the financial impact from potential weather-related losses At an underwriting level, we manage our exposure to weather-related events by integrating catastrophe modeling tools in our underwriting practices, allowing us to leverage sophisticated models in our assessment of potential new business This includes assessing our exposure to wildfires, as well as, the aforementioned weather-related events 
We recognize that climate change is a complex and evolving risk Our ERM program continues to monitor and assess the financial impact of weather-related risks

Each such risk is evaluated as to probability of occurence and severity of loss should such an event occur  to date, so climate change related risk has scored high enough to make our ongoing list of significant risks to the company  While catostrophic weather event is a monitored risk, it is not specific to climate change

However, climate change is considered along with other risks to the Company through its existing Enterprise Risk Management processes  As an insurer focused on supplemental health, annuities and life products, the Companys risks of climate change relate primarily to adverse impacts on morbidity and mortality rates  Changes in morbidity and mortality risks are monitored through existing enterprise risk management practices and considered in the Companys standard pricing and underwriting processes   

The Company recognizes that climate change may impact general economic conditions  Government policies to slow climate change (eg, setting limits on carbon emissions) may have an impact on sectors such as utilities, transportation and manufacturing  The analysis of investments held in these sectors includes the possibility of additional regulation  The Company manages its investment risks by maintaining a well-diversified portfolio, both by sector and geographically  Risks related to climate change in the investment portfolio are monitored through the existing enterprise risk management process used to assess and manage overall investment risk

These risks are included among the risks managed within the overall investment process In the case of corporate fixed maturities risks are mitigated by an established issuer exposure limit framework and regular monitoring of industry exposures In the case of commercial mortgage and agricultural mortgage loan investment activities, bottom-up underwriting guidelines, in-depth collateral evaluations and maintaining broad geographical diversification all serve to mitigate exposure to regional variances that may be caused by climate change In the ordinary course of our investing activities we have made and continue to be interested in investments in businesses and companies that advance development of alternative energy sources At 12/31/2012 the reporting Companies had approximately $90 mm invested in wind, hydro and solar energy related investments

Our plans to mitigate emissions in operations and organization include:

-	Encouraging our policyholders to utilize electronic means of transacting business with the confines of state approved procedures Electronic transactions mean a smaller environmental footprint

-	Ensuring energy efficiency in the facilities we utilize The group has facilities in Manhattan, NY and Roanoke, Virginia The building in which the companys Manhattan  office  is located, at 100 west 33rd street, is certified by US Green Building Council as meeting the GOLD standard for LEED 2009 Existing Buildings Operations and Maintenance The building received very high marks for energy efficiency (both on-site and offsite renewable energy), emissions reduction reporting and solid waste management The emissions footprint of the building was a consideration in its selection The group recently added a second location in Roanoke, VA, and took steps in the design of that space to address energy efficiency This includes meeting ASHRAE (The American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers) guidelines for ventilation and filtration, programmable thermostats, and HVAC duct design for even distribution of air flow


-	Encouraging work from home arrangements for its workforce, and mass transit use for those working out of its Manhattan office The majority of employees working out of the Manhattan office use mass transit to commute; the group has commuter savings programs and it has picked a location that was conducive to using mass transit Videoconferencing is extensively used to connect remote sites for meetings Finally, the group   has work from home programs which help reduce emissions

-	Co-sharing a data center The groups data center was moved to a shared location in North Carolina Sharing of space and resources helps reduce emissions The data center provider is one of the top 30 tech and telecom companies in the EPAs Green Power Partner Program The data center was designed and built with a focus on effectiveness and efficiency This practice helps minimize the depletion of resources and maximizes infrastructure capacities to support our business needs One example is the implementation of smart cooling solutions that leverage artificial intelligence (AI) and predictive analytics The data center also purchases green power where it is available and competitively priced to support green power production By carefully attending to these elements, we minimize our carbon footprint

-	Minimizing printing of marketing materials The company digitizes much of its marketing collateral This means that agents only use materials as needed and additional emissions are not created in overstocking materials

Next, the group will research ways of accounting for its emissions production Once we have a benchmark, we will consider ways of reducing our emissions

Company Name: Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America
text:
Nuveen issues a publicly available summary report at https://wwwnuveencom/responsible-investing-summary-report, which describes the firms overall approach to incorporating ESG factors into investment analysis, our responsible investing principles, portfolio construction and ongoing monitoring across asset classes with the objective of enhancing long-term performance, managing risk and aligning client values Our RI and climate related publicly available information is posted on nuveencom/responsible-investing 
With respect to current holdings in agriculture, timber and real estate, individual investment teams have engaged key constituencies affecting their sector as follows:
	The Agriculture team has an ongoing dialogue with our external clients to engage on the issue of climate change and farmland portfolio impacts and strategy The Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) Advisory Council for our third-party farmland investment vehicle regularly reviews ESG activities within the portfolio We engage internal and external stakeholders on the topic of climate change through our annual Responsible Investment in Farmland report, which is publicly available We also regularly consult external subject-matter experts and engage with local, regional, and global non-governmental organizations (NGOs) to inform and guide our thinking and approach on the topic of climate change 
	Our timberland team is committed to maintaining environmental quality in its forestry operations and is recognized for its best-practice forest stewardship programs and techniques TIAA requires compliance with local laws and environmental regulations We actively encourage proactive interactions by the timberland team with relevant local stakeholders and identification and implementation of environmental enhancement opportunities The timberland team is also active as speakers at timberland and sustainable investment conferences to interact and share perspectives with other interested parties and stakeholders
	The Nuveen Real Estate sustainability program has facilitated engagement with clients, investors, residents, tenants, employees and industry peers through direct contact, marketing campaigns and national platforms such as the Department of Energys Better Buildings Challenge, where TIAA has provided multiple implementation models and showcase projects, to demonstrate actions and processes to help others reduce their exposure to climate risk Nuveen Real Estate provides transparency to investors on ESG strategy and performance and issues an enterprise-wide real estate investments ESG report on an annual basis, including the GA, TIAA Real Estate Account, and all Nuveen-managed third party funds Nuveen Real Estate reports to the Global Real Estate Sustainability Benchmark (GRESB) framework and discloses ESG key performance indicators to investors
Through our proprietary impact framework within our Core Impact Bond strategies, we invest in projects and entities that directly benefit the environment, in keeping with our investment themes of Renewable Energy and Climate Change and Natural Resources As of the end of 2019, Core Impact Bond strategies invested over $3 billion in green bonds - bonds whose proceeds are earmarked to support environmentally beneficial projects or activities We continue to serve as an expert resource for both issuers and investment banks across fixed income sectors in how to structure, execute and report on environmentally beneficial deals  TIAA Investments served on the initial Executive Committee of the Green Bond Principles, which is working on developing voluntary guidelines for green bond issuance and impact reporting
Engagement with Portfolio Companies 
TIAA upholds the view that, as an institutional investor, we have a responsibility to foster long-term value creation through active ownership activities including direct dialogue with investee firms and proxy voting in public equities holdings  Our Nuveen Responsible Investing team implements this long-term perspective, in part, by communicating our view on material ESG matters, including the physical and transition risks from climate change and other salient factors that are likely to affect the long-term performance of individual companies and/or the broader market We encourage corporate managers and boards to carefully assess, manage, mitigate and disclose their ESG risks and opportunities along with robust, time-bound, and measurable ESG performance targets Ultimately, improvements in portfolio companies ESG performance is in our clients best economic interests as these measures help protect shareholder value 
In accordance with the TIAA Policy Statement on Responsible Investing, we recommend that managers in portfolio companies assess material climate-related risks and resource efficiency in operations, production processes, and supply chain management and that they publicly disclose meaningful data relevant to both  We consistently encourage companies that that are exposed to material physical or transition risks related to climate change to disclose the results of forward-looking climate risk scenario analysis, such as a scenario in which global average temperature rise is limited to two degrees Celsius or less above pre-industrial levels  We find that companies that evaluate the potential impacts of future climate scenarios on their key drivers of business performance are not only better prepared for the negative aspects of climate change but also are better able to identify potential opportunities stemming from the low carbon transition
Company disclosures should convey to shareholders how climate change may impact the companys long term business outlook, strategic planning and capital allocation decisions  
We believe that a companys board of directors is responsible for ensuring management accountability, assessing operational strategies and overseeing risk mitigation frameworks As part of this responsibility, we believe the board should guide the development of a strategic, long-term approach to addressing climate-change-related risks and hold management accountable for its implementation As such, we convey to board directors our expectations that they should readily engage with their management teams in developing corporate strategies and performance expectations to address climate-change-related risk  We underscore our expectation by emphasizing that all companies should adopt and report on relevant, science-based climate change management performance targets that are aligned with the Paris Agreement  
When voting on shareholder proposals related to global climate change issues, TIAA will generally support reasonable shareholder resolutions seeking disclosure of greenhouse gas emissions, the impact of climate change on a companys business activities and products, and strategies designed to reduce the companys long-term impact on global climate We supported 83% of climate change proposals in 2019

A significant increase in average mortality rates in any geographical area of the United States could potentially result in an increase in loss ratios for the Company We, however, do not believe conclusive data exists that demonstrates climate change currently poses, or is anticipated to pose in the foreseeable future, any risks to the Company that are material to an assessment of the Company's financial soundness

As our business evolves to respond to healthcare reform in the United States  through integrated healthcare delivery and operational cost reductions  we are transforming our business strategy to be more agile and responsive to current healthcare trends For example: strategically selecting and managing our changing real estate portfolio of office properties and associated services (such as data centers), expanding our number of medical clinics, and other new facility concepts are core to our success in responding to changing market demands and to the impacts of climate change We have invested staff resources and capital funds to manage risks and opportunities presented by the rising costs of fossil fuel-based energy and to improve building energy efficiency  Addressing and collecting data on energy usage and intensity in these facilities supports our latest greenhouse gas emissions-reduction goal to reduce energy consumption and GHG emissions by 5 percent by the end of 2017, and allows us to further understand risks and opportunities related to our energy use We support this goal by collecting data on building energy efficiency and green building features when considering new spaces to purchase or lease

We have not included speculation about future trends deviating substantially from historical observations in our catastrophe risk management at this time

Company Name: The Providence Mutual Fire Insurance Company
text: PMFIC is licensed in eight states  New England, New York and New Jersey and we distribute our products through the independent agency system  The Company works out of one office located on 340 East Avenue in Warwick, RI  The building is 25,000 square feet and houses approximately 100 employees  PMFIC is mindful over the impact of our operations on the environment  Specifically, PMFIC promotes a paperless workspace by utilizing the electronic documentation tool ImageRight in all of our business processes  Whenever paper documents are needed, recycling is implemented and toner cartridges are recycled  Additionally, our Company building is equipped with several energy efficient features, including: lighting sensors, water sensors, HVAC auto controls and energy efficient appliances  Lastly, telecommuting is offered whenever possible

Secondarily, we continue to monitor the potential for inland risks such as increased flooding, hail, wildfires, and winter storms as a result of climate change  Areas such as the central United States may experience increased frequency and severity of damaging hail storms and tornados with climate change as well as these events occurring in areas that have historically been considered low-risk such as the Northwest United States

While both our vehicle and property lines of business are exposed to the variabilities of climate change, we believe the homeowners business is most at risk  The Property business uses a vendor model that captures the potential for natural disaster/weather-related perils into pricing and underwriting practices and, in some cases, have not written policies in what are believed to be high-risk geographies  Additionally, the Company manages its climate change-risks by employing reinsurance in its Property business

Our Directors and Officers (D&O) and Commercial General Liability (CGL) coverages are expected to apply to foreseeable claims related to climate change, and our property reinsurance transfers catastrophe risk at much greater confidence levels than we apply to other lines of business and other risks

We also use the results of the models to estimate potential weather losses at the level of individual properties and small geographic territories We use conservative modeling assumptions to reflect the increased risk that may be associated with climate change In addition, we have business continuity plans in place so that in the event of severe weather or other crises, we can continue to provide our policyholders with the high level of service they expect and deserve

Go Green Initiative:   This initiative is for the Regional Sales Managers to sign up their Agents to Go Green By doing so we will be eliminating any hard copy print going to the Agent All New Agents are automatically set up as Go Green The initiative reduces the amount of print, paper and electricity used in the whole print process

Monitoring includes interaction with the National Weather Service, and offices of emergency management nationwide The Companies work in an anticipatory mode, trying to track climate systems Communications is one of the most important components of crisis management For the past 8 years, the Companies have utilized an automated notification system, in which every employee's contact information is populated We communicate information to employees and managers, before and during a crisis We have found this to be a most effective way of dealing with a crisis, and most importantly, dealing with the intensity of the crisis Also, the Companies offices or policyholders may be negatively affected by climate change impacts and natural disasters, such as hurricane, tornadoes, flooding, etc In response to these risks, the Companies Business Continuity Management (BCM) plan can be implemented in the event of a major crisis that could potentially result in a significant interruption of services The BCM process requires a sound governance structure and effective buy-in among all company management teams The Companies BCM plan and emergency planning follow the following principles: Ensure the safety of the staff All steps must be taken to ensure the safety of employees Drills are routinely conducted to familiarize employees with what should be done in an emergency situation Employees also are familiarized with the accounting and reporting process so managers are aware of the location and condition of their staff in an emergency situation Establish communications The Companies have established an order of communications that will be used in any emergency situation The company has improved communications capabilities of professionals who deal with emergency situations and has added direct connect communication capabilities In addition, all employees should know the telephone numbers to call in case of an emergency All managers should know how to contact each of their employees in the event of an emergency Decide recovery scenarios Once an analysis of an emergency situation has been made and the repercussions are understood, the company's management will implement a plan of action to bring the firm back to work as quickly, safely and efficiently as possible Get the staff back to work The Companies will provide the ability to connect to servers and databases in the event of a building outage if the servers and databases are still functioning at another location Policyholders Services The Companies have established procedures in place to communicate to operational units of the Companies insurance departments mandates related to climate disasters The process ensures the prompt and effective implementation of any required emergency procedures to protect policyholders from interruption of coverage and ensure prompt payment of claims

Company Name: Coventry Health Care of Missouri, Inc.
text: The following describes risks driven by changes in regulation: Risk driver: General environmental regulations including planning; Description: Aetna considers itself indirectly exposed to regulatory risks related to greenhouse gas emissions As a US-based insurance benefits corporation, Aetna does not produce products or services leading directly to the emissions of substantial amounts of greenhouse gases or other pollutants Aetna considers the impact to this driver to be from additional costs associated with regulatory compliance; Potential impact: Increased operational cost; Time-frame: >6 years; Direct/Indirect: Indirect (supply chain); Likeli-hood: About as likely as not; Magnitude of impact: Low; Estimated financial implications: Unknown Aetna operations are housed predominately in leased locations with minimal fuel burning equipment on-site Any regulatory risk is expected to be generated by Aetna's purchase of electricity or fuels As the majority of Aetna leases include electricity and other utilities in the lease rate, the amount Aetna pays may increase, although by how much is uncertain Management method: Unknown The majority of Aetna leases are multi-year If regulations were to drive electrical and fuel costs higher, it is expected that these increased costs would be passed on to Aetna If that were the case then Aetna could pursue separate metering allowing Aetna the opportunity to handle the costs directly and then to implement measures to lower electricity and fuel costs to reap any savings Cost of mgt: Unknown The following describes risks driven by change in physical climate parameters: Risk driver: Change in temperature extremes; Description: Aetna considers itself indirectly exposed to physical risks related to physical climate parameters - either extreme heat or cold; Risk driver: Change in temperature extremes; Description: Aetna considers itself indirectly exposed to physical risks related to physical climate parameters - either extreme heat or cold;Potential impact: Increased operational cost; Time frame: >6 years; Direct/Indirect: Indirect (Supply chain); Likeli-hood: About as likely as not; Magnitude of impact: Low; Estimated financial implications: Unknown Aetna operations are housed predominately in leased locations At this point it is unclear whether Aetna would need to relocate offices based upon temperature extremes, whether mitigating methods would or would not be available, or what the costs associated with these would be Aetna has a Business Continuity Unit which creates and incorporates scenarios addressing situations that would impact its operations; Mgt method: Aetna constantly evaluates its business operations and demands tailoring its real estate requirements to meet these needs Several options are available whether it be relocation, reduction (or increase) in real estate and facility needs, increasing telecommuting options, etc Aetna's Business Continuity Department addresses situations such as that would impact its operations incorporating various strategies such as re-direction of operations, identifying a need for alternative locations, etc Cost of mgt: The future costs associated with this management method are expected to be similar if not identical to current expenditures Risk driver: Tropical cyclones (hurricanes and typhoons) Description: Aetna considers itself indirectly exposed to physical risks related to physical climate parameters -including rain, hurricanes and cyclones Potential impact:Increased operational cost Time-frame: >6 years Direct/Indirect: Indirect (supply chain) Likeli-hood: About as likely as not Magnitude of impact: Low Estimated financial implications: Unknown Aetna operations are housed predominately in leased locations At this point it is unclear whether Aetna would need to relocate offices based upon cyclones/hurricanes, whether mitigating methods would or would not be available, or what the costs associated with these would be Aetna's Business Continuity Department creates and incorporates scenarios addressing situations that would impact its operations thus allowing continued operation Mgt method: Aetna constantly evaluates its business operations and demands tailoring its real estate requirements to meet these needs Several options are available whether it be relocation, reduction (or increase) in real estate and facility needs, increasing telecommuting options, etc Aetna's Business Continuity Department addresses situations such as that would impact its operations incorporating various strategies such as re-direction of operations, identifying a need for alternative locations, etc

MetLife recognizes that every individual and business faces economic, environmental and social risks including: natural disasters, liability loss, accidents, reputation damage and interruption of business Climate change and its associated effects may amplify many of these risks, but most significantly to insurance, climate change can impact the frequency and/or severity of hurricanes, tornadoes, and hail Climate change is expected to have its largest impact on the homeowners business  MetLife is a diversified company and its homeowners business represents under 3% of the enterprises 2014 premium 

The perils that climate change may impact most significantly are hurricanes, tornadoes, and hail so losses from these perils may increase due to climate change MetLife has long recognized the possibility of catastrophe losses varying significantly from expected amounts in a given year as a result of climate change In response, the Company has historically monitored, and continues to monitor, its spread of risk monthly  The Company writes in all 50 states and the District of Columbia  The Company identifies the geographic areas that could produce the largest catastrophe losses through both the analysis of exposure concentrations and the analysis of catastrophe models  Since catastrophe modeling is not exact, the Company reviews the results from three different independent catastrophe models Each modeler employs its own staff of experts that may include scientists, climatologists, actuaries, engineers, and statisticians as well as other disciplines  The Company reviews the catastrophe model results for five different hurricane zones
 
Modeling several hurricane zones helps identify the modelers current beliefs about how climate change may differ by zone  The Company reviews both the Long Term (historical record of hurricanes) and Near Term (representing the next five years of expected activity under a warm sea surface assumption) estimates, but manages to the more conservative Near Term estimates The Company evaluates potential losses from events that cause greater damage than observed historical events (eg, 1 in 100 year, 1 in 200 year, 1 in 250 year, 1 in 500 year, 1 in 1000 year, and 1 in 2000 year events) for each of the five hurricane zones along with their impact on surplus Year over year changes in each return periods estimates provide additional insight into how the modelers view the impact of climate change Of course, other impacts are reflected in the segmented geographic and various return period analysis as well, such as new knowledge pertaining to the quality of the construction due to building code changes The Company pays close attention to the impacts on liquidity and capital needs associated with each of the return period losses mentioned above The Company also reviews the latest published articles on climate change  

The Company continually reviews the possible impact of climate change on the reinsurance market and reinsurance costs The Company purchases catastrophe reinsurance such that the Near Term net post-tax losses from events with a conservative return period are less than a pre-determined percentage of surplus The Company plans reinsurance costs out three years into the future 

Finally, the Company follows a consistent process year after year re-evaluating the multi-model results, risk concentrations, and latest climate change science

In addition to the procedures outlined above, MetLife also assesses and includes climate change in risks considered in the Companys investment portfolio and business practices  One example of this monitoring is an Event Risk Analysis that is conducted semiannually by MetLife Real Estate Investors (MREI) The analysis reveals MREIs exposure to hurricanes and windstorms in respect to the geographic concentrations of the MetLife portfolio
