Company Name: Boston Medical Center Health Plan, Inc.
text: BMC Health Plan recently announced a change to become a fully virtually workforce, with an expectation that over 90% of its staff will be working from home on a daily basis That will have a favorable impact by greatly reducing emissions related to our workforce no longer commuting to the office each day Additionally, BMC hospital is a national leader in green initiatives to make our facilities more resilient in the face of climate risk For example, our new inpatient psych facility is designed to be net zero emissions

The geographic areas considered includes all locations where our Company and its subsidiaries operate, with a focus on North America 

We consider a range of potential opportunities driven by physical climate risks, including changes in temperatures, precipitation patterns and sea levels Specifically, we consider the potential for changes in physical climate parameters to present a broader series of global public health challenges, such as those relating to (1) extreme weather events, (2) decreases in water supply, (3) heat exposure and (4) declining crop yields In the short-term, extreme weather events have been prioritized as our greatest physical risk

We also consider how changes in physical and transition risks could also influence a series of socioeconomic challenges and opportunities that would likely impact the delivery of healthcare Examples could include health and hygiene issues due to migration, malnutrition, and increases in respiratory, bronchial, water-borne and other diseases Additionally, we consider how these negative societal and environmental impacts could present opportunities where Cigna, in particular, could provide products and services to help respond to these changes in physical climate parameters across the markets we serve

Our risk assessment considers all geographic locations and markets where we operate in addition to potential new markets under evaluation Additionally, we consider global environmental and socioeconomic trends, which may impact the value of our assets in addition to revenue and costs in our target markets The criteria used to determine our priorities with regards to climate change risks and opportunities include the following factors: degree of potential regulatory, physical and other business impacts to Cigna In addition to engaging with our internal stakeholders to prioritize risks and opportunities, we also monitor the activities related to climate change risk among our key stakeholders, which include investors, corporate customers and industry peers 

For example, increasing energy efficiency at our facilities has been prioritized due to (1) cost savings and risk mitigation opportunities, (2) identified value to our stakeholders and (3) alignment with our mission and the increasingly globalized nature of our operations Based on our prioritization, we have a Strategic Sustainability Performance Plan in place that includes formal policies on energy and water consumption, and direct and indirect carbon dioxide emissions

We define risk as having a substantial financial and strategic impact using both qualitative and quantitative measures Qualitative measures consider correlations to our business model, mission 
and value chain Quantitatively, we generally consider a risk to be substantive based on a scenario where at least 1% of our net income could be impacted In 2018, this threshold was approximately $25 million

As an organization, Farmers recognizes that it is essential that we consider the impact we have on the environment, and that we create and foster a culture where all individuals are aware of opportunities to conserve energy and natural resources

We have initiatives in process that reduce our carbon footprint These include changes in the way we manage our facilities, our fleet and our travel

From an energy procurement standpoint, our goal is to purchase energy in an efficient, cost effective and environmentally responsible manner, and to establish and implement effective energy management programs In 2020, we purchased 64,088,426 kWh in Renewable Energy Credits to account for the total energy use across the Farmers real estate portfolio

Farmers Insurance has implemented an enterprise-wide carbon footprint measurement platform that includes utility, paper, fleet vehicle fuel consumption, waste, and employee travel Between 2019 and 2020, Farmers reduced electricity consumption by 2219% Heating consumption for the same period went down by 3181% Overall Facilities emissions went down by 2178% between 2019 and 2020

Farmers is committed to renewable energy sources Farmers currently has solar arrays in four additional Southwest regions ranging in size from 25 KW to 240 KW to help offset energy consumption and costs

From an operating perspective and to ensure ongoing success, Farmers completes quarterly audits of HVAC and lighting schedules to ensure systems are going into setback modes during after-hour periods at all locations where Farmers has control over HVAC and lighting systems At locations where we do not manage these systems, our local Facilities team partners with property management to ensure our spaces are conditioned and lit during occupied times only

Our primary office building in Caledonia, MI completed an LED retrofit for all interior lighting as well as added multi-stream recycling in 2020

Our Caledonia, MI and Woodland Hills, CA offices participate in composting programs and prior to the pandemic, generated approximately 15,000 lbs of organic material annually that in turns gets used in farm and garden applications across the local regions

In addition to these improvements, we have also implemented programs to remind employees to power down equipment when it is not in use Many computer monitors and desktop computers are automatically set to go into a sleep or hibernation mode after a short period of inactivity

Depending on job assignment, employees may be provided with a company fleet vehicle Since 2010, more fuel efficient vehicles have been purchased for the company fleet, midsized sedans are being used instead of full-size sedans, hybrid and electric vehicles have been added to the fleet and the overall fleet size has been reduced Between 2019 and 2020, Farmers reduced its fleet by 31%, reduced its fleet miles driven 6023%, reduced gallons consumed by fleet at 5536% or 1,396,981 gallons from calendar year 2019 to calendar year 2020 Total CO2 emissions went down by 5536%

When offices were open prior to March 2020, Farmers employees that commuted to our business locations were encouraged to use ridesharing and the use of public transportation In some locations, we provide incentives including subsidies for train passes, bus passes and vanpools, free shuttle buses from train stations and preferred carpool parking spaces In March 2020, 98% of our employee based shifted to remote work  reducing employee commute by approximately 81 million miles compared to 2019

Farmers has also installed ten (8 in Southern California and 2 in Phoenix) electric charging stations to provide an energy source for those employees who already drive electric vehicles and to also encourage more environmentally friendly vehicle use In Los Angeles, we provide a company stipend to employees for alternative travel

Telepresence technology and high-quality HD video conferencing systems in many operations have helped minimize airline travel

In addition to our focus on the reduction of emissions we have made improvements in our effort to reduce water consumption Improvements include low volume sink faucets, low volume toilets and waterless urinals Other improvements within our operations include upgrades to programmable irrigation systems and pop-up sprinkler heads, which eliminate leakage and overspray We have also transitioned to xeriscape in some locations

In 2020, we achieved our goal to reduce print for internal purposes by 80% compared to a 2015 baseline Strategies around print reduction, messaging, and a majority of employees working from home led to realizing this target Copier/printer machines in many of our locations are set for duplex (two-sided) printing and the print/copy default has been set to black and white vs color Farmers has implemented an MDS optimization program within Document Logistics, replacing multi-functional devices with more energy efficient equipment This program was put into place not only to reduce energy consumption and the impact on the environment, but to also ensure cost savings We are in the fifth year of the program and continue to reduce both the number and size of the multifunction devices (MFD) in our facilities

In 2020, we were able to reduce the current fleet from 480 to 299, a 38% decrease Replacement devices are optimized based on use and are more energy efficient We continue to work on reducing utilization of paper and office supplies across the enterprise

Virtually all employee communications are handled electronically rather than through paper As of 2011, semi-monthly statements of employee earnings and deductions have been electronically available and are no longer printed and mailed to employees Farmers employee benefit statements have also transitioned from being printed and mailed to employees homes to providing the statements electronically Improved ordering processes have lowered the volume of consumable supplies in many locations Recycling programs have been implemented for paper, plastic, cardboard and glass Printer, copier ink and toner cartridges are also recycled, as are cell phones, chargers and obsolete electronic equipment such as computers and monitors In our mail rooms, we have begun recycling and reusing packing materials for shipping

We have implemented initiatives that provide customers with environmentally friendly choices that also reduce the organizations carbon footprint For example, in some operations, mail sent to agents and customers is delivered in envelopes made of recycled material A new billing system available in some states and for some products provides increased on-line billing and payment capabilities In some states and for some products, we are working to provide customers with the option to receive electronic policy forms and notices from us, rather than paper copies Customers with these electronic policies may also have the option to receive bills, pay bills and view their billing histories online Some states prohibit the use of paperless communication with policyholders, which limits our ability to consider paperless options

Our MultiCar auto policy, available in some states, can cover multiple vehicles on one policy, thereby reducing the amount of paper customers receive and our overall carbon footprint

In 2010, Farmers built a 164,000 SF facility in Oklahoma City that was recognized by the US Green Building Council as qualifying for Core and Shell LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) certification at the silver level, and also qualified for LEED certification for the Tenant Improvement portion of the project In 2020, our Phoenix office as awarded the Platinum Green Business Certification from the Phoenix Green Business Leader and our Portland office requalified for the Green Business Leader gold certification

In some of our larger facilities: 1) during building retrofits, water bottle refilling stations are added to water fountains Plastic single-use containers are no longer provided by Farmers as of 2020; 2) programmable thermostats are in place; 3) carbon footprint studies and energy audits have been completed; 4) Energy Star equipment is purchased whenever practical; 5) cleaning hours were revised to allow for more daytime cleaning, allowing us to deactivate interior lights earlier in the evening; 6) new employees are informed of our green business practices during their initial training classes and existing employees receive regular electronic communications on various energy-related topics, keeping awareness at a high level; 7) In 2016 our large facility in Washington started a composting program as part of its waste services in the café and all kitchenettes

As of 2019, we achieved our goal of eliminating single use plastic from our internal operations by working with our vendors to replace single-use plastic materials with alternative, environmentally friendly materials All single use plastic in our onsite cafés have been replaced with an alternative material We have also updated all company ordering options to remove all single use plastic offerings, such a cutlery, plastic water bottles, etc Lastly, we implemented a k-cup recycling program in our large locations

In addition the two Print and Distribution Centers in North America have implemented several significant initiatives to mitigate impacts to the environment including: aggressive approach to deliver agent, customer and broker documents electronically versus traditional USPS mail; On-line report viewing; purchasing of envelopes and stationary manufactured with paper from trees harvested from forests that are SFI (Sustainable Forestry Initiative) certified, Print-On-Demand of agent support materials versus warehoused stored materials; digitizing as much in-bound mail as possible via an active imaging approach; implemented many initiatives improving efficiency, lowering energy consumption, actively participating in operational recycling program, consolidating operations to a two-site COE model and reducing operational waste from 4% to less than 2%

Company Name: John Hancock Life Insurance Company Of New York
text:
The following are examples of risks that climate change could pose to our company:

Regulatory risks
As a global life and health insurer and wealth and asset management company, we do not anticipate being directly impacted by climate change regulations in the near term  However, certain assets in our investment portfolios could be subject to increased regulation which may result in increased operating costs  This could include, for instance, carbon pricing regimes imposed on our oil and gas investments or energy efficiency requirements in our real estate portfolio  We monitor the regulatory environment on an ongoing basis and do not deem (potential) regulations to have a material impact on our company at this time

Physical risks
Manulifes operations and investments are diversified across many sectors and geographies  So while this may expose Manulife to the effects of an environmental event in one region, its holdings in any affected region are limited and circumscribed  Nonetheless, extreme weather events may pose operational risk to Manulife and as such, we have in place business continuity procedures and regularly perform concentration risk assessments on our operations  Any financial risks of environmental impacts are further minimized through insurance and reinsurance

Other risks
Manulifes reputation may be adversely affected if it is not perceived to be taking meaningful action to help address climate change  Changing client behavior may impact demand for certain products  As an example, large corporate tenants are increasingly seeking out more environmentally sustainable office space (see answer to Question 5 for more detail)
If climate change has a significant impact on any of our investment securities, or the economy in general, investment losses may occur

Not considered materially relevant as the Company is not a Property & Casualty insurer nor are the Companys investments in companies/industries that are considered to be at significant risk from climate change

Company Name: The Union Labor LIfe Insurance Company
text: We participate in the building managements recycling and energy usage programs and policies  In addition, in 2019, the Company changed over all lighting to LEDs and installed interior windows to increase natural light in to the main office spaces, therefore reducing our overall energy consumption  The Company also moved our data center to a shared data center, which should be more energy efficient
However, the company monitors and considers the impact of weather related events in its disaster recovery and business continuity plans

However, the Group provides access to risk management seminars and materials to educate insureds about potential causes of loss including loss resulting from climate change  

To the extent climate change-influenced events grow in materiality, the Group would likely focus on providing credits to induce certain actions by policyholders provided its rate plans were adapted to do so

As a result of climate change, the Company has undertaken to reduce exposures in severe climate prone areas, adopting new guidelines on maximum exposure within defined parameters, as well as the use of coastal underwriting guidelines Based on historical and modeling data along with our property reinsurance placement, the Company has developed exposure aggregation restrictions in high risk areas (includes both hurricane and tornado prone areas) The Company incorporates the weather exposure and corresponding reinsurance charges in our property pricing In addition to hurricane and tornado risk, the Company also considers flood zones considering acceptance of specific flood coverage b) Investment Management: Our investment manager considers internal and external factors that would affect the ability of issuers to repay debts, remain competitive and maintain a strong financial position Climate change issues, other environmental and legal scenarios are part of that consideration in analyzing industries and issuers In fact, our investment manager is a signatory to the United Nations Principles for Responsible Investments (UNPRI) group and climate change is one focus of the group 
The Companys investment manager considers regulatory, physical, litigation and competitiveness-related climate risks, among others, when assessing investments The Companys investment manager considers the implications of climate change for all of its investment classes The Companys investment manager does not use a shadow price for carbon when considering investments where carbon is currently regulated or likely to be regulated in the future The Companys investment manager does factor the physical risks of climate change in all asset classes into security analysis

Company Name: Esurance Property and Casualty Insurance Company
text:
Allstate completes a comprehensive inventory of all Scope 1, 2, and select Scope 3 emissions annually and reports the verified findings through CDP

Allstate has established an absolute emissions reduction goal aimed at reducing energy use at owned facilities to 2o% below 2007 levels by 2020 and is continuously working to identify and act on other non-energy related emissions reduction opportunities As of December 2012, Allstate has reduced Scope 1, 2, and select Scope 3 emissions by approximately 22% compared to a 2007 baseline

A sampling of projects implemented to date include installation of more efficient light fixtures, reductions in the hours lights are used, operation of sophisticated lighting controls which include daylight harvesting features and occupancy sensors, paperless solutions (eBill, ePayments, and ePolicy), real estate consolidation, improvement in fuel economy of the corporate fleet, and building material recycling In total, Allstate estimates these activities resulted in nearly 21,000 MT of CO2 emissions reductions
in 2012 (Scope 1, 2, & 3)

Projects planned for 2013 and beyond include electric vehicle charging stations at corporate office campus in Northbrook, IL To reduce the energy associated with data storage and other computing-intensive processes, Allstate has begun increasing the temperature at owned data centers, thereby reducing the overall cooling load at these facilities

The Insurance Information Institute (iii) has stated the potential for a $100 billion hurricane catastrophe year is constantly growing As such, as mentioned in question #2 above, ACUITY currently remains non-coastal to mitigate hurricane exposures ACUITY also reviews and utilizes weather patterns in order to price its products and diversify its geographic risk within the states where we operate

The company does have business continuity 
plans in place should a natural disaster or other event force the company out of its offices

In 2018, we were proud to establish science-based greenhouse gas (GHG) reduction targets that have been approved by SBTi, the leading organization in driving corporate climate action: By 2030, we will reduce our absolute scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions 36 percent from a 2010 base year 
By 2023, we will ensure that 70 percent of our suppliers by emissions establish their own science-based reduction targets for their scope 1 and 2 emissions

Significant changes in convective storm patterns, hurricanes, and droughts could impact the way in which EMC insures property exposure over time EMC monitors long-term weather patterns and geographical concentrations of risk as part of its catastrophe and exposure management processes Historical actions have been taken to reduce exposure concentrations in some catastrophe-prone areas and to limit growth in others Exposure growth is being monitored throughout the year to ensure that exposure concentrations do not unknowingly exceed established risk tolerances 

In addition to managing exposure concentrations, EMC continues to evaluate opportunities to reduce losses from catastrophic events For example, EMC has increased deductibles and changed the way deductibles apply to commercial property policies with multiple locations EMC has also made a concerted effort to monitor insured values and make sure they are sufficient for the insured risk

EMC purchases aggregate catastrophe reinsurance as a component of its overall catastrophe management strategy In addition, EMC has protected its surplus and financial position by securing per risk and facultative reinsurance treaties on larger insured properties

Along with underwriting risk, severe weather could also have an impact on EMC corporate headquarters facilities, as well as its regional branch offices around the country  EMC has a very robust disaster recovery plan in place for each branch/
department which it is prepared to employ if and when it is necessary EMC's branch office locations, which are spread throughout the country, help to minimize the risk arising from severe weather effecting operations, as offices located in non-affected areas are available to assist the impacted offices meet the demands that would be presented if a physical office location was severely impacted by storms

Centrals home office continues to reduce its carbon foot print  In November of 2009 the home office began a program to reduce electricity and natural gas consumption  From 2009 to 2012 Central reduced electric usage by 183% and natural gas usage by 225%

Because of our efforts in this area Central was recognized by the US Environmental Protection Agency as an Energy Star Building for 2011  Buildings that earn this award use a minimum of 35% less energy and generate a minimum of 35% fewer greenhouse gas emissions that similar building across the country 

In April 1, 2012 Central Insurance Companies received recognition from its electric provider, American Electric Power, for completing an energy efficiency project and reducing energy usage at it home office location in Van Wert, Ohio   

Beginning in 2003 Central embarked upon many paperless initiatives internal to our business processes and external to our independent agency channel and policyholders

AGENCY PARTNERS
In 2004 we eliminated printing and mailing all paper policy documents previously sent to agents  Agents are able to view and save policy related documents from our agent portal  We are also able to download policy information directly into various computer systems our agents use  That same year we eliminated all paper manual for our agents and our employees  That information is accessed online through our agency portal  Agents are also able to submit new applications for clients for most of our lines of business online rather than mailing those applications to us

POLICYHOLDERS
In 2008 we introduced an updated version of our policyholder portal to our market allowing policyholders 24/7 access to their insurance information  They can retrieve 2 years of policy and billing information They can pay their bill online and they can report and track a claim  69% of all premiums paid to our company are done via some form of electronic payment (EFT, E-check, debit or credit card) We introduced ebill and epolicy in 2009 and 2010 allowing policyholders to turn off paper documents  In 2011 we introduced an I-phone app of our consumer portal and in 2012 we introduced a mobile app for the Android platform  Some states have recently published plans to allow a mobile id card as valid proof of insurance; proof our actions to support a mobile platform have value to the market place and environment  To date about 25% of our Personal lines and Commercial lines policyholders access the consumer portal to interact with their insurance needs

INTERNAL PROCESSES
All underwriting and claim files are created and stored electronically  Emails and fax are seamlessly attached to electronic files without printing paper  Major vendors are required to communicate with us electronically as well  We monitor postage, paper and printing costs quarterly by employee and business unit  Each operating unit has authority to develop and implement a workflow solution that reduces paper

Lastly, fuel efficiency in our corporate fleet offerings is one of several important factors when considering our fleet vehicles  The Company continues to downsize vehicles offered  We also have begun offering 4-cylinder vehicles where appropriate

Climate risk is not addressed within the structure of CHRISTUS Health Plan CHRISTUS Health Plan is an HMO providing health products to underserved and under-represented communities Due to the nature of the organizations service lines, and the short duration of the typical health insurance contract period, the organization does not have formal policies around mitigating the risk of climate change

The Companys Home Office in New York City also has an uninterrupted power supply system and the Home Office and the National Telecommunications and Conference Center both have back-up generator systems capable of supplying power for up to 48 hours or more, depending on usage, along with vendor contracts to supply fuel for the generator systems as may be necessary  In 2015, the Company enhanced electrical cabling throughout the building and increased the availability of emergency generator power to tenants requesting access 
As a result of the Companys post-Superstorm Sandy review of its Business Continuity Plans and the reported damage incurred by neighboring facilities, the Company added improvements to its Corporate Headquarters, which included the installation of additional drains and pumps to mitigate the risk of flooding, the raising of fuel pumps for generator operations and ensuring redundant electrical circuits to provide power from emergency generators 
The post-Superstorm Sandy review also identified a concern with the location of the Companys designated Recovery Center for its mainframe applications in New Jersey  The area in which the Recovery Center is located was heavily flooded, although the Recovery Center itself was not flooded nor its operations interrupted  After careful analysis, the Company determined that there was a risk that the Companys Home Office, its National Telecommunications and Conference Center and its designated Recovery Center could be affected by the same storm or incident, such as a wide-spread power outage and not available for an extended period of time  Given the risk, the Company determined that it would be prudent to move its recovery center to a facility operated by the same vendor that is located in Arizona, which is on the Western Power Grid  In January 2015, the Company completed the successful changeover from its prior mainframe disaster recovery site to it new site in Arizona  Moving the Recovery Center to Arizona mitigates the risk that the Home Office the National Telecommunications and Conference Center and the designated Recovery Center would be affected by the same storm or incident
The Company conducts at least two disaster recovery tests during the year  The tests conducted since the relocation of the Recovery Center to Arizona have been successful

Columbia Insurance Groups core values states, We believe in being responsible corporate citizens  We live out that value in our continued dedication to the assessment, reduction and/or mitigation of emissions in our operations where possible and appropriate

We continue to approach the problem of emissions and their impact on the environment in a fluid manner, in order to continually evaluate our organization and search for improvements in our plans  Some components of our plan include:

	We manage fuel consumption by gradually replacing our fleet of 6-cylinder company vehicles with more efficient 4-cylinder models  The majority of our fleet has now been replaced

	We facilitate fuel efficiency by requiring employees to use company vehicles whenever possible when travel is required  This ensures that fuel-efficient vehicles are being used for company business

	We encourage fuel economy by assisting employees interested in carpooling or sharing rides in connecting with other like-minded employees

	We continue to decrease waste by reducing the amount of paper used in our operations by creating and managing underwriting and claims files electronically

	We reduce unnecessary waste for others by encouraging our agency partners to create, submit and maintain documents in an environmentally-friendly manner via submitting information and applications electronically or through an online portal maintained by Columbia Insurance Group

	We encourage green actions by providing our policyholders with online options for bill payment

	We conduct environmental audits of our facilities to identify areas for improvement  For example, we recently began a Lighting Audit, with a plan to replace fluorescent bulbs with more energy efficient LED bulbs  

	We work to reduce energy consumption by continuing the process of replacing our 
existing HVAC units with more energy efficient units

	We have continued our efforts to prevent energy waste by continuing to partially replace the roof of our Home Office building, creating a more energy-efficient environment

In September 2018,
the Company became the first US insurer to publicly commit never to invest in coal and
other fossil fuels, and published and distributed this statement to its customers and the
media (See https://wwwlemonadecom/blog/divest_coal/)
Lemonade also called on its peers in the industry to join them and divest from these
polluters, and Lemonade leadership has frequently spoken about it in industry conferences,
climate activists and NGOs, and with the press
As a Certified B-Corp, and member of the B-Corp Climate Collective, Lemonade has
received high scores on the B-Corp assessment, and was recertified in 2019 In the
Environmental Impact Area, B-Corp evaluated the Company's overall environmental
stewardship, including how the Company manages general environmental impacts like
climate, water use and sustainability, and impacts on land and life
In addition, Lemonade has partnered with multiple climate-focused nonprofits through its
Giveback program, from prominent global organizations such as 350org to national ones
such as American Forests (planting 218,522 trees to date) and local California charities
such as Save The Bay, allowing Lemonade customers to support research on the impacts of
climate change, and awareness and activism for the environment through their insurance
policy
In the five year record of the annual Lemonade Giveback, 17 climate organizations have
received more than $450,000 from the Lemonade community The Company has also
worked directly with many of these organizations to educate and engage customers,
shareholders, employees, and other stakeholders about the risks of climate change

Climate change risk currently ranks lower on the risk spectrum when compared to liquidity, durations, interest rate, and asset class

Furthermore from an investment portfolio standpoint we believe any risks or opportunities associated with climate change, such as carbon and water restrictions, are generally priced into the cost of the investment through the market; any potential arbitrage opportunities would have imbedded investment risk which we believe to be inappropriate for us to take given our overall risk tolerance profile

Given the nature of our underwritten liability we do not currently assess the correlation between climate risks our underwriting and investments Due to the relative short-tailed liability associated with the health underwriting risk profile we believe it is not as critical as it would be for a life company, or P&C company, to structure our portfolio with a similar duration

Company Name: Palisades Property and Casualty Insurance Company
text: For example, our reinsurance program is structured to account for climate change and the risks to insureds associated with it  In addition, the Companys assets are protected, and disaster recovery and business continuity plans are in place across our departments and companies, to enable us to fail over critical IT systems and servers from our co-location data centers, to recover key communications and network infrastructure, and to resume business operations as quickly as possible in case severe weather or other events disrupt business as usual

Company Name: Tower Insurance Company of New York
text:
We minimize travel through extensive use of teleconferencing 
2	Most employees work in urban areas including company headquarters in lower Manhattan  The majority of employees commuting to Manhattan take public transportation to work
3	We have recycling programs in every office
4	Tower does not print out paper copies of policies for agents and instead makes them available electronically
5	E-delivery:  We are engaged in a campaign which encourages policyholders to go paperless and to have documents delivered electronically
6	E-payments:  Policyholders are encouraged to pay insurance bills electronically, either through the Tower website or EFT
If we can find any specific areas that we can actively participate in to assess, reduce, or mitigate the emission, we will build up the plans

However, as the PMIC Risk Management footprint is developed, Climate change-related risks and their respective assessment will be given consideration as part of the developing Risk Management strategies

Although not specifically referencing individual criteria, per se, in our investment policy, Old Republic considers sound business judgments to include that consideration The Old Republic group of companies, as multi-line commercial liability insurers, primarily involved in workers compensation and vehicle liability insurance; as a mortgage guaranty insurer; and as a title insurer does not believe it has a material climate change risk with respect to underwriting operations Almost all of Old Republics underwriting risk is subject to re-pricing on an annual basis To the extent that climate change may impact the number and severity of losses of Old Republics policyholders, that impact would likely be long-term in nature, as one of several factors influencing inflation Any impact of climate change on policyholder losses would implicitly be considered in Old Republics normal pricing & underwriting process, without any meaningful need to explicitly identify climate change as the root cause of that specific change Consequently, Old Republic believes that climate change is implicitly addressed within its normal individual risk selection and more global risk management process 

A large portion of Old Republics investment portfolio consists of fixed rate income investments and management has, in a general manner, considered climate risk with respect to investment management as an element of risk in its sound business judgmen

The impact of climate change is one of the many risks that are considered in investment decisions and we continue to monitor developments regarding climate change

MetLife recognizes the importance of investing in renewable energy ventures that have a positive impact on the environment  MetLife has invested approximately $30 billion in renewable energy projects and evaluates opportunities to invest as advances in technology make these alternative energy sources attractive investments
MetLife Real Estate Investments (REI) has a broad based sustainability strategy covering MetLifes existing real estate equity portfolio, new development projects, mortgage investments and real estate funds REIs strategy centers on the EPAs Energy Star program and US Green Building Councils Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) standards REI has equity stakes in 25 LEED certified properties with a market value of $55 billion (as of 12/31/12)

Climate change regulations can pose risks to the operations and financial performance of issuers across a broad array of sectors and subsectors, including but not limited to utilities, energy, automotive, agriculture, materials, consumer and industrial manufacturing, real estate, and insurance  Industries which are most at risk from potential burdensome regulations in the near-term are those that negatively affect air and resource quality  Certain industries are exposed to additional risks from climate change, including changes in energy demand for heating and cooling, peak hydrocarbon demand, weather-driven variability in agricultural production and water availability, rising sea levels, and extreme weather events

We have considered climate change risks for all asset classes and continue to closely monitor and evaluate industry trends, regulations, and long-term risks associated with climate change for all of our holdings 
The Companies have adapted their investment strategy to account for issuer-specific risks associated with climate change and climate change regulations  As an example, utility investments are evaluated based upon their generation mix and carbon intensity  Energy investments are made with consideration for potential greenhouse gas emissions regulations and downside risks to global oil demand

Auto related investments are contemplated with consideration for the ongoing transition to hybrid and electric vehicles  Investment in property and casualty insurers are evaluated in light of their environmental risk management practices  Environmental stewardship, geographical diversification, and long-term sustainability are key considerations for all new investments and the Companies continue to monitor and assess risks driven by climate change and related regulatory interventions

Climate change is one risk that would be considered
Cignas general account investment portfolio consists predominately of fixed-income assets While the primary risks Cigna undertakes are credit related, climate change can play a role in our evaluation of the creditworthiness of specific issuers and industries Risk factors may include:
	Changes in regulatory requirements (eg, emissions controls);
	Changes in supply/demand for fuel (eg, oil, natural gas);
	Developments in renewable energy sources; and
	Effects of extreme weather events on industries and issuers
Climate change may impact certain investments For example, commercial real estate may become less desirable due to climate change factors such as global warming, rising sea levels or hurricane activity This could adversely affect a property's value as collateral for a commercial mortgage loan Climate changes can influence the inflation outlook and/or creditworthiness of specific emerging market issuers (eg a reduction in rainfall can cause food prices to rise, increasing inflation)

Our risk management and loss prevention programs provide policyholders with strategies for efficiency and safe driving which have the effect of reducing emissions Safe driving includes precision driving practices (slow acceleration, limiting maximum speed and speeding) that reduce the volume of fossil fuels consumed Our safety newsletters have included topics on fuel saving and safety strategies including reducing speed, braking, increasing follow distance, etc We also encourage the use of telematics which measure fuel consumption, mileage, and driver behavior to increase MPGs

The Health Alliance Compliance Officer and Information Security Officer are currently charged with augmenting the climate change related risks  In addition, this team is consistently identifying techniques to mature our internal risk assessment and management process
The organization however does promote healthy and active communities through a bike share program and safe street/walking

However, climate change is one of many risks considered in analysis of current and potential investments The operating environment for both types is constantly evolving, introducing new risks from a financial, regulatory, competitive and environmental perspective, among others MassMutual regularly monitors the investment portfolio for changes to the relative value of holdings against current and prospective investments, with the noted risks (among others) contributing to relative valuations and decisions regarding portfolio composition MassMutual prefers to remain flexible regarding its future investments, and the company makes investment decisions in the best interests of its policyowners A variety of factors support these decisions, of which climate change may or may not play a role As a regular course of business, the company monitors debt and equity portfolios to assure portfolio diversification relative to managing both environmental and seismic risk Periodic adjustments to the portfolio help maintain portfolio diversification For new investments, the investment management policy governs investment limits by metropolitan statistical area and other risk thresholds such as amount of seismic exposure, size of the investment and other diversification measures As part of the companys overall enterprise risk management policy, these limits are regularly reviewed in addition to a quarterly review of concentration/diversifications measures

Company Name: NY Life Insurance Company of Arizona
text: Potential threats resulting from climate change are managed within the existing risk management framework We are not a property-casualty insurer with the potential for material adverse claims risk arising from violent weather disruption

The Information provided in this Survey describes activities that occur at the level of the FNTG Group of Insurers' ultimate controlling parent, Fidelity National Financial (FNF or "the Company") It is at the FNF-level that the FNTG Group of Insurers' risk appetite is determined, and the earning, capital, liquidity, operations and reputation of the FNTG Group of Insurers are overseen collectively, and at which the supervision of those factors are coordinated and exercised
The Company has implemented a number of sustainability initiatives throughout its corporate offices and operations aimed at reducing consumption or emissions, including our reuse and recycle program, energy efficiency and conservation projects, and Digital Strategy Initiative 
Our recent efforts to reduce our energy and water consumption include: the use of Energy Star compliant technology at the majority of our data centers, faucet flow restrictors in our breakrooms and restrooms and soil-moisture managed irrigation systems on our corporate campus; the replacement of aging equipment with energy efficient alternatives; and retrofitting lighting in our corporate campus and parking garages with light emitting diode (LED) bulbs, compact fluorescent lamps (CFLs) and motion sensors Through these and other conservation efforts, over the period of just one year (2018-2019), FNF has reduced its electricity expenditure by 4%,or approximately 236,000 kilowatt hours
 Aside from its corporate office, the Company does not own or control any physical facility in which it operates  Where possible, we maintain leases in LEED® certified buildings, which are recognized for their energy efficiency, meeting stringent standards as determined by the US Green Building Council 
The Companys Digital Strategy Initiative promotes sustainability through paperless technology programs within its corporate and direct operations throughout the United States Where we do produce waste in our operations, we seek to dispose of that waste in an environmentally-responsible manner Our waste reduction efforts include:  the use of technology tools such as dual monitors to enhance work capabilities and eliminate printing, use of eSteward© certified vendors to recycle or repurpose equipment, elimination of single-use water bottles in favor of filtered water dispensers, and incorporation of recycling programs at all of our locations
We have not identified any significant risks posed by our business to the environment Our determination that there are no environmental risks posed by our operations that would have a substantive impact on the environment is consistent with and supported by the Sustainability Accounting Standards Board Materiality Map, which indicates that environmental risks are generally not financially material for companies within the Insurance sector of the Financial Services industry, such as FNF

Company Name: Farmers Mutual Hail Ins. Co. of Iowa
text:
The very nature of our business (crop insurance) is directly connected to not just climate change, but weather in general, geography, and geology The crop risks we insure are affected by these factors annually, thus a drought year, or an above average rainy summer are not unusual Obviously, if there were to be a number of years consecutively where there were above average moisture levels, this would have an effect on our business We do not view this as climate change however, and instead simply believe it to be the nature of the business of insuring agriculture

Regarding climate change and any investment decisions we make on behalf of the companys mutual policyholders, any such decision is made based on sound business judgment after diligent research and review The choice to invest is based upon the good faith belief that doing so is the best thing for the company and its owners (the policyholders) We take this fiduciary obligation seriously and this is what motivates us Climate change may affect what is worth investing in, but the decision is always centered on what is best for the company and the policyholders

We are continually identifying ways to operate each office more
efficiently to reduce our environmental impact The changes in the number and severity of
natural catastrophes create a risk to our organization We continuously perform stress
tests utilizing various natural catastrophe events The purpose of performing these tests
is to evaluate the financial impact should significant catastrophes occur These tests
also evaluate whether modeled exposure is within the established risk tolerance to the
natural catastrophe guidelines We use the latest version of RMS Risklink to model our
exposure

We use electronic document distribution for our employee and member communications We encourage electronic filing of documents in an effort to reduce paper We offer a limited number of employees the option to work from home anywhere from 1 to 5 days a week, saving natural resources and reducing our carbon footprint We started processing EFTs instead of paper checks as a source of payment to vendors, reducing the use of natural resources to print and deliver paper checks
This will be something we will evaluate in the future

As a company, we continue to assess and reduce emissions in operations while maintaining expected levels of customer service  As a service organization, our carbon footprint is primarily real estate utilities energy use, business travel and company fleet vehicles
Nearly a decade ago, we embarked on an ambitious journey to maximize the use of our office space; invest in building automation that adjusts heating, cooling, and lighting based on occupancy; and replace building infrastructure with more energy-efficient equipment  Through these and other efforts, over the past 12 years, weve lowered carbon emissions per policies in force (PIFs) by 61 percent This represents an additional 3 percent reduction from the previous year, and keeps us on track on the commitment to reduce by an additional 10 percent by 2022
To accomplish this goal, we will continue to invest in facilities, equipment, and company vehicles that are increasingly energy-and fuel-efficient  All these actions support a goal to reduce carbon emissions, while also reducing the costs that our customers ultimately bear

Climate risk is addressed through our severe weather response plan Having experienced significant weather events in the past, we believe the company has sufficient Property and Casualty insurance to address the following costs associated with such events: 
1	3rd Party Liability: property damage or bodily injury to visitors/invitees, etc
2	1st Party asset damage and Business Interruption (Business Income and Extra Expense) insurance
ii	Furthermore, the company has disaster recovery / business continuity plans to ensure business continuity in the event of such events 
iii	The company investment policy does not specifically address climate change issues However, the companys investment policy relies solely on its investment guidelines The company investment guidelines provide limitations based on credit quality, duration, single issuer and sector for investments in fixed income securities Since the portfolio is well diversified, we believe the impact of climate changes, if any, would be very limited

Company Name: Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Rhode Island
text: During our annual risk assessment process, climate change has not risen to the enterprise risk level

In the majority of instances our policies are both crop related (and thus modeled based on actual history), or are not insurance risks based on hurricane modeling (hurricane modeling does involve more climate related science) Modeling based on loss cost history remains our focus

We recently had a leading expert in the field of climate change meet with our Board of Directors and executives to discuss the latest research and the potential risks facing the property and casualty industry

We have several communications with our independent agents and policyholders about disaster safety and planning and potential loss prevention or mitigation opportunities, the increase in severe weather and its impact on our business  We have discussed the strategies the company is employing to mitigate risk and lessen the impact of climate change to our financial condition

Arbella is a member of NAMIC who is an advocate for stronger, safer buildings for Americans NAMIC supports the BuildStrong Coalition which believes that safer building codes can save lives and reduce loss, especially from severe weather events NAMIC supports state and federal legislation to encourage the adoption and enforcement of strong building codes NAMIC and the BuildStrong Coalition support the creation of a separate, federal financial incentive for states that adopt and enforce statewide building codes 
Arbella has seats on the Massachusetts Property Insurance Underwriting Association (MPIUA) Board, Underwriting Committee and Investment Committee where it monitors key initiatives impacting the MPIUA and marketplace Participation additionally allows Arbella to partner with the MPIUA on mitigation and regulatory initiatives

In June 2014, Arbellas CEO, John Donohue, joined Boston Massachusetts Green Ribbon Commission, a group of Bostons top executives and community leaders tasked with providing advice and counsel to the City of Boston on the design and implementation of its Climate Action Plan  Arbella expects to be an active participant in working with the Green Ribbon Commission as it works with the City of Boston, an area where many of Arbellas policyholders live and work, to build resiliency in the city and prepare for climate change
General risk assessment is an ongoing function
Oour investments are in line with NAIC guidelines for our line of business

We engage with policy makers at international and national levels, business leaders in the insurance industry and other sectors, multilateral organizations, NGOs, and others

Much of the work Swiss Re does at the policy-maker level around the globe on the climate change topic aims to encourage a better understanding of the need for action as well as how the insurance industry can contribute from the perspective of a provider of risk transfer, a risk manager and as an investor Swiss Re generally works to support actions to help move the debate in the right direction rather than giving support for specific pieces of legislation For example, in Europe, we have continued to raise awareness of the important role insurers play in mitigating climate risk through different interactions with policy makers This includes speaking at industry conferences (Insurance Europe and the ABI), presenting at the European Commissions DG Climate Actions working group on Climate Adaptation and engaging bilaterally with the European Commission and national governments In the US, we have maintained regular dialogue with the National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC), principally on climate change and natural catastrophes In Switzerland, we have provided a committee member to the OcCC (Organe consultatif sur les changements climatiques), an advisory body on climate change set up by the Swiss Federal Administration

Memberships of organisations such as The Climate Group allow for periodic dialogues on climate-related topics, (predominantly resilience and risk transfer themes) with regional, national and state governments which are also members At the UN climate summit in September 2014, Swiss Re pledged its financial capacity as well as its expertise to help nations increase their climate resilience through the following commitment: "By the year 2020, Swiss Re commits to having advised 50 sovereigns and sub-sovereigns on climate risk resilience, and to have offered them protection of USD 10bn against climate related risks": wwwswissrecom/rethinking/climate_and_natural_disaster_risk/Swiss_Re_at_UN_Climate_Summithtml

In 2015, Swiss Re partnered with Standard & Poor's in a special project to quantify the impact of natural catastrophes and climate change on sovereign ratings Based on a sample of 38 countries, our simulations indicate that natural disasters (earthquakes, tropical storms, floods and winter storms) of a severity that is likely to occur once every 250 years can indeed weaken the affected sovereign's rating by up to 15 notches The study also finds that the potential effect of climate change on their ratings can be significantly reduced by catastrophe insurance  This study is aligned to more than one aspect of our business as it informs countries about their exposure to extreme weather It also helps inform the private sector in these countries about the importance of climate change adaptation 

Swiss Re regularly publishes on weather and climate related topics and supports the publication of reports by external organizations  Swiss Re also provided research and expertise for the COP21 Climate Change Conference in Paris in December 2015

Swiss Re continues to share our data on the potential impact of major natural catastrophe events on cities through a number of publications Following on from last years publication Mind the risk: a global ranking of cities under threat from natural disasters, we extended our Risky Cities series in 2015, providing more detailed data for Istanbul and Bangkok These studies are publicly available on our website (http://wwwswissrecom/rethinking/climate_and_natural_disaster_risk/)

However, the Company will continue to identify and monitor investment and insurance risks (ie morbidity and mortality risks) as impacted by climate change through its existing enterprise risk management process
See Question Three

Company Name: Interinsurance Exhcnage of the Automobile Club
text:
 Green Coverage provides a limit of up to $25,000 for the additional cost to repair or replace certain classes of property that are damaged or destroyed with equivalent property that meets environmentally responsible and energy efficient standards This coverage could apply to appliances, lighting fixtures and bulbs, windows, doors and skylights, roofing products, insulation, and heating and ventilation fans

The Exchange has also encouraged our policyholders to pay online to reduce paper mailing, reducing waste and carbon emissions 

The Exchange was the first carrier to receive approval from the California Department of Insurance to introduce a Verified Mileage program, providing lower premiums for policyholders who confirm the number of miles they drive annually by providing odometer readings We have since implemented this program in several other markets, including Texas, Missouri, and Illinois This voluntary program provides an incentive in the form of lower insurance premiums for drivers to reduce their carbon footprint by driving less

Additionally, the Exchanges affiliation with the Auto Club means that there are number of other steps taken to engage key constituencies 

The Auto Club both provides information to the public and advocates for public policies and appropriate funding related to transportation, automobile use, fuels and propulsion systems, fuel efficiency, emissions, and climate change We publicize these issues and our efforts in Auto Club publications (eg Westways and Journey magazines) distributed to about half of all households in our Southern California service area (and members in other states as well) Our regular articles on these topics are intended to increase our members awareness of climate change, environmental, transportation, automotive, and related topics The following articles are some examples:

- Fun on Electric Bikes  Nov/Dec 2018 
- A Guide to Your EPA Window Sticker  March/April 2019
- Green Car Guide  May 2019 

The Automotive Research Center (ARC) develops and distributes materials educating members on how to conserve fuel in the way they drive, maintain, and operate their vehicles The ARC distributes the annual AAA National brochure The Gas Watchers Guide which provides information for motorists about how to use less fuel This brochure is distributed to AAA Branches, including locations in CA, TX, MO, IL, NM, HI, AL, KY, OH, PA, ME, NH, and VT as well as on AAAcom

The ARC published the inaugural Green Car Guide in 2010, and it is now an annual publication and available nationwide These materials are distributed through our AAA Branches, and available on our Website Members can also use a searchable website database at AAAcom/greencar to easily find information on the green vehicles that we were tested The results of the Green Car Guide tests are also announced through the media to reach a wider audience 

Starting in 2018, the ARC, in partnership with AAA National, regularly tests vehicles for fuel economy and emissions The results are compared with the fuel economy and emissions ratings for these vehicles to determine if there are any discrepancies In addition, the ARC has developed its own drive-cycles for use on the dyno, based on real-world driving, in order to further study the fuel economy and emissions of these vehicles

The following resources are available online and provide more information on the Auto Club's support for balanced, safe, environmentally sound, and responsible transportation improvements, and for the wise and effective use of taxes and fees paid by motorists and others for transportation projects and services

- Auto Club in the Community resources and information on transportation and traffic safety advocacy and environment and automotive research and developments  http://wwwcalifaaacom/home/about/community-and-safetyhtml
- Mobility 21 (a Southern California coalition we co-founded and help lead to promote mobility, public transit, and road improvements)  http://wwwmobility21com
- Sharing the Road (a guide to safe bicycling in California)  http://c1539092r92cf0rackcdncom/SharingTheRoadpdf

In our Midwest markets, the Auto Club provides information to the public and its members on public policies relating to a wide range of public issues including the environment Member publications, including the Midwest Traveler and Southern Traveler magazines, offer tips on fuel savings, advice on fuel efficient vehicles, alternative forms of transportation, battery recycling, and adequate funding for all modes of transportation Printed material on a host of environmental subjects is available at Auto Club branch offices and public displays

Within the structure of CHRISTUS Health Plan climate risk is not addressed CHRISTUS Health Plan is an HMO providing health products to underserved and under-represented communities Due to the nature of the organizations service lines, and the short duration of the typical health insurance contract period, the organization does not have formal policies around mitigating the risk of climate change

Company Name: Kaiser Foundation Health Plan of Washington Options
text: KPs current and planned efforts to reduce its overall greenhouse gas emissions include energy conservation initiatives as well as large-scale investments in renewable energy sources and the purchase of carbon offsets For example, in the State of Washington, KP has a Power Purchase Agreement with Puget Sound Energy that, starting in 2021, supplies 100% of its yearly electricity needs from wind energy KP continuously conducts baseline and performance measurements for energy consumption and other sources of greenhouse gas emissions across its facilities and activities under its operational control These include clinical buildings where health care is delivered as well as non-clinical buildings (for activities such as administration and data storage) and fleet vehicle operations KP annually measures and reports its greenhouse gas emissions based on the General Reporting Protocol of The Climate Registry, a nonprofit collaboration among North American states, provinces, territories and Native Sovereign Nations that sets standards to calculate, verify and publicly report greenhouse gas emissions

Company Name: KAISER FOUND HLTH PLAN OF WA OPTIONS
text: One way that KP may be able to regularly reassess climate change related risks over time is through health research carried out by the organization In 2005, Kaiser Permanente launched a program aimed at building one of the largest and most comprehensive resources in the United States for research on the influence of both inherited and environmental factors on peoples health The databank created through this program, now called the Kaiser Permanente Research Bank, has the ambitious goal of recruiting 500,000 Kaiser Permanente adult members to share health information and a small blood sample for research The Research Bank is conducting scientific studies that are examining the role of genes and environment in conditions as varied as diabetes, cancer, bipolar disorder, heart disease, asthma, glaucoma, multiple sclerosis, and migraine  among many others DNA samples are used to produce genotypic markers on the whole genomes of Research Bank participants, making it possible to study the role of genes in many different diseases and conditions KP investigators and collaborating scientists can conduct research to understand genetic and environmental influences  including weather and climate influences  on disease susceptibility, the course of disease, and response to treatment; as well as to translate these findings into improvements in medical care and public health By studying data pulled from Kaiser Permanente Research Bank participants' health surveys, electronic health records and DNA samples, researchers are now looking for new ways to diagnose, treat and prevent certain diseases

The policy is in place to protect the integrity of data, availability of data, and critical business systems, and to minimize the impact on operations

Ohio National Life Assurance Company does not have a formal evaluation policy measuring the financial implications of climate change related to risk management decisions, however the impact of climate change is considered as a risk factor in a variety of corporate decisions made

KPs current and planned efforts to reduce its overall greenhouse gas emissions include energy conservation initiatives as well as large-scale investments in clean and renewable energy sources For example, in the State of Washington, KP has a Power Purchase Agreement with Puget Sound Energy that, starting in 2021, will contribute to supplying 100% of its yearly electricity needs from wind energy KP continuously conducts baseline and performance measurements for energy consumption and other sources of greenhouse gas emissions across its facilities and activities under its operational control These include clinical buildings where health care is delivered as well as non-clinical buildings (for activities such as administration and data storage) and fleet vehicle operations KP annually measures and reports its greenhouse gas emissions based on the General Reporting Protocol of The Climate Registry, a nonprofit collaboration among North American states, provinces, territories and Native Sovereign Nations that sets standards to calculate, verify and publicly report greenhouse gas emissionsKP publishes detailed summaries of its programs on its web site: wwwkporg/green

Climate change risk currently ranks lower on the risk spectrum when compared to liquidity, durations, interest rate, and asset class
Furthermore from an investment portfolio standpoint we believe any risks or opportunities associated with climate change, such as carbon and water restrictions, are generally priced into the cost of the investment through the market; any potential arbitrage opportunities would have imbedded investment risk which we believe to be inappropriate for us to take given our overall risk tolerance profile
Given the nature of our underwritten liability we do not currently assess the correlation between climate risks our underwriting and investments Due to the relative short-tailed liability associated with the health underwriting risk profile we believe it is not as critical as it would be for a life company, or P&C company, to structure our portfolio with a similar duration
Medica does have an investment policy to mitigate investment risks, rooted in diversification of their portfolio and in accordance with NAIC and State guidelines

The company continuously evaluates the portfolio to ensure it meets our objective of strengthening our capital position and does not subject us to unacceptable risk

The company has not altered its investment strategy as it believes it has a sound investment policy that provides for a conservative and diversified portfolio
In connection with development of Global Atlantics firmwide Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) Framework, Global Atlantic will seek to improve its commitments to operational sustainability

Rather, the Companys investment objectives are: (a) to invest on a long term basis in accordance with applicable insurance regulatory guidelines; and (b) to ensure preservation of invested capital for policyholder protection, always providing sufficient liquidity for the payment of claims and other policy obligations Investment guidelines require all investments to be made using the long-term value of investing approach by investing in securities of companies and other entities at prices below their underlying long-term values to protect the Companys capital from loss and earn income over time and provide operating income as needed 

The Company has considered the impact of climate change on its investment portfolio The Company has approximately 1% of the Companys total investment portfolio in the energy sector Majority of the equity invested in the energy sector is held in a company that provides state of the art technology and industry-leading expertise to provide utility and industrial customers with fuel-efficient turnkey plants that are mobile, customizable and scalable Approximately 356% of the Companys total investment portfolio is in the form of municipal revenue bonds that were issued by townships/cities/counties that are associated with water & power, water supply or sewer Less than 1% of the Companys total  investment portfolio is in real estate investments

Awareness, measurement and ongoing monitoring of these risks will help ensure that PPCI will have sufficient resources to pay the claims of its policyholders and to control the magnitude of its climate-exposed insurance risks PPIC has identified geographic areas that are more susceptible to extreme weather-related events through modeling and analysis of historical exposure and loss activity This includes areas subject to fires, hurricanes, flooding, severe thunderstorms and tornadoes
Climate risk is considered during discussions of emerging risks amongst RLI executives conducted on a periodic basis, and may result in specific actions in the future as necessary and feasible

Guy Carpenter examines the book of business on an annual basis using catastrophe modeling software  This modeling incorporates single occurrence events, as well as the risks of multiple events within one calendar year  As a result of this risk of multiple events, ACIA purchases aggregate and catastrophe reinsurance to protect its surplus  Frequent storms affecting the ACIA policyholder footprint would create the potential for reinsurance rates to rise  

Because of the geographic distribution of policyholders, ACIA is not subject to large risk from changes in tropical or coastal storm patterns, frequency or severity

While ACIA does not directly tie climate change to liquidity and capital needs, it performs stress testing which imposes large storms on the book of business, and also has a liquidity stress scenario which includes temporary reinsurer inability to pay


The company also maintains a line of credit from the Federal Home Loan Bank which serves as a liquidity backstop

However, the company does contain or limit Source 1 (direct) and Source 2 (electricity indirect) emissions to the extent possible by reducing boiler, furnace and owned vehicle emissions as well as purchased electricity emissions  Examples of this include: 1) in 2003, the companys newly constructed addition to its corporate headquarters was designed to be energy efficient; 2) lighting throughout the building has been replaced with energy efficient products 3) the companys fleet vehicles for field employees are replaced on a recurring basis with energy efficient vehicles; 4) ACUITY has followed a recycling program for many years  recycling as many materials as possible (paper, aluminum, plastics, toner cartridges etc) 5)  Within our data centers, ACUITY uses hot/cold aisles to reduce the level of air conditioning required;  6) ACUITY utilizes computer technology throughout the company to bring added efficiency to our operations  As a result of this initiative, ACUITYs  policy and claims processing is paperless Millions of pages of paper have been saved over the past 9 years through automation In one year alone, a project for an online agency log saved approximately 17 million pieces of paper annually as agency paper copies of personal declarations and lapse notices were made available electronically  ACUITY created an interactive agency bill statement for agents use on-line to eliminate paper and to encourage more timely and detailed payments All agents are required to use the on-line version of the statement; the paper copies were eliminated to increase efficiency for all parties and reduce the use of paper Finally, when an agent sold or renewed a policy, that agent would receive a paper copy of the policy for his or her records ACUITY has now ceased sending paper copies of policies to our agents and requires that all agents receive this information electronically  This process will save millions of pages of paper each year

to ensure proper risk diversification We do not offer flood coverage to our policyholders, but we do offer fire following coverage, backup of sewer/drain coverage, terrorism coverage, etc so close monitoring of risk aggregations is imperative to protecting the company and its policyholders

Flood maps for much of the NY and NJ areas have been proven to be out of date and inaccurate due to changes in shoreline due to higher seas Storm surge which caused significant damage is being refactored into every modeling tool as a result of how much damage was caused by Sandy In addition, many companies are forced to revisit their policy and coverage wording regarding storm surge vs flooding 

Regarding catastrophic models being used to conduct stress tests as a result of climate change most of that work will first have to be done by the modeling vendors themselves The majority of property insurance companies use the models out of the box and unless capabilities are built in to the product it is unlikely that we would attempt to make any changes ourselves Our actuarial team reviews claims in conjunction with our underwriting and claims staff every quarter In the event that this review should ever determine that there is a need to increase recognition of the potential loss related to a climate change event beyond our existing controls then it would come from this group

PCS may be indirectly affected if the issuer of a bond investment or a company in which we hold an equity investment is impacted by climate change to the extent that the value of our investment is impaired PCS has established a diversified portfolio of bonds and equities and monitors risks and impairments to its investment portfolio on an ongoing basis with the assistance of its investment advisors As mentioned above, PacificSource has established a Sustainability Committee, which helps PacificSource strive for ways to reduce its carbon footprint

ISMIE has a comprehensive listing of risks to the business that is analyzed and reviewed on a regular basis ISMIE has a documented impact analysis for each risk considered and the controls in place to mitigate the risks ISMIE has a comprehensive Business Continuity Plan to address risks posed to the offices due to severe weather events

Additionally, the management of the financial and legal risks related to climate change is very much a consideration in the companys underwriting practices, particularly in our property and casualty lines The company considers the factors of climate risk to mitigate concentration exposures; supports our policyholders with education, safety, training and sustainability assistance; and provides immediate coverage and environmental cleanup for those impacted by adverse events
RNA's products are sold through independent agents and, given the small real estate footprint, it's unlikely that the organization produces significant emissions from its operations

The Enterprise Risk and Return Council ("ERRC") is Allstate's senior risk management committee and includes the CEO, business unit presidents, enterprise and business unit chief risk officers and chief financial officers, general counsel, and treasurer The ERRC convenes monthly to assess and manage risks and opportunities, including topics related to climate change, which may impact the company

In addition, Allstate's Sustainability Leadership Committee, composed of officers and senior staff from across the company, meets on a quarterly basis in order to guide environmental efforts from an enterprise wide perspective, build alignment, create momentum for Allstate's heightened sustainability efforts, and identify opportunities associated with environmental responsibility and climate change Climate change is a topic evaluated by the ERRC The Sustainability Leadership Committee is responsible for managing climate change strategy for the company The ERRC convenes monthly to discuss key topics, strategies and actions regarding Allstate's significant risks, including those risks affected by climate and other factors The ERRC focuses on identifying and capturing enterprise portfolio risk and reward opportunities, which may include topics such as climate risk Additionally, an Enterprise Risk and Return Dashboard Report is prepared quarterly for the Audit Committee and the Board of Directors; this report allows the Board and the Audit Committee to compare risk exposure with the company's enterprise action plan targets by capturing key information and metrics on material issues, such as catastrophic and severe weather events, quarterly auto and property insurance underwriting results, business continuity, disaster recovery plans, and investment concentrations The Enterprise Risk and Return Management Dashboard Report captures climate-related risks such as catastrophic weather events and includes metrics like quarterly auto and property insurance underwriting results, nationwide business continuity, status of disaster recovery plans, and investment concentrations Statements on climate policy are published annually as part of the corporate responsibility report and annual CDP disclosure

On a whole our insurance operations are office based and do not produce significant emissions, as we are, as a company committed to reducing our carbon footprint  We have taken initiatives that have the net effect of reducing environmental impact such as:
1	Recycling paper;
2	Increased utilization of electronic processing platform, to include electronic documents Using agent portals with E-pay and paperless pay stubs; and 
3	E-fax, E-scanning and scanning paper files into electronic databases

Additionally, we follow industry standard and take prudent measures with respect to our IT operations, which have a direct impact on our emissions  And while, they are not explicitly planned as mitigation efforts, these practices greatly affect our emissions output They include hosting our server infrastructure in a professional data center, designed and engineered specifically for the purpose of housing IT infrastructure, which allows purposeful design, economies of scales and elimination of superfluous energy wastage that can be found with a lower quality stand-alone data center Bankers made the conscious decision to run almost all of its server infrastructure as virtual servers several years ago, because virtualization of servers and consolidation of the devices onto blades that are meant to specifically share sever load dramatically reduces the overall power consumption and cooling needs

These are just some of the ways in which, Bankers overall business strategies consistent with climate change goals of assessing, mitigating or reducing emissions related to operations, despite not having a specific climate change plan
