We do, however, routinely contemplate the impact of climate change throughout the organization in various settings, including: the Emerging Hazards Committee, the Enterprise Risk Committee, the Enterprise Catastrophe Committee, and in meetings with the Board of Directors

We recognize the potential impact of climate change on our insurance book of business, the publics perception of corporate social responsibility and the regulatory environment related to climate change, including the potential impact on the value of securities issued by an entity and held in our investment portfolio

Climate change has the potential to significantly alter global weather patterns, possibly producing more frequent and/or more intense severe convective storms and hurricanes More intense storms may elevate the risk of both coastal and riverine flooding Wildfires could become more frequent and more difficult to control as drought patterns change Winter storms could drive cold weather conditions further south and into areas that are less prepared   For all of these potential weather changes, we utilize various commercially licensed software models and data to better understand the potential impact that adverse weather may have on policies we insure We also continue to monitor scientific progress to determine how climate change may impact CNA in ways not specifically accounted for by the models

With respect to operating risk, we have a Business Resiliency Program that is designed to protect employees and reputation, while keeping CNAs operations functioning at a level acceptable for serving our policyholders and shareholders in the event of a business interruption, regardless of cause As part of this program, we seek to ensure that our facilities have adequate back-up in place for data, access to IT infrastructure, remote application access, etc, so that we can respond quickly to climate-related emergencies without major disruption to our business processes These contingency plans are frequently tested and have occasionally been used in extreme weather-related incidents

We utilize our software models to determine the potential impact of weather events on all of our facilities We use this information to prioritize mitigation efforts, improve employee safety, and improve business resiliency

When evaluating investment decisions, we typically review information in the public domain, as well as in offering documents that detail the risks posed by the investment These disclosures usually include details surrounding the legislative risk posed by climate-related legislation (eg, introduction of a carbon tax for industries and activities that emit significant amounts of carbon dioxide, cap and trade legislation that sets allowable limits for emissions of carbon dioxide at a mandated cap while allowing for the trading of permits among industries to encourage lower emissions, etc), dependencies on various environmentally sensitive pricing (eg, commodity or energy prices), sensitivity to weather-related phenomena (eg, insurance or reinsurance company investments, hurricane exposure to offshore energy facilities, etc) and the like The amount of disclosure and the decision whether or not to buy or sell an investment in light of the risk (or lack thereof) will vary on a case by case basis

The process has four integrated components While assessing the risks during the risk assessment process, each risk is rated keeping in mind the financial impact to Cambia If a climate risk were to be identified during our risk assessment process, the current process will enable us to assess the degree of its impact to Cambia
 
From a financial liquidity perspective we do not test or take specific measures directly related to climate change We do not model and review the adequacy of our surplus and liquidity as a result of higher utilization of healthcare services We look to ensure that we have adequate layers of liquidity to meet these potential needs

At this time MVP feels that further research on the potential impact that climate change has on its investment portfolio is appropriate but that the current portfolio is well diversified and positioned to meet its objectives and risk tolerance 

GS Asset Managements OCIO team is in the process of researching the impact of climate change (physical risk and transition risk) on long-term capital market assumptions and developing climate change scenario and analysis that may potentially feed into their strategic asset allocation process This analysis has the potential to provide forward-looking actionable intelligence for assessing and managing the impact of climate related risks  It would also include sample scenario analysis regarding the transition to a low carbon economy

Fire risk associated with drought caused by climate change and exposure to fire is actively monitored by the Company and incorporated in its risk selection process Policies are in place in the event of a fire (or other event) causing office shut down or employees' inability to come to work

Scope of the process 
Aetna's Senior Vice President and Head of Marketing, Product and Communications, oversees Aetnas environmental sustainability practices, public policy positions, and Company responses and heads Aetnas Sustainability Council Various organizational personnel, eg, legal, insurance, real estate, and business functions, sit on the Sustainability Council and consider potential financial implications, regulatory factors, and reputational risk, using a risk management process An advisory group reports to the Council to assist in prioritizing new risks, investigate issues, and discuss new ideas
Risk management allows Aetna to identify our risks; describe them sufficiently to allow a prudent review; measure and prioritize risks; assess controls; and assess the degree to which those changes can affect our business This process is used to identify significant risks and/or opportunities that would potentially affect our business, including those from climate change
ii How risks/opportunities are assessed at the company level
Aetna assesses risks and opportunities on an individual basis with the primary focus on the impact to core business processes Of the factors reviewed, those carrying the most weight are exposure and impact Any climate change related issues that may have a significant and material impact to the company would be brought to the Council
Aetnas Sustainability Council, under the direction of the Senior Vice President and Head of Marketing, Product and Communications, facilitates the flow of environmental risk/opportunity development information to senior management
Aetna also has an Office of Business Continuity Management whose sole purpose is to maintain continuity of services throughout a natural or other form of disaster, including those caused, directly or indirectly, by climate change Aetna also maintains a Corporate Event Response Team (CERT), consisting of department heads (or their appointees) from across the Company, which convenes in response to various crisis events and to coordinate Aetnas response to those events Business Continuity Management advises and consults to the CERT during crisis events The CERT and Office of Business Continuity Management regularly perform drills and other exercises to ensure Aetna can respond with maximum effectiveness in the face of any kind of crisis We believe Aetna, through its CERT and BCO teams, is well positioned to respond to climate change related issues
iii How risks/opportunities are assessed at the asset level
Aetna operations and activities predominately occur within Aetna offices The main climate change impact at the offices at the asset level is real estate and procurement Aetnas Real Estate Services department considers environmental impacts when making office leasing and other facility decisions by assessing the exposure of Aetnas facilities, eg, business interruption due to severe weather events, and by incorporating criteria into the selection process, eg, determining if the location may be flooded Our business continuity assessments include the hazards posed by climate-related risks  including temperature changes, rising sea levels and severe weather conditions/natural disasters Aetna also considers such risks at all stages of our real estate life cycle  including selection, building design, and operation, eg, assessing a buildings involvement with the US Environmental Protection Agencys Energy Star program
Aetnas Procurement department and information technology areas similarly consider environmental impacts and enhancing sustainability practices in its equipment leasing, purchasing activities, and equipment end of life decisions Suppliers are evaluated annually on an enterprise level using a five-element scorecard followed by a strategic business review of the suppliers operational performance and level of compliance and risk A key component of the scorecard is an online sustainability assessment Opportunities for further development of sustainable business practices are discussed with each supplier
iv The frequency of monitoring (weeks/months/years)
Aetnas Sustainability Council reviews existing and newly trending environmental issues during scheduled meetings and receives input from the advisory groups Potential risks and impacts which may impact the corporation would be forwarded to the Aetna Executive Committee, as warranted
v Criteria for determining materiality/priorities
As discussed previously, potential risks are prioritized based on magnitude and likelihood of impact
vi To whom are the results reported
Aetnas Sustainability Council reviews existing and newly trending environmental issues during scheduled meetings Potential risks and impacts which may impact the corporation would be forwarded to the Aetna Executive Committee, as warranted

Company Name: Anthem Blue Cross Life and Health Insur
text:
As of year-end 2016 Anthem has reduced scope I and II GHG emissions intensity by 19% and is over 60% of goal  Anthem has reduced scope I and II GHG emissions by 22,781 Metric Tons CO2e compared to baseline year 2013

Anthem discloses all GHG emissions data via the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP)  For the 2017 disclosure all data was third party validated  To view Anthems latest disclosure please visit CDPnet

However, all of our insurance policies contain per occurrence and/or annual aggregate caps which mitigate this impact Our insurance policies do not have specific exclusions for geographical areas which may be seen as more prone to climate change risk
We seek to invest with investment managers that value and incorporate material ESG factors into their investment decision-making process
There is a corporate goal of energy reduction by 25% over a 10 year period  Efficiencies are handled as repairs/improvements are being made as opposed to a specific list

Our core risks have the potential to be affected by climate change, such as catastrophic mortality and morbidity due to natural disasters, including floods, tornadoes, earthquakes, hurricanes, and disease pandemics 

Such events could also lead to unexpected changes in persistency rates as policyholders and contract holders who are affected by the disaster may be unable to meet their contractual obligations, such as payment of premiums on our insurance policies or deposits into our investment products  A natural disaster or a disease pandemic could trigger an economic downturn in the areas directly or indirectly affected by the disaster, potentially impacting our investment portfolio The effectiveness of external parties, including governmental and nongovernmental organizations, in combating the spread and severity of a disease pandemic, could have a material impact on the losses experienced by us Further, in our group health and life operations, a localized event that affects the workplace of one or more of our customers could cause a significant loss due to mortality or morbidity claims  

These events have the potential to disrupt our business operations due to the impact on our employees and may negatively affect our ability to provide services to our customers and investors  The ability to continue to generate new business may also be affected

Our key risks affected by climate changes are brush fires and wind storms As further explained in the answer to question 3 above, CIG models these exposures and purchases reinsurance at appropriate levels to mitigate the financial risks of a catastrophic event CIG also sends news letters to our policyholders and has a web-site devoted to the safety and security of our policyholders The web-site is called The Protector Network and it has articles on such subjects as disaster preparedness, safety hints and fire prevention as more fully discussed in the answer to question 6 below Our risk exposure is throughout California; however CIG has a concentration of risks in the coastal areas such as Santa Barbara and Ventura

First, Mercury offers a number of credits for utilization of better building materials  Common examples would be credits for the installation of storm shutters or roofing materials that offer superior wind resistance  Second, Mercury surcharges areas that are more prone to weather-related events thus encouraging home building in less risky locations

In California, Mercury has changed the acceptability of homeowners policies with respect to wildfire risk  Recently, Mercury has been more open for this type of business than in past years, and we have adopted more rigorous underwriting processes for evaluating wildfire risk  Among the considerations are clearance around a home and being part of a Firewise community, which the homeowner and the community have some ability to control However, our view of wildfire risk has evolved with the events of 2017 and
2018  We now also have moratoriums in place for areas where our aggregate exposure has become too high  

The company provides tools and resources to policyholders so they can protect their homes before disaster strikes, and we offer discounts to those who proactively take steps to harden these same homes

As many people are taking steps to reduce their carbon footprint, the company is encouraging these actions by providing green discounts to their policyholders In California and New Jersey, the less you drive the more you can save as the companys focus is on mileage rating for these states Policyholders outside of California and New York, can receive a discount for owing and electric vehicle, and we provide green discounts on homeowners and business policies for buildings with LEED certifications

However, PHP is working to reduce environmental impacts in interactions with key constituencies such as members, providers, agents, and brokers through efforts to increase the move toward electronic communications

We do not create products and have a minimal impact on the environment We offer LTD, STD and Life policies The extreme weather and climate change could pose a threat to our policyholder's An individual could get injured or killed by extreme weather changes - blizzards, torrential rainstorms, flooding The probability of these weather-related events materially affecting our financial statement bottom line is minimal

Time is spent on strategy regarding concentration, reinsurance and pricing  The company has spent little or no time bringing increased awareness of climate risk to the client level other than farm clients as discussed in question 6
We have operations near the Gulf Coast and have taken special precautions due to hurricane risk

Company Name: Athene Annuity & Life Assurance Company of New York
text: Athene has an Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) program to identify, measure, mitigate, manage and report on all material risks to the company including emerging risks  The ERM program includes extensive stress testing to both sides of the balance sheet that captures a wide range of potential deviations from expected assumptions, and a range of severe scenarios and economic dislocations  At this time Athene does not believe climate change poses a material risk to its particular lines of business

Various organizational personnel, eg, legal, insurance, real estate, information technology and business functions, sit on the Sustainability Council and consider potential financial implications, regulatory factors, and reputational risk, using a risk management process An advisory group reports to the Council to assist in prioritizing new risks, investigate issues, and discuss new ideas
Risk management allows Aetna to identify our risks; describe them sufficiently to allow a prudent review; measure and prioritize risks; assess controls; and assess the degree to which those changes can affect our business This process is used to identify significant risks and/or opportunities that would potentially affect our business, including those from climate change

Aetna assesses risks and opportunities on an individual basis with the primary focus on the impact to core business processes Of the factors reviewed, those carrying the most weight are exposure and impact Any climate change related issues that may have a significant and material impact to the company would be brought to Aetna's Sustainability Council The Council facilitates the flow of environmental risk/opportunity development information to senior management

Aetna also has an Office of Business Continuity Management whose sole purpose is to maintain continuity of services throughout a natural or other form of disaster, including those caused, directly or indirectly, by climate change

Aetna's Real Estate Services department considers environmental impacts when making office leasing and other facility decisions by assessing the exposure of Aetna's facilities, eg, business interruption due to severe weather events, and by incorporating criteria into the selection process Our business continuity assessments include the hazards posed by climate-related risks

Aetna's Procurement department and Information Technology areas similarly consider environmental impact and enhancing sustainability practices in its equipment leasing, purchasing activities, and equipment end of life decisions  Procurement suppliers are evaluated annually on an enterprise level using a five element scorecard A component of the scorecard is an online sustainability assessment

Significant increases in natural perils shape our product
and geographic mix and growth targets Exposure to catastrophic events is also
considered in underwriting, pricing and reinsurance strategies
Our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) program is in development and while we do
not have a climate change policy, per se, climate change has been identified as a risk to
our property insurance line of business, with specific regard to impact and influence on
catastrophe risk
As part of formalizing our ERM program, we are presently identifying key risks,
including financial, across our operations, with consideration for current and forward
looking risks We plan to undertake an evaluation of mitigating factors and resulting
residual risks, in a proportional manner We expect monitoring and assessment to be
conducted on a quarterly basis, or more often if warranted The Audit Committee of the
Parents Board of Directors will oversee the ERM and are expected to receive quarterly
updates

The Chief Risk Officer meets annually with a well-respected research meteorologist to discuss all aspect of climate change and the risks posed to a Northeast property and casualty insurer

We have several communications with our independent agents and policyholders about disaster safety and planning and potential loss prevention or mitigation opportunities, the increase in severe weather and its impact on our business  We have discussed the strategies the company is employing to mitigate risk and lessen the impact of climate change to our financial condition

Arbella is a member of NAMIC who is an advocate for stronger, safer buildings for Americans NAMIC supports the BuildStrong Coalition which believes that safer building codes can save lives and reduce loss, especially from severe weather events NAMIC supports state and federal legislation to encourage the adoption and enforcement of strong building codes NAMIC and the BuildStrong Coalition support the creation of a separate, federal financial incentive for states that adopt and enforce statewide building codes 

Arbella has seats on the Massachusetts Property Insurance Underwriting Association (MPIUA) Board, Underwriting Committee and Investment Committee where it monitors key initiatives impacting the MPIUA and marketplace Participation additionally allows Arbella to partner with the MPIUA on mitigation and regulatory initiatives

Arbellas CEO, John Donohue, is a member of Boston Massachusetts Green Ribbon Commission, a group of Bostons top executives and community leaders tasked with providing advice and counsel to the City of Boston on the design and implementation of its Climate Action Plan  Arbella is an active participant in working with the Green Ribbon Commission as it works with the City of Boston, an area where many of Arbellas policyholders live and work, to build resiliency in the city and prepare for climate change

The Company does not believe that climate change will have a significant impact on the workers compensation market in the near future No additional catastrophic modeling is considered necessary at this point The Company has considered the potential impact climate change will have on future operations but does not believe any significant action will need to be taken until it is determined through our regular risk assessment process that climate change will adversely impact workers compensation insurance or if the concentrations in our investment portfolio shift towards investing in industries with future climate change exposure risk

Members of the executive committee own the risks and monitor activity related to each risk  The Groups risk management team meets with risk owners twice a year to formally identify risk which may include emerging risk from climate change  

A report on emerging risks is reviewed by the Group annually  New risks, potentially including climate related risk, are identified where relevant  The risk owners, risk management team and subsidiary boards provide support to the Group in performing this review of emerging risk

With a focus on commercial liability insurance, and limited property exposure, the Group does not believe that climate change will result in a major shift or lessen the demand for its products  Where relevant, the Groups underwriters do consider climate liability risk when underwriting a potential policyholder  For example property and treaty underwriters

Group underwriters also discuss areas of insufficient coverage with brokers and clients to identify potential new product offerings; this includes the impact of climate change

At this time, PCS has not specifically altered its investment strategy in response to these considerations However, the impact of climate change on investment assets is one of many measures considered by managers of our investment portfolio If climate change has a significant impact on any specific bond issuers, or the economy in general, investment losses could potentially occur

Company Name: New York Marine & General Insurance Company
text:
For example, we always encourage our auto policyholders to use telematics, not only because it makes drivers safer, but also because it encourages drivers to be more fuel efficient (wasteful speeding and rapid starts/stops are recorded) We also advise our fleet clients of risk management best practices, such as selecting drivers based upon their driving histories, including but not limited to speeding and reckless driving (which wastes fuel and results in greater emissions)
Our insureds understand that more miles driven and unnecessary personal use of company vehicles by employees increases their exposure to risk and usually their premium as well Insureds may be advised that reducing unnecessary miles driven and personal use of company vehicles by employees can reduce their premiums and also have a positive impact on climate change by reducing fuel usage and emissions
During our property surveys we always look at the age and condition of HVAC systems, electrical services, etc When these systems exceed 20 years of age, they are more likely to produce property claims from fires, etc When we identify these conditions, it is our standard practice to recommend that the client replace or upgrade their systems with units meeting current codes and standards Although we dont specifically ask insureds to replace old inefficient systems for efficiency purposes, our practices does have the effect of encouraging insureds to replace older systems with newer ones (which are also more efficient in virtually all cases) The use of LED lighting in warehouses is another example where ProSight and other insurers encourage clients to replace older, (inefficient & dangerous) metal halide lighting with newer systems that save tremendous amounts of energy (and are safer)  Additionally, loss control surveys also include assessment of risk exposures including vulnerability to flooding, power outages, brush fires, etc If we find situations which warrant improvement, we make recommendations to client to help them reduce chances of loss This has the side benefit of helping them deal more effectively with the impacts of climate change on their local environment
The Company recognizes the positive impact of solar energy on climate change, and in fact we are one of the fastest growing insurers of solar installers, through our solar installers insurance program
The Company loss control has the goal of helping to make our clients safer and more efficient The above examples are just some of the practices we have to encourage clients to address climate issues along with other aspects of safety & risk management
We believe current risks associated with climate change present minimal risk related to our business, including financial implications

Investment management is an integral part of our business Understanding the extent and how climate change will impact the value of investments is crucial Concerns about climate change are changing the way assets are managed and giving rise to new and alternative asset classes, especially in the field of renewable energy and carbon investments We are committed to integrating climate change  among other environmental, social and governance (ESG) factors - into our proprietary investment strategies and third-party asset management Customer demand, a growing recognition of the importance of ESG factors and better risk-adjusted returns are sound business reasons for integrating ESG factors in our investments By scrutinizing investments from an ESG perspective, we endeavor to identify long-term risks and opportunities that are not fully reflected in market prices and seek to capitalize on them for the benefit of shareholders, customers and other stakeholders This is especially relevant to us, because as an insurance company we manage and carry risk over very long time horizons  We are increasingly demonstrating our commitment to ESG by incorporating these factors in our investment strategies and asset management 
As a leading global insurance company and one of the world's top five asset managers, we are aware of the potential impact of our investment decisions We take seriously the responsibility that comes with the investment side of our business and are committed to systematically addressing controversial topics by integrating ESG considerations into our investment processes 
Sustainability in Proprietary Asset Management:
With proprietary assets of over 530 billion across a range of asset classes, sectors and countries, we are directly and indirectly connected with other businesses, sectors and economies, and are therefore an integral part of the globalized economy 
We strive to invest sustainably across all asset classes over time The practical implementation of sustainability in proprietary asset management involves integrating ESG factors into our investment process, for example through research, corporate and country analysis, asset manager selection, monitoring and risk management We firmly believe that considering ESG factors in investment management is not a short-term trend and over time will fundamentally change business, and consequently, investment performance 
Throughout 2013, we have developed an ESG Directive for Investments, which aims to integrate ESG as a standard practice into the management of Allianz insurance investment portfolios The Directive will be implemented in a step-by-step manner (2014-15) and intends to: 
Include ESG questions in the asset manager selection process
Assign asset managers to apply tailored ESG policies to the portfolios that they manage on behalf of Allianz
Include ESG-related topics during annual asset manager reviews 

Due to the range of asset classes we own around the world, the Directive does not provide a one- size fits all solution or standardized approach to ESG that all asset managers have to implement Instead, the responsibility for defining the best or most suitable ESG approach for a specific investment portfolio rests with the respective asset manager 
ESG factors are considered in investment processes for alternative investments, such as renewable energy, infrastructure investments, and real estate We are preparing the integration of ESG considerations into remaining asset classes in 2014 in line with our ESG Directive 
Furthermore, we continue to promote sustainable business practices within the companies we invest in Our approach is to seek dialogue to overcome challenges to sustainability For example we engaged with controversial sectors, such as extractive industries As a global investor we can have significant influence and we see it as our responsibility to promote sustainable business practices within the companies we invest in Our approach is to seek dialogue to overcome challenges to sustainability Throughout 2013, we have for example engaged with a major Asian energy company regarding environmental and HampS practices Furthermore, we successfully implemented an environment, social and governance (ESG) dialogue format, which continually engages a group of German and international NGOs The goal of this exchange is to establish an evidence-based dialogue built on trust and mutual understanding This allows our NGO partners to directly address Allianz with their concerns and gives Allianz the opportunity to listen and understand their different perspectives We can also tap into the expertise of NGO partners when formulating ESG positions and guidelines, incorporating their direct, on-the-ground experience of various topics Our ESG dialogue is part of our new ESG framework for the Allianz Group In this area, we plan to develop a formal ESG engagement framework to strengthen and standardize our approach to engagement with companies 
Acknowledging Boundaries:
As described above, engagement is particularly important for asset classes or investments where we cannot avoid indirect exposure to issues that could be considered controversial For example, due to our size we rely on broad indices with high liquidity as benchmarks for our large-scale investments While we need such instruments for diversification and hedging purposes, we have no influence on their composition Therefore we look to initiate and take part in dialogue with providers of such indices to determine how ESG issues can be integrated
Furthermore, as a large institutional investor, we aim to diversify our portfolio across many different sectors and companies Although some of these sectors are fundamental to economic progress, they are also prone to negative ESG impacts and may be controversial A typical example relates to fossil fuel generated power While there is the need to combat climate change, the rising global energy demand cannot be fulfilled without energy generated from fossil fuels For instance, renewable energy generation can be intermittent, so there is still a need for flexible back up from conventional energy sources when renewable energy supply cannot meet demand The use of fossil fuels will continue for the foreseeable future in order to meet rising global energy demand While we recognize the impacts of fossil fuels, we are not in a position to avoid such sectors as a general principle (as for example we do in the context of banned weapons, which our ESG process governs through a Group-wide exclusion applied to our proprietary investments, subject to limitations we are working to overcome when restricted companies are listed on major stock exchange indices, or where Allianz invests in investment funds managed by other organizations) As a result, and even though it might be perceived as a contradictory, we invest in both renewable and non-renewable sources of energy We see both sides of the argument  the need to contribute to global energy security and to economic development that relies on energy use, while also maintaining our commitment to contribute to a low-carbon economy
By the very nature of our business, insurance companies are also large- scale institutional investors and we take our responsibility as a provider of capital seriously Investment decisions are based on a systematic approach considering the potential risks and opportunities that could affect particular issuers and industries including considerations of climate change and other relevant ESG aspects material to the specific investment Going forward, we believe that an increasingly robust analysis of ESG-related issues is fundamental to understanding the long-term performance of investments We consider carbon being among the relevant environmental aspects for some investments, specifically for certain issuers and industries However, we do not consider carbon to be a steering metric for driving all investment decisions given the diversity of our investment portfolio, regulatory requirements and the fiduciary duty to our clients Additionally, the sole knowledge of carbon emissions would be a too narrow view - more importantly we need to understand the climate change context and adaptation strategies of issuers What is more, current levels of carbon emissions can lead to wrong conclusions as the competitive situation, regulatory environment, investments made and the long-term reduction path also need to be taken into account On top of this, there is no robust methodology and practicable approach, from an effort/ benefit perspective, available supporting the calculation of carbon footprint of investments Also, the availability and quality of carbon data is still insufficient Proposed approaches such as applying estimations and carbon footprint averages for whole industries reduce the meaningfulness of the information and, we do not deem it appropriate to base investment decisions on low quality data
Governance: 
At Allianz, all ESG related integration-activities (including with respect to climate change and investments) are centrally coordinated by the Group ESG Board, established in 2012 The ESG Board consists of three Allianz SE board members, responsible for the proprietary investments of Allianz, the asset management of Allianz as well as global corporate insurance lines The ESG Board determines yearly work-plans and holds ultimate accountability for integrating and strengthening ESG aspects within our insurance and investing activities 
The ESG Board meets quarterly and reports to the Group Finance and Risk Committee for decision-making Besides the designated ESG Board, several committees with Board member leadership play an important role in our decision-making processes: 
Group Finance and Risk Committee: controls adherence to the principles of the Group-wide capital- and liquidity planning as well as the investment strategy and prepares the risk strategy This includes establishing and controlling a Group-wide risk management and risk controlling system, also including sustainability risk The committee is also the decision- making body for ESG-related topics, based on analysis and deliberations within the ESG Board 
Group Investment Committee: oversees and reviews the investment activities of Allianz SE and Group companies in order to implement the Group Investment Strategy The committee also decides on concrete investment frameworks for covered investment assets 
In addition, several Board members assume direct responsibility for specific sustainability topics Functional departments also provide regular updates on sustainability issues directly to the Board 
With regard to responsible investment, the ESG Board: determines the overall ambition level for ESG integration into AZ proprietary investments; determines the specific ESG requirements towards Asset Managers, which will be incorporated in the RfP process and the Asset Manager selection process for new mandates; and receives regular updates on status of implementation and decides further implementation steps 
Board Members:
The Allianz SE Board Member responsible for Investments is responsible for ensuring that respective ESG Board decisions which regard responsible investment are carried out, and thus oversees the process of the ESG integration into Allianz' insurance investment portfolios 
AIlianz Investment Management (AIM) Leadership:
At Allianz, investment management is performed by a global function, Allianz Investment Management (AIM) It manages all assets covering the liabilities of all Allianz Group insurance companies AIM is responsible Asset-Liability Management, Investment Strategy and Asset Manager Management The latter includes the complete process of mandating internal/external Asset Managers for the management of Allianz assets
The CIO of Allianz Investment Management (AIM) obtains operative responsibility for carrying out ESG integration measures The CFO of Allianz Investment Management (AIM) obtains monitoring responsibility of the ESG integration into investments He further coordinates (1) the efforts of AIM Financial Control (AIM FC) in implementing concrete ESG requirements for the assets of Allianz insurance investment portfolios (proprietary assets); and (2) the efforts of AIM Asset Manager Management (AIM AMM) to consider the ESG approach and resources in the selection and regular reviews of Asset Managers 
Portfolio Managers/ external managers: 
Per the ESG Directive for Investments, all Asset Managers investing Allianz insurance investment portfolios are systematically assigned to develop and implement an ESG approach (process started in Q4 2013, to be completed throughout 2014-15) 

Due to the range of asset classes we own around the world, the Directive does not provide a one-size fits all solution or standardized approach to ESG that all asset managers have to implement Instead, the responsibility for defining the best or most suitable ESG approach for a specific investment portfolio rests with the respective asset manager 
Implementation is carried out by our mandated Asset Managers 
Carbon Investments:
Allianz is operating on a carbon neutral basis since 2012 In addition to continually reducing carbon emissions from our own operations, we offset remaining emissions through direct investments in carbon reduction initiatives, which generate CO2 certificates Investments to date include forest protection projects in Kenya and Indonesia (according to the UN, global deforestation is advancing alarmingly and currently accounts for around 17% of global greenhouse gas emissions) and an energy efficiency program in India, described below  Any remaining certificates after we offset our carbon footprint can be sold on the European carbon market to generate a financial return The carbon reduction projects we have invested in include:
Wildlife Works Carbon LLC (WWC): Through acquisition of a 10% share in this developer of REDD projects (Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and forest Degradation) we are supporting a forest protection project in Kenya WWC projects meet strict sustainability criteria and are the first of their kind to generate CO2 certificates By investing in WWC, we are highlighting REDD projects as an attractive investment option since they combine a high level of social and ecological responsibility with competitive returns for investors
Rimba Raya: In 2013, Allianz invested in the Rimba Raya (translated as eternal forest) project in Borneo (Indonesia), the world's first REDD project to bear the triple CCB Gold Label (Climate, Community amp Biodiversity Alliance) and the first that can generate certificates in line with the market-leading VCS (Voluntary Carbon Standard) With this investment, Allianz helps prevent deforestation of 64,000 hectares of forest avoiding the release of 90 million tons of CO2 
C-Quest Capital LLC (CQC): We are financing an energy-efficiency program implemented by CQC in India The program replaces incandescent light bulbs in private households with more energy-efficient and long-lasting compact fluorescent lamps (CFLs) The program allows private households to purchase CFLs at a greatly discounted price, enabling them to lower their energy bills and improving energy efficiency in a country that frequently experiences energy shortages
Investments in Renewable Energy: 
Concerns about climate change are changing the way assets are managed and have given rise to new, alternative asset classes, especially in the field of renewable energy and carbon Allianz is an early investor in these new asset classes, and as a result we have already gained valuable experience and are benefiting from the opportunities they offer We see renewables as an investment opportunity with an attractive risk-return profile and are expanding our investments Investments in renewable energy projects are expected to provide sound returns in the long run (renewable energy investments with a maturity of 25+ years are typical), which fits well with Allianzs long-term investment strategy, which calls for manageable risks and attractive returns for durations of 20 years or more  For these reasons, Allianz is aiming for additional volume of around 400mn a year in direct investments in renewable energy projects
As large institutional investors, insurance companies are important players in financing a low-carbon economy Since 2005, we have made direct investments in renewable energy projects and the total invested by the end of 2013 was 17 billion, making Allianz one of the largest investors in this field Our renewable energy portfolio now includes over 42 wind and 7 solar parks in Germany, France, and Italy and Sweden with a total asset base of over 1000MW of generating capacity  including 250MW from wind projects acquired in 2013 Group centers of competence like Allianz Climate Solutions and Allianz Center for Technology provide a comprehensive view of the risks associated with renewable energy technologies to ensure that Allianzs clean energy investments are sound investments with stable returns At present, Allianzs renewable energy investments are realizing return of between 6 and 8%  much higher than many other asset classes  and uncorrelated with the ups and downs of the financial markets
Investments placed on behalf of Allianzs US insurance operating entities continue to play a role in the Groups renewable energy finance position In 2012, Allianz Life Insurance Company of North America joined more than a dozen US insurance groups that invested $681 million in the Topaz Solar Farms as part of the California Organized Investment Network By producing a projected 550MW of electricity, Topaz will help the state comply with the California Renewable Portfolio Standards (RPS), which requires that by December 31, 2020, each California investor-owned utility must procure at least 33 percent of its retail electricity sales from renewable energy sources 
In 2013, Allianz Life invested $80M in three additional renewable energy projects, including:
The Tenaska Imperial South (Csolar IV South) project - located in Californias Imperial Valley - and its nearly 2 million solar panels that can generate enough electricity (130 MW) to power approximately 44,000 homes The project began full commercial operation in early November 213 and has a 25-year power purchase agreement with San Diego Gas and Electric (SDGampE) 
The Solar Star projects, co-located in Kern and Los Angeles counties in California, that will deliver 579MW from more than 17 million solar modules, when complete 
Continental Wind, a 667 MW portfolio of 13 operational wind farms located across the USA
Real Estate:
Allianz manages a global real estate portfolio of currently around 30 billion, mainly in continental Europe Allianz Real Estate (ARE), a subsidiary of the Allianz Group and a leading international real estate investment and asset manager, continues to expand its worldwide-diversified real estate portfolio Allianz Real Estate of America, acting as a principal on behalf of the Allianz Group insurance companies, makes equity investments and provides commercial mortgages in the American markets  including a US commercial loan portfolio in excess of $6 billion on behalf of Allianz Life Insurance Company of North America and Fireman's Fund  
Independently and as part of the Groups Risk Governance Structure as explained in response to question three (3) of this survey, ARE considers a variety of climate change related factors when assessing potential building investments, including for example the impact of natural catastrophes and climate impacts that contribute to high risk areas that may be excluded 
While adapting to physical impacts of climate change, real estate also needs to be part of the equation for climate and energy solutions  as buildings account for nearly 40% of both greenhouse gas emissions and energy consumption in the US, and globally An ARE pilot program in 2010 found that up to a 23 percent reduction in energy consumption and related carbon emissions could be achieved with relatively small investments Together with our tenants, we can work to increase energy efficiency and reduce carbon emissions
The ARE Sustainability Program:
ARE has a comprehensive sustainability program in place, with a focus on environmental factors, to support our Group commitment to significantly reduce carbon emissions and meet the demand for sustainable real estate 
The Allianz Real Estate sustainability program focuses on our core processes and creates a baseline and standards to assess our real estate's sustainability performance Environmental factors, such as energy consumption and carbon emissions, are the main focus area, which not only help our sustainability performance but also help to reduce operating cost for tenants, many of whom are Allianz entities 
The main activities of the Allianz Real Estate sustainability program are: 
Create Transparency 
Introduce common metrics for real estate sustainability
Assess and measure the sustainability status of ARE's real estate portfolio in a standardized way
Include sustainability in ARE's portfolio reporting 
Investment Management 
Include sustainability criteria in investment decision-making
Check the sustainability performance of new real estate investments as part of the acquisition process
Include energy efficiency and other sustainability topics in the due diligence process
Mandatory green building certification for new or refurbished assets (eg LEED, BREAM) 

Asset management 
Improve communication between ARE and tenants to improve sustainability performance
Include property-specific sustainability strategies into business plans Include energy efficiency into target setting with property and facility managers 
Assess individual properties' sustainability status using the Green Rating method (see below) 
Property management 
Measure, collect and report building information according to sustainability metrics 
Implement specific improvement measures in property planning Proactively suggest measures to further optimize buildings' sustainability performance 
Working with Policymakers amp Tenants:
Although the influence of sustainable properties has yet to fully materialize in the value of real estate, we see that regulatory requirements and changing market demand, especially on the tenant side, will force real estate owners to improve the environmental impact of their portfolios in the future  ARE actively engages with its tenants to further enhance the sustainability performance of its buildings  at the same time helping tenants to reduce their operating costs  ARE is taking the following measures to respond to changing customer behavior within our global real estate portfolio: upgrading properties (retrofit and refurbishment), adjusting portfolio strategy, and engaging with policy makers on related code and other mandates and incentives In general, tenants are developing a growing demand for sustainable space and energy efficient space  and ARE estimates that up to 5% of its current annual asset volume is required to comply with local regulations and to attract and meet the requirements of tenants demanding sustainable and energy-efficient properties
Standards amp Ratings: 
ARE is a founding member of the Green Rating Alliance (GRA), a European association of real estate owners and investors, auditors, industry bodies, measurement organizations and technology providers GRA has developed the Green Rating system, which provides a consistent approach to assessing, benchmarking and improving the environmental performance of existing buildings The Green Rating covers six core areas: energy, carbon, water, transport, wellbeing and waste ARE has assessed many of the existing commercial properties under management and all new investments using the Green Rating system Of all assets acquired since 2008, more than 20% have "green credentials" (eg Green Building Certification, Environmental Rating) 

From a risk perspective, Firemans Fund also houses significant green building expertise and plays a leading role in standards development, continuing to serve in 2013 as the first insurer elected to the US Green Building Councils National Board of Directors, thereby helping to shape the risk and value methodology behind the global expansion of the LEED green building standard 
Applicable sustainability standards vary around the world and within the United States, and are developing rapidly Concerned real estate managers and insurers are working with energy and building code regulators to find operating cost reductions aimed at carbon reduction and climate change objectives, alongside broader energy, environment and sustainability priorities Its essential that the insurance industry and its regulators work to consolidate and improve the many government and industry-led sustainable real estate standards, codes, and related performance and disclosure systems around common objectives and best practices, rather than create additional layers of reporting and requirements that may conflict with or duplicate existing efforts For real estate markets to internalize sustainable value drivers, the underlying standards, tools and reporting programs need to be clear and consistent 
Sustainability in 3rd Party Asset Management:
Allianz Asset Management (AAM), one of the worlds top five asset managers, is responsible for our third-party asset management business as well as for managing the majority of our proprietary assets AAM is home to two asset managers: Allianz Global Investors (AllianzGI) and PIMCO, a multi-asset global solutions provider 
Although these two subsidiaries have different regional focuses and investment strategies, embedding Environment, Social and Governance (ESG) issues into asset management and offering corresponding products and services is common practice in both Building strong ESG research capabilities, engaging with the companies they invest in and pursuing active share ownership through proxy voting, are at the heart of their ESG strategies
We manage a growing portfolio of Sustainable and Responsible Investments (SRI) By the end of 2013, total SRI assets managed by Allianz Asset Management (AAM) amounted to 957 billion, corresponding to 6% of AAMs total assets under management 
The largest share of AAMs total SRI assets under management are managed by PIMCO By the end of 2013, PIMCOs SRI investments totaled 782 billion (2012: 491 billion) In addition, Allianz Global Investors (AllianzGI) managed 175 billion (2012: 153 billion) of SRI investments, including the newly launched Renewable Energy Fund (AREF), which has so far attracted approximately 140mn in commitments from institutional investors 
A number of factors have driven this increase: SRI screening was introduced following a review of the investment criteria for some of the assets managed for Allianz Group; general market appreciation; and inflows of new assets from our third-party customers (including new customers) especially into fixed-income SRI products

Allianz GI:
AllianzGI seeks to be a leader in integrating ESG across the investment value chain:
1    Upstream - participating in multi-stakeholder initiatives to improve market governance
2    As an Investor - integrating ESG factors in its investment decisions
3    Downstream - encouraging improved governance and ESG performance of investee companies 
A global ESG team is responsible for ESG research, engagement and proxy voting, and ESG advisory services The teams services are utilized across our global investment platform, not just for our sustainable and responsible investment (SRI) portfolios They are also made available to the wider investment platform for use and consideration in mainstream investments
ESG Research:
Research is the cornerstone of our investment process at AllianzGI and ESG research is a component of equal importance We conduct proprietary, in-house qualitative and quantitative ESG analysis on a global universe of companies, sovereigns, covered bonds, government linked entities (agencies) and supranationals We apply both a quantitative and qualitative approach to identify and weigh material ESG factors for all business sectors and apply a best in class approach What is more, our proprietary research is also informed by external research 
Corporate Governance  proxy voting and engagement:
We have a policy in place and actively seek dialogue with companies we invest in AllianzGI has a proxy voting process in place with the Global Proxy Voting Committee and Global Corporate Governance Guidelines to provide for oversight and guidance to our Regional Proxy Voting Committees within our regional offices We want to ensure proxy voting decisions are in the best interest of our clients and take into account the most important ESG issues
When evaluating ESG issues, AllianzGI considers information from many sources, including our independent global proxy research provider, the relevant portfolio management team, the main analyst responsible for monitoring a particular company, the management of the company, and shareholder groups Engagement at AllianzGI involves two-way interaction with a company, either through presenting a viewpoint, seeking change or monitoring and documenting results We see that company engagement can improve ESG performance and reduce material ESG risks in owned companies
Beyond engagement with individual companies, other areas of ESG engagement include public policy initiatives and collective investor and multi-stakeholder engagement We feel that by selectively engagi

Company Name: Kaiser Foundation Health Plan of Washington
text:
Millions of people in KPs communities and beyond are being impacted by climate change-influenced wildfires and hurricanes KP worked to help reduce the effects of these disasters, because clean food and water, housing and power  as well as access to health care  are required to support good health and are essential to relief and recovery
KP continues to invest in state-of-the art technology to allow convenient access to high-quality care via secure messaging, telehealth, retail and employer-based clinics and mobile health vehicles These technologies and innovations help KP policyholders to potentially reduce their overall amounts of travel and travel-associated air pollution Kaiser Permanentes website, kporg, and its mobile apps, which allow access to personal medical information and communication with caregivers, were accessed over 850,000 times per day during 2018 Over 30 million prescriptions were requested via digital channels and more than 50 million lab results were viewed online in 2018 KP also uses teleconferencing, videoconferencing, and telepresence to reduce employee travel

Company Name: Great American E & S Insurance Company
text:
Please see the response to Question 6 above concerning materials the Company generally offers to insureds related to business continuity planning, emergency response planning, tornado safety and hurricane recovery  

Please see the response to Question 1 above concerning the steps the Company has taken with respect to employees, including recycling and commuting to work
When assessing other real estate transactions, emphasis and consideration are given to climate related issues

A maintenance fee is paid to an outside control center that monitors our HVAC system for the purpose of reducing energy consumption 

Reduction/Mitigation- All lighting in unused areas of our office are turned off Copy machines are kept on a power save mode Our paper shredding service recycles 100% of our consumption Old computers are sent to a computer recycling company and all printer cartridges are also recycled  We are also moving to more digital means of distributing documents to cut down on paper use All new appliances that have been purchased are energy start efficient We also offer work from home options and encourage our employees to ride bicycles to work
However, the Companies encourage clients to elect to receive certain financial documents online with an Electronic Delivery System (eDelivery), instead of paper

Examples of specific Westfield initiatives that have positively affected the environment include:
	Our Facilities team continually identifies and evaluates significant facility components that consume energy and strategies are developed to reduce consumption over the short and long term
	Continued with a lighting upgrade in the corporate headquarters that reduces the number of light fixtures by utilizing higher efficiency light fixtures LED lighting is also part of this upgrade
	Continued to look at opportunities to expand LED exterior lighting across the corporate campus 
	Implemented hands free, low flow faucets and flush valves and continue to look for similar opportunities to expand
	Implemented motion sensors to control lights in rest-rooms and conference rooms and continue to look for similar opportunities to expand
	Building automation systems to control and monitor heating/cooling and refrigeration equipment
	Utilization of the Medina County Waste Recycling Center for all trash generated at the Westfield Center campus
	Use of biodegradable water treatment chemicals for cooling tower applications
	Recycling of 600,000 lbs of paper each year
	Use of environmentally friendly cleaning chemicals in our housekeeping and food service operations
	Implementation of alternative energy vehicles including flex fuel, electric and hybrids into the fleet along with introduction of more fuel efficient models 
	Implementation of E-Pay, electronic pay stubs to replace paper versions
	Conversion of trade journals/periodicals from paper to electronic subscriptions
	Recycling of scrap metals and other construction materials
	Utilization of organic fertilizers and recycling of organic waste
	Use of recyclable building materials and low volatile organic compound (VOC) materials where appropriate
	Implemented technological enhancements to electronically capture and store documents to reduce paper consumption in conjunction with programs to encourage employees to print/copy less
	Implemented electronic processing platforms that negate the need for paper documents
	Personal computing equipment is recycled by donating items to local schools and non-profits
	Surplus office supplies are recycled/re-distributed throughout the organization and donations are made of supplies not needed
	Programs are in place to reduce the volume of printed reports which has resulted in a 30% reduction in the quantity of paper consumed  
	Alternative energy technologies are used where applicable to reduce reliance on traditional fuels  For example, we installed a solar powered weather warning system on our grounds
	Substituted battery powered hand tools replacing combustion engine hand tools in our grounds operations 
	We are using power metering equipment in the data center to analyze energy consumption and we will use the data for future IT equipment considerations
	A fulfillment program has been improved to reduce the storage of paper documents  Continue enhancements to our fulfillment approach to more print on demand technology
	We evaluate suppliers for their sustainability initiatives 
	Implemented use of walk off mats at entrances to reduce frequency of carpet cleaning and maximize life of standard carpet within facility
	Addition of more efficient paper towel dispensers and towels to reduce cost and waste
	Replaced vacuum cleaning equipment with Green certified equipment with HEPA filters to provide healthier work environment
	Private offices are built using Dirtt demountable walls; reuse of product over time instead of traditional building materials that are discarded when torn down 
	Maintain a corporate garden on the main campus that consists of 30 plots to grow vegetables and other herbs This is a team building initiative for employees to promote our health and wellness culture The garden uses all organic grown practices and materials

Company Name: Sun Life and Health Insurance Company U.S.
text:
S) The Company is wholly-owned by Sun Life Financial Inc (SLF Inc)

Sun Life has expanded the scope of its environmental reporting through a greenhouse gas (GHG) Framework which includes completed data collection and GHG emissions calculations for years 2007 through 2017 for its Real Estate Investment portfolio and leased properties in Canada, for years 2013 through 2017 for its United States (US) Real Estate Investment portfolio and for years 2014 through 2017 for its International Corporate Real Estate and Investments portfolio and corporate travel As we continue to collect consumption data and calculate emissions, we expect to develop a deeper understanding of our emissions sources and opportunities for reduction or mitigation 
Building on the significant progress made in 2016 to expand the scope of our environmental reporting, in 2017, Sun Life committed to short- and long-term global GHG reduction targets: reduce our GHG emissions intensity by 20% by 2020, and 30% by 2030 (relative to a 2014 baseline) 

Our total targeted global GHG emissions intensity decreased by 147% as of the end of 2017, compared to our 2014 baseline year While we have made strong progress, we anticipate that the level of effort, investment and commitment required to reach our 2020 and 2030 targets will increase over time We view these targets as ambitious, but achievable Our year-over-year decrease in targeted global GHG emissions intensity was 26%, keeping us on-track to exceed our 2020 target These reductions are the result of proactive energy and resource management in the investment portfolio, the implementation of tenant and employee engagement programs, and leveraging advanced data analytics to optimize building performance

Our target is composed of GHG emissions resulting from energy, water, and waste (where weight data exists), and normalized to remove the impact of changing weather, occupancy and exceptional loads, for Canada, United States and International Real Estate Investment properties where Sun Life has financial control, and global corporate real estate properties >40,000 ft² where Sun Life has financial control, and is measured on an intensity basis (tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent per square foot) relative to a 2014 baseline  Year-over-year reductions are calculated annually and cumulatively reported against the 2014 baseline Reported reductions account for the purchase of renewable energy credits and carbon offsets (net, market-based reporting)

Sun Life continues to focus on opportunities to reduce energy consumption and, in turn, to reduce GHG emissions Between 2015 and 2017, we achieved a 5% reduction in energy use intensity across our combined global corporate real estate and Real Estate Investment portfolio Our energy use intensity is declining as we continue to implement energy-efficiency projects and innovative energy management programs, and build employee and tenant awareness of their roles in reducing energy consumption

This modeling is done as part of Sentrys catastrophe reinsurance purchasing process It also relies on these models when making decisions on exposure aggregations 

Each model has its proficiencies and deficiencies within certain sub-sections of Sentrys book of business The models are compared to Sentrys history of actual catastrophe losses in order to give added context to the models Sentry also utilizes mapping tools to evaluate and assess exposures

S, assumed by Zurich though insurance policies To address the potential physical risks to its own operations, Zurich maintains and tests robust business continuity plans and also maintains property coverage that addresses flooding, windstorm and other perils Risks assumed through the issuance of insurance policies to customers are addressed as an integrated part of the underwriting process

Financial Risks - Physical risks impacting Zurichs customers may result in increased frequency and severity of certain claims These risks are addressed as an integrated part of the underwriting process

Investment Risks - See response to Question 5

Insurability Risks - In general, the insurance sector in the US and globally faces the challenge of maintaining the availability and affordability of insurance products while addressing the pressures imposed by potential changes in climate conditions A deep understanding of the risks posed by climate change, and options for adaptation to and mitigation of these risks, is necessary to adequately underwrite insurance products exposed to those risks

Regulatory Risks  Zurich has potential exposure to climate-related regulatory risks, both with respect to its own operations as well as those assumed through its products and services  New and enhanced regulationand the uncertainty leading up to such regulationin the insurance area and in areas as diverse as emission caps and building codes could impact the insurance sector, directly and indirectly These risks are addressed as an integrated part of the underwriting process and are monitored by our Government & Industry Affairs function

Reputational Risks  The reputation of companies perceived as not taking the climate change challenge seriously may be affected over time  Zurich has taken an active approach to dealing with these evolving issues, both as a matter of its commitment to customers and with respect to corporate and fiscal responsibilities
We are a life and annuity company thus this is a secondary effect for us

Humana is committed to integrating green building principles into our existing and new portfolio of facilities with a focus on energy and water efficiency Humana advanced this objective through the integration of climate and sustainability factors such as energy efficiency projects at our facilities, access to transportation, Energy Star or LEED guidelines, employee engagement (ie, behavioral change) and other parameters, into the decision criteria used to improve our facility portfolio and select future Humana locations  Opportunities for improving the portfolio and achieving energy and GHG reduction goals are identified by the Workplace Solutions team in collaboration with our external consulting partners  Initiatives may be evaluated and presented to the senior management for support and funding including capital investment, associate involvement (ie, resource support) or other requirements  

Our short-term strategy is informed by our environmental goals, influencing our team to focus on energy efficient operations within our owned and leased facilities, spurring direct investment in both financial and personnel resources These investments have enabled Humana to implement initiatives to achieve our targets such as an ongoing portfolio-wide LED lighting retrofit, which will result in over $1,080,200 in annual energy savings, as well as continued alignment with our previously developed comprehensive set of design standards for office and clinical operations to ensure consistency, energy efficiency, and sustainable practices across new builds and renovations Over the course of five years, we invested more than $69 million in building efficiency improvements, optimized our building occupancy rate, and implemented new energy-efficient processes and recycling standards Additional focus on infrastructure projects such as consistent BMS systems in our owned sites will create energy efficiencies We are also exploring renewable energy options to determine opportunity and feasibility toward setting a science-based target Finally, ongoing workspace optimization efforts increase workspace density while also decreasing building vacancies, thereby reducing our physical footprint and alleviating commute burden to reduce energy usage and emissions  

On the whole, energy use reduction and greenhouse gas emissions reduction efforts not only drive progress toward our sustainability goals, but also illustrate to our employees and customers our commitment to reduce GHG emissions and operate as efficiently as possible Employee engagement efforts include a continuing focus on increasing work from home with the understanding that this strategy will have a significant impact on Scope 3 emissions, while providing our workforce greater flexibility and reducing operational demands of our facilities

Our long-term strategy is impacted by potential consequences of climate change such as regulation, natural resource scarcity, facility operational costs and human health impacts Our Workplace Solutions leaders review short- and long-term trends and impacts associated with sustainability and refine our business strategy accordingly For example, Humana's portfolio includes both owned and leased assets where many facility investments are on a long-term basis (up to 10 years) Our sustainable real estate approach ensures these investments take into consideration the long-term impacts of building characteristics on climate change and overall environmental impact, employee wellness, and operational costs

C&F Risk Engineering provides educational materials to insureds that include specialized programs, such as Water Damage Minimization  property loss leader best mitigation practices, and Sprinkler Impairment and Fire Watch Tool Kits 
Risk Engineering conducts severe weather (hurricane, tornado, hail, wind, storm surge, and flood) assessments for prospective and existing customer locations, as well as wildfire assessments using advanced software analytics Clients with these exposures are subject to on site surveys with potential recommendation submission to increase protection  Overall, based on the coverage provided, Risk Engineering reviews the controls in place to prevent accidental losses  This may include a review of any interior and exterior drainage from the building and/or site, venting of airborne vapors and fumes, spill containment practices, etc  The Companys environmental group has also published a number of technical documents pertaining to chemical releases  These include:  spill and chemical incident response programs and procedures, underground storage tank claim procedures, the loading and unloading of top loading cargo tanks, cargo tank rollover prevention, etc

However, our primary office building is LEED certified and the management company has instituted the several programs to help reduce its tenants emissions, including the following: 
Building Automation system  after-hours shut off of over 80% of building lighting
Restroom Motion Sensors  saves approximately 216,000 kilowatt-hours per building per year
Energy efficient chemical water treatment  for cooling of buildings saves 750,000 kilowatt-hours pre year
Green Cleaning Chemicals  at least 60% of the cleaning and paper products used are approved as Green Seal and Environment choice for low VOC content and low environmental impact
Water Use Reduction  The installation of low flow, automatic water closets, urinals and faucets saves approximately 600,000 gallons per year compared to similar buildings 
Landlords in other of our office buildings have introduced similar programs
Additionally,there is building wide recycling program for paper, cardboard, plastic, metal, and batteries
We have not, therefore, delivered information to policyholders regarding potential reduction of losses associated with climate change

In addition, the Company has also taken steps to encourage policyholders to reduce their CO2 footprint and incorporate energy efficiency into their properties

Liberty Mutual offers its policyholders discounts for loss mitigation features (eg, storm shutters in hurricane exposed geographic areas) that act to directly reduce both the likelihood and magnitude of property damage from severe weather events Risk Management Guides covering all major natural catastrophe perils (eg, hurricanes, floods, hail) are made available to policyholders These guides outline numerous steps that policyholders can take to protect their properties and reduce the potential for damage related to severe weather events The Company also has Loss Prevention units staffed by engineers and other technical experts who consult directly with commercial property owners and develop customized action plans to reduce the susceptibility of losses due to severe weather events

Personal lines policyholders are incentivized to reduce their CO2 emissions through products that cover structural modifications such as installed solar panels with full replacement guarantees The Companys ByMile product incentivizes driving fewer miles by charging customers based on car usage For commercial lines, the Companys GreenSelectTM product enables policyholders to incorporate a wide array of energy efficiency features into their properties with full replacement in the event of damage Liberty Mutual also provides policy endorsements that enable policyholders to replace appliances and mechanical equipment with high efficiency versions in the event of a loss The ISO Green Upgrades product is also offered for commercial lines customers Energy customers  who are engaged in various aspects of upstream, midstream and downstream activities - that leverage renewable energy are insured via property, casualty, and surety products

This program reduces the impact of high energy costs and protects the environment  Examples of green actions taken by the Company include the following:

	Waste Prevention
o	As a standard business procedure, set all printer defaults to 2-sided 
o	Regularly consolidate and minimize number of mailings to each household
o	Continue to replace traditional print and mail with electronic delivery methods to distribute content for internal business partners and to our agents and policyholders

	Recycling	
o	Established an enterprise-wide program that encourages all paper waste be placed in shred bins; the company that shreds the paper waste then recycles it
o	Placed recycling bins in every building for glass, aluminum, steel cans and plastic  
o	Recycle and salvage all used electronic equipment through a registered recycling program
o	Recycle all cardboard received in our executive offices in Carmel, IN
o	Utilizing electronic payment options for customers to reduce paper 

	Energy Conservation
o	Track all electricity and natural gas usage, leveraging renewable (green) energy, and increasing Data Center temperatures at three sites by 6 degrees
o	Operate a Building Automation System in two of our locations, Carmel and Philadelphia, which allows control of electrical consumption
o	Installed a lighting and temperature control system in the Chicago office location to limit energy use, as well as, double pane glass on all outside windows in Carmel and Philadelphia
o	Conversion to LED lighting and utilization of light sensors
o	Installed multi-function devices (500+) that are Energy Star rated

	Water Conservation
o	Reduce the use of fertilizer and water in landscaping and mulch (rather than bag) cut grass
o	Installing sensor faucets and fixtures

	Transportation
o	Implemented alternative work arrangement policy that provides the opportunity for qualified associates in many departments to set flexible work hours and/or work from home via computer hook-up based on the needs of the business
o	Support video conferencing to connect remote sites for meetings to reduce the environmental impact of business travel
o	Installed bike racks to encourage employee travel by bicycle

	Purchasing
o	Purchase used furniture and equipment as a standard business practice

Initiatives and projects are being considered and evaluated on an on-going basis through the Green List These initiatives and projects are aimed at increasing the corporate awareness, engaging the associate base, and improve the overall company environmental practices
In the Company's risk assessment process, climate change has not been identified as a potential financial exposure for USLF

State National employs a conservative investment strategy designed to preserve capital, limit market risk, and maximize liquidity and flexibility for the payment of claims The portfolio comprises primarily short duration fixed income securities of high credit quality Due to the conseivat1ve nature of State National's investment strategy, we consider our portfolio to be low risk from a climate change perspective We routinely review our investment policy and any risks associated therewith, which would include climate change risks if they affect the portfolio State National does not currently anticipate any effect on its portfolio due to climate change
